His  animosity</span><span>  to  the  mother  country,  its  people  and  its</span><span>  institutions  is  so  intense  that  he  goes  out</span><span>  into  the  street  and  \"swears  at  large\"  in</span><span>  order  to  ease  his  mind.  As  to  her  land</span><span>  forces,  heinforms  us  that  \"a  couple  of</span><span>  French  army  corps  would  suffice  to  drive</span><span>  the  wonderful  army  of  England,  with  all</span><span>  her  Indian  and  colonial  troops,  to  the</span><span>  devil.\"  Whatever  reputation  it  may  have</span><span>  wrongfully  acquired  in  former  days  has  van-</span><span>  ished,  he  tells  us.  \"English  incendiarism</span><span>  in  South  Africa  has  tarnished  the  Iast  re-</span><span>  mains  of  England's  military  glory,  and</span><span>  branded  her  name  as  infamous  for  all  time.</span><span>  It  has  revealed  to  the  world  the  shameless-</span><span>  ness  of  the  English  character  and  an  un-</span><span>  \"scrupulousness  which  hesitates  at  nothing.\"</span><span>  Words  almost  fail  Herr  Meyer,  indeed,</span><span>  when  he  endeavors  to  express  his  contempt</span><span>  for  the  British  fleet,  and  his  enormous  ad-</span><span>  miration  for  that  of  Germany;  while  to</span><span>  those  who  are  capable  of  holding  up  the</span><span>  former  as  a  model  for  the  construction  of</span><span>  the  latter,  he  sarcastically  exclaims,  \"Eng-</span><span>  land,  powerful  at  sea,  and  therefore  on  land</span><span>  —  the  land  grabber  and  therefore  the  in-</span><span>  satiable;  England,  unscrupulous  in  her  am-</span><span>  bition,  and  therefore  breaking  up  in  an  ir-</span><span>  reparable  decay;  England  is  to  be  the  edu-</span><span>  cator  of  Germany!  Only  he  who  is  taken</span><span>  in  by  the  deceptions  conjured  up  by  the</span><span>  Protean  arts  and  duplicity  of  Britain  can</span><span>  allow  her  to  be  capable  of  such  a  task.\"</span><span>  Finally,  having  exhausted  his  tolerably</span><span>  copious  vocabulary  of  vituperation  in  ve-</span><span>  hement  abuse  of  our  countrymen,  Herr</span><span>  Meyer  winds  up  his  pamphlet  in  these  stir-</span><span>  ring  words:  —  \"Unite,  German  people,  in</span><span>  the  war  cry  of  Germany,  'Los  von  Eng-</span><span>  land!'\"  —  which  may  be  read  as  a  para-</span><span>  phrase  of  the  elder  Cato's  memorable</span><span>  words,  \"Delenda  est  Carthage.\"</span><span>  Having  listened  to  Herr  Meyer's  Anglo-</span><span>  phobic  declamation  against  the  \"infamous\"</span><span>  conduct  of  Great  Britain  in  the  Boer  cam-</span><span>  paign,  based,  as  a  matter  of  course,  upon</span><span>  the  monstrous  fabrications  invented  by  Dr.</span><span>  Leyds,  and  circulated  through  the  medium</span><span>  of  the  reptile  press  in  Germany  and  else-</span><span>  where,  it  is  amusing  to  turn  to  the  very</span><span>  next  article  in  the  same  number  of  the</span><span>  \"Contemporary,\"  and  to  read  Mr.  Auberon</span><span>  Herbert's  narrative,  mainly  drawn  from</span><span>  German  sources,  of  the  atrocities  perpe-</span><span>  trated  by  the  Germans  during  their  occu-</span><span>  pation  of  France  in  1870-71.  \"All  movable</span><span>  property  was  subject  to  demands  of  German</span><span>  commanders  to  be  transferred  by  the  horses</span><span>  and  labor  of  the  inhabitants  to  any  point</span><span>  directed. If  the  village  or  town  de-</span><span>  fended  its  property  the  penalty  was  burn-</span><span>  ing  of  the  village.  If  any  German  troops  al-</span><span>  lowed  themselves  to  be  surprised  in  any  vil-</span><span>  lage,  penalty—  burning  of  the  village. In  simi-</span><span>  lar  circumstances  in  France  thirty  years  ago</span><span>  every  inmate  of  the  habitation  would  have</span><span>  been  put  to  death  by  the  German  soldiery.</span></p> "

                        "articleText": "<p><span>  GERMAN  FINANCES.</span></p> <p><span>  Herr  Von  Koenneritz  writes</span></p> <p><span>  Sir,—In  connection  with  the  \"Economist's\"  state-</span></p> <p><span>  ment  regarding  the  position  of  the  German  finances,</span></p> <p><span>  it  may  not  be  without  interest  to  remind  your  readers</span></p> <p><span>  that,  compared  with  the  estimates  for  1907,  viz.,</span><span>  1,187,600,000  marks,  the  Empire's  receipts  during  last</span><span>  year  totalled  1,201,100,000  marks;  that  is,  roughly</span><span>  13,500,000  marks,  or  about  1  per  cent  more  than  had</span><span>  been  anticipated.  Compared  with  1906,  all  sources  of</span><span>  revenue,  except  two  show  increases,  as,  for  instance,</span><span>  Customs  duties,  643,000,000  marks,  or  88,400,000  marks</span><span>  more  than  during  the  previous  year.  Tobacco  and  cigar-</span></p> <p><span>  ettes  excise  duties  23,600,000  marks,  or  7,000,000  marks</span><span>  more,  distilled  excise  duties  112,600,000  marks,  or</span><span>  7,800,000  marks  more,  brewing  excise  duties  51,100,000</span><span>  marks,  or  8,200,000  marks  more,  etc.  The  two  excep-</span><span>  tions  referred  to  are  the  stamp  duties  on  revenue-pro-</span><span>  ducing  stocks  and  on  Bourse  transactions,  which  together</span></p> <p><span>  yielded  22,900,000  marks  less  than  in  1906.  But  against</span><span>  this  it  should  be  remembered  that  they  had  been  un-</span><span>  naturally  high  during  that  year.  All  other  sources</span><span>  of  revenue  together  show  an  increase  of  160,000,000</span><span>  marks  in  round  figures,  so  that  if  we  deduct  the  lesser</span><span>  yield  of  the  Bourse  transactions,  there  still  remains  for</span><span>  1907  an  excess  of  revenue  of  137,000,000  marks  in  round</span><span>  figures  as  compared  to  the  previous  year.  Moreover,</span><span>  the  fact  should  not  be  lost  sight  of  that  of  the  new</span><span>  duties  passed  in  1906,  obviously  none  were  able  to</span><span>  yield  their  full  measure  of  revenue  in  1907.  This  will</span><span>  only  be  the  case  in  1910,  and  not  before.  This  much,</span><span>  however,  may  safely  be  predicted—that  the  expecta-</span><span>  tions  which  led  to  the  imposition  of  the  new  duties</span><span>  will  be  fully  justified;  in  fact,  in  some  instances,  the</span><span>  yield  has  already  come  up  to  the  estimates.</span></p> "

                        "articleText": "<p><span>  GERMAN.</span></p> <p><span>  Herr  Dernburg,  the  Kaiser's  Press  agent  for</span><span>  America,  and  probably  one  of  the  most  blun-</span><span>  dering  and  thoughtless  persons  in  the  World,</span><span>  has  deemed  it  fit  to  deliver  himself  publicly  on</span><span>  the  subject  of  —  tact!</span></p> <p><span>  It  was  at  a  meeting  of  a  league  newly-form-</span><span>  ed  in  Berlin  with  a  view  to  expanding  German</span><span>  industrial  interests  in  the  South  American</span><span>  continent.  Herr  Dernburg,  who  had  been  elec-</span><span>  ted  president,  said,  according  to  a  Reuter  mes-</span><span>  sage  from  Amsterdam  received  recently:  —</span><span>  'Germany  has  only  a  few  friends  in  the</span><span>  world.  Feeling  in  South  America  is  divided,</span><span>  and  real  neutrality  in  North  America  is  also</span><span>  doubtful.</span><span>  'It  is  not  uninteresting  to  note  how  Lord</span><span>  Haldane  at  Manchester  explained  to  British</span><span>  merchants  that  now  a  favorable  opportunity</span><span>  had  come  to  snatch  away  from  Germany  her</span><span>  commercial  supremacy  for  ever.</span><span>  \"For  generations  to  come,  we  need  not  fear</span><span>  competition  abroad,  though,  if  the  present  war  ,.?.'.</span><span>  Iasts  a  long  time,  commerce  will,  at  last,  be</span><span>  obliged  to  find  new  outlets,  and  the  recapture</span><span>  of  the  ground  now  lost  will  become  more  dif-</span><span>  ficult.</span><span>  \"For  coal  and  iron  South  America  will  be</span><span>  dependent  on  the  industrial  States  for  a  long</span><span>  time  to  come,  and,  therefore,  the  investment</span><span>  of  more  capital  in  South  America  will  be  well</span><span>  worth  while  for  commercial  reasons,  and  also</span><span>  in  order  to  regain  lost  ground.</span><span>  ''Besides  strengthening  our  economic  influ-</span><span>  ence,  the  obtaining  of  a  certain  intellectual</span><span>  influence  will  be  of  an  importance  which,  up</span></p> <p><span>  till  now,  has  been  greatly  under-estimated.</span><span>  \"We  have  not  understood  the  soul  of  the</span><span>  South  Americans,  and  not  of  them  alone.  For</span><span>  this  reason,  we  find  few  friends  among  neu-</span><span>  trals.  This  is  largely  the  fault  of  the  Ger-</span><span>  mans,  who  must  learn  to  understand  foreigners</span><span>  and  introduce  German  achievements  in  science</span><span>  and  art  with  more  discretion  than  heretofore.</span><span>  \"Only  too  often  the  German  merchant  shows</span><span>  an  absence  of  that  friendly  feeling  towards</span><span>  merchants  abroad  which  is  of  special  weight</span><span>  with  Southern  people.\"</span></p> "

                        "snippet": "It is a mistake to suppose, when reading of peace talk in Germany, that the topic is a new one there. It is not. I heard the German",
                        "troveUrl": "https://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article144792699?searchTerm=german+date%3A%5B1910-01-01T00%3A00%3A00Z+TO+1919-12-31T00%3A00%3A00Z%5D",

                        "articleText": "<p><span>  German  Ideas  of  Peace</span></p> <p><span>  By  D.  Thomas  Curtin</span></p> <p><span>  It  is  a  mistake  to  suppose,  when</span><span>  reading  of  peace  talk  in  Germany,</span><span>  that  the  topic  is  a  new  one  there.</span><span>  It  is  not.  I  heard  the  German</span><span>  people  talking  peace  a  month  after</span><span>  the  outbreak  of  war—of  a  peace</span></p> <p><span>  to  be  sure  which  Germany  would</span><span>  dictate  and  keep.  When  the</span><span>  Fatherland  was  winning  I  heard  no</span><span>  discordant  note.  That  was  owing</span></p> <p><span>  to  the  general  belief  in  and  eager-</span><span>  ness  for  certain  victory  and  vast</span><span>  annexation  which  prevailed  then.</span><span>  To-day  the  Germans  —  with  the</span><span>  exception  of  a  minority  of  extreme</span><span>  Social  Democrats  —  are  no  less</span><span>  united  in  their  desire  to  get  all  they</span><span>  can,  but  they  are  not  all  united  in</span><span>  their  opinions  as  to  how  much  they</span><span>  can  get.  Hence,  after  the  French</span><span>  definitely  blocked  the  German  of-</span><span>  fensive  at  Verdun  and  the  British</span><span>  Fleet  grip  more  and  more  tightly</span><span>  the  economic  life  of  German,  a</span></p> <p><span>  </span><span>  bewildering  variety  of  Kriegsziele</span><span>  (war  aims)  was  discussed  by  all</span><span>  classes  of  people.</span><span>  The  National  Liberal  Party  in</span><span>  Germany,  as  I  have  already  in-</span><span>  dicated  in  a  previous  article  on</span><span>  submarines,  is  backing  a  gigantic</span><span>  and  aggressive  plan  for  German</span><span>  world-domination  through  a  colossal</span><span>  organisation  and  expansion  of  Ger-</span><span>  man  commerce  and  industry.  The</span><span>  great  captains  of  industry  who  con-</span><span>  trol  the  party  believe  in  the  em-</span><span>  ployment  of  the  German  Army  and</span><span>  Navy  to  further  their  ends  —  i.e.,  to</span><span>  secure  permanently  for  Germany</span></p> <p><span>  the  mining  regions  of  Northern</span><span>  France  and  the  coal  and  shipping</span><span>  of  Belgium  ;  and  to  cripple  rival</span><span>  commerce,  not  only  as  a  means  of</span><span>  winning  the  war,  but  also  of  limit-</span><span>  ing  competition  against  them  after</span><span>  wards.  These  are  the  men  behind</span><span>  Tirpitz,  and  they  are  working,  and</span><span>  will  continue  to  work,  to  restore</span><span>  him  to  power.</span><span>  Dr  Stresemann,  one  of  the  most</span><span>  influential  National  Liberals,  is  a</span><span>  dynamo  of  energy  in  German  com-</span><span>  mercial  plans.  His  eyes  sparkling</span><span>  with  zeal,  reddish  hair,  a  clear,</span><span>  metallic  voice,  he  is  a  heavy  man</span><span>  physically,  wielding  a  tremendous</span><span>  and  growing  power  in  Germany  to-</span><span>  day.  He  has  a  controlling  interest</span><span>  in  a  recently  organised  combination</span><span>  of  some  two  thousand  manufactur-</span><span>  ing  firms,  and  is  practically  dictator</span><span>  of  the  Sachsische  Handelsgesell-</span><span>  schaft  and  the  Deutsch-Amerikan-</span><span>  ische  Wirthschaftsverband.</span><span>  He  became  one  of  theChancellor's</span><span>  most  out-spoken  enemies  at  the</span></p> <p><span>  time  of  the  Danish  concessions  to</span><span>  America,  and  his  fiery  advocacy  of</span><span>  relentless  submarine  warfare  has</span><span>  earned  him  a  reputation  for  fright-</span><span>  fulness,  even  in  Germany.  He  be-</span><span>  longs  to  the  Western  School  of  pre-</span><span>  sent-day  Germany  —  the  school</span><span>  which  believes  in  placating  Russia</span><span>  (to  be  followed  by  a  peaceful  pene-</span><span>  tration  of  that  country)  and  the</span><span>  smashing  as  far  as  possible  of</span><span>  Britain  and  France.  As  his  utter-</span><span>  ances  in  the  Reichstag  plainly  show,</span><span>  he  is  passionately  anti-American  in</span><span>  general  and  anti-Wilson  in  par-</span><span>  ticular.</span><span>  Since  he  is  one  of  the  foremost</span><span>  Germans  in  the  great  campaign</span><span>  against  Great  Britain  both  during</span><span>  and  after  the  war,  Dr  Stresemann's</span><span>  views  should  be  of  particular  in-</span><span>  terest.  His  most  recent  utterances</span><span>  agree  in  the  main  with  those  he</span><span>  made  in  an  interview  which  he  gave</span><span>  me,  and  which  I  duly  communi-</span><span>  cated  to  American  newspapers</span><span>  through  the  Wilhelmstrasse.  There</span><span>  are,  however,  some  important  dif-</span><span>  ferences  which  I  shall  point  out</span></p> <p><span>  later.</span><span>  \"How  seriously  do  German  in-</span><span>  dustrial  circles  regard  the  Paris</span><span>  Economic  Conference?\"  was  the</span><span>  first  question  I  put  to  Dr  Strese-</span><span>  mann.</span><span>  \"If  one  is  to  attach  great  import-</span><span>  ance  to  the  words  of  the  political</span><span>  economists  of  the  Entente,\"  he  be-</span><span>  gan,  \"then  we  must  agree  that  we</span><span>  might  have  considerable  anxiety</span><span>  and  alarm  about  our  industrial  fut-</span><span>  ure;  but,  as  a  matter  of  fact,  Ger-</span><span>  man  industrial  circles  view  these</span><span>  endeavors  of  our  enemies  with  calm-</span><span>  ness  of  indifference.</span><span>  \"Russia  cannot  emancipate  her-</span><span>  self  from  German  industry.  As</span><span>  for  France,  she  may  look  to  a  boy-</span><span>  cott  of  German  wares.  Yet  that</span></p> <p><span>  will  make  no  appreciable  difference</span><span>  in  our  world  trade,  even  though</span><span>  here  and  there  we  may  drop  a  few</span><span>  million  marks.  We  have  but  to</span><span>  consider  France's  tremendous  losses</span><span>  in  relation  to  her  already  falling</span><span>  birthrate  before  the  war  to  realise</span><span>  that  France  must  inevitably  sink  to</span><span>  the  rank  of  a  third  rate  Power.</span><span>  \"After  the  war  Great  Britain  will</span><span>  probably  stand  united  against  us,</span><span>  politically  and  economically,  but</span><span>  we  fear  her  just  as  little  as  we  fear</span><span>  Russia  and  France.  We  rely  first</span><span>  of  all  upon  the  peerless  quality  of</span><span>  our  goods  —  just  think  of  our</span><span>  chemical,  textile,  and  toy  monopo-</span><span>  lies,  and  the  like  —  and,  secondly,</span><span>  we  rely  on  our  unsurpassed  mar-</span><span>  kets  for  consumption.</span><span>  \"In  1913  we  imported  for  ex-</span><span>  ample,  from  Great  Britain  and</span><span>  her  colonies  2,109  ,000,000  marks</span><span>  (£105,450,000)  worth  of  goods.</span><span>  Do  you  for  a  moment  believe  that</span><span>  our  rival  is  going  to  sacrifice  such</span><span>  a  tremendous  volume  of  business</span><span>  for  the  sake  of  a  personal  spite?</span><span>  Any  tariff  war  which  is  waged</span><span>  against  us  can  injure  us,  but  it  is</span><span>  bound  to  injure  the  side  just  as</span><span>  much.  That  will  be  realised  all</span><span>  the  more  in  England,  since  these</span><span>  threats  drive  us  into  a  closer  trade</span><span>  and  industrial  relationship  with</span><span>  our  allies,  thus  affording  us  a</span><span>  greater  extent  of  united  industrial</span><span>  territory  to  oppose  the  industrial</span><span>  chicaneries  which  our  enemies  have</span><span>  developed  during  the  war.  In  this</span><span>  we  shall  undoubtedly  be  successful</span><span>  at  the  Peace  conference.</span><span>  \"With  the  United  States  we</span></p> <p><span>  shall  resume  trade  immediagelyafter</span><span>  the  end  of  hostilities.  The  war</span><span>  has  caused  both  of  us  to  become  un-</span><span>  comfortably  short  in  some.  com-</span><span>  modities.  Consequently,  the  first</span><span>  demands  after  our  resumption  of</span><span>  trade  will  restrict  free  competition,</span><span>  since  both  sides  must  limit  them-</span><span>  selves  at  first  to  importing  the  most</span><span>  necessary  commodities.  You  will</span><span>  need  dyestuffs,  for  example  ;  we</span><span>  must  have  certain  raw  materials.</span><span>  \"To  be  sure,  trade  rivalry  will  be</span><span>  keen  in  other  markets,  especially  in</span><span>  South  America.  It  is  there  where</span><span>  immense  capital  is  necessary  for</span><span>  extensive  undertakings,  and  we</span><span>  fully  realise  your  advantage  over</span><span>  us  for  the  present  in  this  respect,</span><span>  for  it  is  you  who  have  made  the</span><span>  greatest  economic  gain  out  from  the</span><span>  world  war,  a  gain  which  puts</span><span>  millions  upon  millions  of  ready</span><span>  money,  while  bleeding  Europe  will</span><span>  emerge  from  the  struggle  economi-</span><span>  cally  weakened.</span><span>  \"We  Germans  would  not  dispute</span><span>  your  legal  right  if  you  would  balance</span><span>  the  munition  deliveries  to  our</span><span>  enemies  with  raw  materials  and</span></p> <p><span>  foodstuffs  to  us.\"</span><span>  Dr  Streseman  then  went  on  to</span><span>  explain  that  America  did  not  really</span><span>  understand  Germany  because  she</span><span>  looked  at  her  through  the  \"dis-</span><span>  torted  eyeglasses  Of  Reuter.\"  \"It</span><span>  is  only  in  British  fancy,\"  he  said,</span><span>  \"that  we  are  going  to  wage  war</span><span>  against  Brazil  or  other  South</span><span>  American  States  in  order  to  establish</span><span>  colonies.</span><span>  \"You  look  calmly  on  while</span><span>  Britain  rules  half  the  world,  while</span><span>  she  militarily  controls  the  gates</span><span>  of  the  world  in  Egypt,  India,</span></p> <p><span>  Cape  Colony,  Canada,  and  Gib-</span><span>  raltar.  In  your  opinion  that  is  all</span><span>  right  ;  but  if  in  peace  time  Ger-</span><span>  many  indicated  that  she  wished  a</span><span>  coaling  station  or  two  to  protect  her</span><span>  vast  trade,  then  half  the  press  of</span><span>  the  universe  rose  in  an  outcry</span><span>  against  the  German  lust  for  'con-</span><span>  quest'  and  the  'world  domination'</span><span>  she  wished  to  establish.  We  stand</span><span>  second  in  world  trade.  In  exports</span><span>  we  are  only  300,000,000  marks</span><span>  (£15,000,000)  behind  England,</span><span>  and  we  surpassed  her  by  more  than</span><span>  3,000,000,000  marks  (£150,000,</span><span>  000)  in  exports,  if  we  exclude</span><span>  British  exports  to  her  own  Colonial</span><span>  Emgire,  which  buys  4,000,000,000</span><span>  marks'  (£200,000,000)  worth  of</span><span>  goods  from  her  annually,  she  would</span><span>  long  ago  have  been  defeated  by</span><span>  Germany  in  free  world  competition</span><span>  —  defeated,  however  not  by  unfair</span><span>  methods,  but  by  the  superior  qual-</span><span>  ity  of  German  goods.\"'</span><span>  In  the  \"Through  German  Eyes\"</span><span>  column  of  ''The  Times\"  recently</span><span>  is  discernable  a  more  anxious</span><span>  strain  in  Dr  Stresemann's  remarks</span><span>  concerning  the  Paris  Economic</span><span>  Conference.  Russia,  in  particular,</span><span>  seems  to  have  considerably  dis-</span><span>  mayed  him.  The  meeting  of  the</span><span>  Russo-British  Chamber  of  Com-</span><span>  merce  at  the  Savoy  Hotel,  at  which</span><span>  Count  Benchendorff,  the  Russian</span><span>  Ambassador,  presided,  should</span><span>  prove  further  unpleasant  news  in</span><span>  the  Fatherland.</span><span>  Note  that  Dr  Stresemann  now</span><span>  says:—  'We  do  not  yet  know  the</span><span>  end  of  the  struggle.  We  know</span><span>  that  we  are  military  invincible.</span><span>  But  wherever  an  economic  heel  of</span><span>  Achilles  shows  itself  England  will</span><span>  make  every  attempt  to  bleed  us  to</span><span>  death.  The  peace  must  include</span><span>  the  restoration  of  free  competition</span><span>  in  face  of  the  resolution  of  the</span><span>  Paris  Conference.  When  free  com-</span><span>  petition  is  restored  nothing  can</span><span>  frighten  us,  because  we  know  that</span><span>  in  this  freedom  Germany  can  win</span><span>  the  victory.\"—  \"The  Times.\"</span></p> "

Although  the  weatber  was</span><span>  very  threatening  about  thirty  couples</span><span>  were  present.  During  tbe  evening</span><span>  a  presentation  was  made  to  the  worthy</span></p> <p><span>  secretary,  Mr.  W.  L.  O'Brien.  Mr.</span><span>  A.  Lowe  mads  the  presentation,  and</span><span>  in  a  few  fitting  words  said  that  the</span><span>  Club  was  indebted  to  Mr.  O'Brien</span><span>  for  his  untiring  efforts  in  furthering</span><span>  its  interests.  Mr.  M.  Robson  endors-</span><span>  ed  the  last  speaker's  remarks,  and</span><span>  said  be  hoped  that  although  Mr.</span><span>  O'Brien  was  not  actually  in  harness</span><span>  he  hoped  the  CIub  would  not  lose  one</span><span>  of  its  most  energetic  members.  Mr.</span><span>  O'Brien  in  responding,  said  he  tried</span><span>  to  do  his  best  in  the  interests  of  the</span><span>  Club,  but  through  pressure  of  busi-</span><span>  ness  he  was  unable  to  do  it  justice,</span><span>  so  he  thought  it  better  for  the  Club</span><span>  if  he  allowed  some  one  else  to  fill  his</span><span>  place.  He  again  thanked  the  mem-</span><span>  bers,  and  said  he  would  continue  to</span><span>  do  his  utmost  to  advance  its  interests.</span><span>  A  tennis  match  was  played  between</span><span>  Bannockburn  and  Gratnau  last  Satur-</span><span>  day.  The  game  was  very  evenly  and</span><span>  keenly  contested,  and  was  won  by</span><span>  Bannockburn  by  the  narrow  margin</span><span>  of  4  games.</span><span>  We  have  experienced  several  frosts</span><span>  during  the  last  few  weeks,  and  of</span><span>  course  everybody  is  wishing  winter</span></p> <p><span>  over,  and  the  nice  warm  days  in  its</span><span>  stead.  Last  Thursday  at  the  School</span><span>  at  9  a.m.  it  was  32  degrees,  a  record</span><span>  for  this  year  up  to  the  present.  By</span><span>  the  way,  the  local  school  garden  at</span><span>  the  present  is  looking  in  tip  top</span><span>  order,  although  it  cannot  boast  of  a</span><span>  garden  equal  to  \"Andersons\"  it  will</span><span>  in  the  near  future  eclipse  many  so-</span><span>  called  gardens.</span><span>  At  the  present  time  the  local  school</span><span>  is  half-time,  but  it  is  to  be  hoped</span><span>  that  before  long  it  will  be  made  into</span><span>  a  provisional. It  is  estimated  that  Germany</span><span>  lost  7,000,000  by  the  cession  of</span><span>  territories  under  the  Peace  Treaty,</span><span>  2,750,000  from  deaths  in  wartime,  and</span><span>  2,500,000  by  the  decrease  of  the  birthrate</span><span>  in  wartime;  therefore,  but  for  tho</span><span>  war  the  population  would  have  been</span><span>  75,000,000.                         "articleText": "<p><span>  GERIAN  INDUSTRY.</span><span>  Sir  Philip  Gibbs  gives  a  remarkable</span><span>  account  of  the  new  spirit  and  the  re</span><span>  newal  of  industry  in  Germany.</span><span>  \"Her  people  are  working  harder  than</span><span>  any  others,  at  lower  wages,  and  with</span><span>  more  efficient  organisation.  They  have</span><span>  been  braced  by  defeat,  whereas  the</span><span>  victor  nations,  and  above  all  Great</span><span>  Britain,  have  been  slackened  by  victory,\"</span><span>  he  writes  in  the  \"Review  of  Reviews.\"</span><span>  The  Change  in  the  People.</span><span>  \"When  I  went  first  into  Germany</span><span>  after  the  armistice  the  people  seemed</span><span>  stupefied  by  what  had  befallen  them.</span><span>  All  their  faith  had  been  shattered  by</span><span>  the  downfall  of  their  armies,  and  they</span><span>  were  afraid  of  revolution,  and  hopeless.</span><span>  ly  uncertain  of  the  future.  Many  of</span><span>  them,  ;especially  the  women  and  chil</span><span>  dren,  were  still  suffering  from  the</span><span>  effects'  of  long  under-feeding,  ,prices  of</span><span>  food,  clothing,  and  other  necessities  of</span><span>  life  were  above  the  reach  of  working</span><span>  folk,  demobilised  soldiers  were  not  yet</span><span>  assimilated  into  civil  life.  and  the  spirit</span><span>  of  the  people  was  dejected  and  de</span><span>  spairing.</span><span>  \"Now,  in  Berlin  the  general'  appear</span><span>  ance  of  the  people  is  not  miserable  but</span><span>  cheerful,  not  dejected  but  alert  and  con</span><span>  fident.  One  does  not  see  crowds  of</span><span>  listless  unemployed  men  hanging  about</span><span>  labour  exchanges  or  rattling  collecting</span><span>  boxes  in  the  faces  of  the  passers-by.</span><span>  One  sees  crowds  of  men  stepping  out</span><span>  briskly,  obviously  employed,  well-dressed,</span><span>  well-fed,  keen\"  on  their  jobs,  doing  good</span><span>  business.</span><span>  Krupp's  5s.  Day.</span><span>  \"The  German  working  man  in  Krupp's</span><span>  factories  and  others,  is  paid  60  marks</span><span>  a  day.  At  the  old  value  of  the  mark</span><span>  that  would  be  £3.  At  the  present  value,</span><span>  inside  Germany  itself,  I  reckon  it  as</span><span>  five  shillings.</span><span>  \"For  an  eight-hour  day  it  works  out</span><span>  at  74d.  an  houi  compared  with  1s.  9d.</span><span>  to  2s.  6d.  an  hour  of  the  mechanic  in</span><span>  \\Great  Britain.</span><span>  \"The  German  working  man  on  60</span><span>  marks  a.  day  gets  almost  enough  to  eat</span><span>  (never  enough  meat),  almost  enough</span><span>  to  support  a  wife  and  small  family,  almost</span><span>  enough  to  make  himself  satisfied'  with</span><span>  his  job.  By  strict  attention  to  economy,</span><span>  he  can  squeeze  out  a  few  marks  for</span><span>  the  simple  pleasures  of  his  leisure  hours,</span><span>  which  consist  mostly  in  light  beer  and</span><span>  light  music  in  some  public  garden  or</span><span>  beer-hall.</span><span>  \"The  professional  classes,  and  the</span><span>  clerical  classes  (city  clerks,  typists,  etc.)</span><span>  are  not  so  well  off  relatively  as  the</span><span>  mechanics'  and  labourers.  Whereas  the</span><span>  cost  of  living  has  increased  from  eight</span><span>  to  10  times,  the  salaries  of</span><span>  professors,  teachers,  civil  .servants,</span><span>  and  others  have  only  risen  from  4</span><span>  to  6  times.  It  is  they  who  are  most</span><span>  pinched  'and  reduced  to  desperate</span><span>  straits  in  order  to  'keep  up  appear</span><span>  ances.  .</span><span>  A  New  Industrial  Organisation.</span><span>  \"Now,  upon  the  great  mass  of  cheap</span><span>  labour  German  capitalists  are  building</span><span>  up  a  new  and  intensive  sytem  .of  indus</span><span>  trial  organisation,  beyond  anything  the</span><span>  world  has  previously  seen  in  efficiency</span><span>  and  driving  power.  Hugo  Stinnes,and</span><span>  his'great  Trust,  controlling  a  vast  mo</span><span>  nopoly  of  coal,  iron  and  steel,  of  whom</span><span>  there  has  been  much  talk,  because  he  re</span><span>  presents  most  powerfully  'this  new</span><span>  phase  of  German  energy,  is  only  one</span><span>  of  a  score  of  other  magnates  who  prac</span><span>  tically  control  the  whole  industrial  life</span><span>  of  .Germany,  and  are  the  real  rulers  of.</span><span>  the  State.</span><span>  \"Their  method  is  what  is  described</span><span>  as  the  creation  of  'vertical'  trusts.</span><span>  That  is  to  say,  by  a  combination  and  pool</span><span>  ing  of  many  companies  in  possession  of</span><span>  raw  material  and  industrial  plant  they</span><span>  build  up  an  immense  production  .of  manu</span><span>  factured  articles  which  have  that  raw</span><span>  material  as  their  basis.</span><span>  Krupp's  Peaceful  Output.</span><span>  \"Thus  the  great  munition  works  of</span><span>  Krupp,  entirely  engaged  in,  the  produc</span><span>  tion  of  guns  and  armaments  during  the</span><span>  war  'bon  a  colossal  scale,  read  the  lesson</span><span>  of  defeat,  and  within  a  few  months  after</span><span>  the  Armistice,  adapted  their  plant  and</span><span>  their  organising  genius  in  a  marvellous</span><span>  way  to  the  requirements  of  peace.  They</span><span>  are  now  making  engines  and  machinery</span><span>  of  all  kinds,  agricultural  implements,</span><span>  cash  registers,  safety  razors,  and  any</span><span>  kind  of  article  in  iron  and  steel  for</span><span>  which  there  is  a  world  market.  The</span><span>  General  Electric  Company  is  also  de</span><span>  veloping  its  energy  with  gigantic  strides,</span><span>  reaching  out  to  'neutral'  countries  and</span><span>  absorbing  many  industrial  concerns  of</span><span>  which  the  basis  of  activity  is  coal  and</span><span>  iron  and  electrical  power,  in  Austria,</span><span>  Hungary,  and  other  countries..</span><span>  \"These  great  Trusts,  are  already  cap</span><span>  turing  the  world's  markets,  and  have</span><span>  already  succeeded  in  recovering  some</span><span>  of  the  pre-war.  prosperity  of  German</span><span>  trade-which  is  almost  a  miracle  con</span><span>  sidering  the  ruin  of  the  German  economic</span><span>  system  by  the  exhaustion  of  a  bloody</span><span>  and  unsuccessful  war,  the  loss  of</span><span>  colonies,  shipping,  and  foreign  pro</span><span>  perty,  the  loss  of  man  power,  and  the</span><span>  deterioration  of  machinery,  railways,</span><span>  and  rolling  stock.</span><span>  Imports  Falling  Off.</span><span>  '¶masing  as  all  this  is,  however,  one</span><span>  must  not  exaggerate  the  actual  results.</span><span>  Germany  is  not  rolling  in  wealth,  as  some</span><span>  observers  have  reported.  Apart  alto</span><span>  gether  from  her  international  debts</span><span>  leaving  on  one  side  altogether  the  gigantic</span><span>  payments  of  the  indemnities  which  she</span><span>  has  undertaken-her  industry  and  com</span><span>  merce  are  about  two-thirds  normal  com</span><span>  pared  with  the  pre-war  standard.  Her</span><span>  imports  of  cotton  amount  to  nearly  half</span><span>  of  thcse  in  1913.  Her  ioal  output  during</span><span>  the  first  four  months  of  this  year  was</span><span>  44,500,000  tons  compared  with  57,000,000</span><span>  toxas  in  the  same  period  of  1913.</span><span>  \"Half  the  amount  of  pre-war  tonnage</span><span>  (largely  under  foreign  flags)  is  now</span><span>  coming  into  the  port  of  Iamburg.</span></p> <p><span>  If  They  Pay!</span><span>  \"All  this  is  a  sign  of  industrial  and</span><span>  conmmunercial  recovery,  astoundmg  as  a</span><span>  proof  of  cnergy,  industry,  and  organised</span><span>  efficiency,  after  the  shock  of  national  de</span><span>  feat.  But  those  German  people  who</span><span>  have  put  up  such  a  tremendous  fight</span><span>  for  their  old  place  in  the  world  are  now</span><span>  confronted  with  the  necessity  of  paying</span><span>  indemnities  to  the  victor  nations  which</span><span>  will  test  their  power  of  recovery  to  the</span><span>  uttermost  and  demand  new  and  unpre</span><span>  cedented  efforts.  It  is  not  going  to  be</span><span>  easy  for  them  to  pay.  If  they  suc</span><span>  ceel,  it  will  be  the  greatest  industrial</span><span>  adventure  ever  undertaken  by  any  people</span><span>  in  the  world.  To  succeed  they  must  in</span><span>  crease  their  volume  of  exports  by  at</span><span>  least  fotir  times,  which  would  be  an</span><span>  achievement  unrivalled  in  the  industrial</span><span>  history  of  the  world.  Con  they  do  that.</span><span>  and  if  they  do  what  will  be  the  effect</span><span>  upon  other  nations?</span><span>  \"It  has  already  been  asked  by  Mr.</span><span>  Reginald  McKenna.  What  will  happen</span><span>  to  British  trade  if  Germany  pays  her</span><span>  indemnities  in  the  only  way  possible</span><span>  by  an  immense  increase  of  exports?</span><span>  The  very  fulfilment  of  her  pledges  will</span><span>  ruin  the  countries  receiving  payment  by</span><span>  the  destruction  of  their  own  export</span><span>  trade.  .o  we  reach  the  monstrous  para</span><span>  dox  that  in  shouting  *Make  Germany</span><span>  pay!'  we  were  insisting  upon  our  own</span><span>  ruin.                         "articleText": "<p><span>  GERMAN  DEBTS.</span></p> <p><span>  When  Germany,  a  month  ago,  placed  an  embargo  upon</span><span>  the  import  of  wool,  amongst  other  raw  materials,  it  was</span><span>  noted  here  that  this  situation  had  been  arrived  at  as  part  of</span><span>  a  German  programme  to  bring  pressure  to  bear  upon  her</span><span>  debtors  in  regard  to  the  payment  of  the  debts  owed  by  that</span><span>  country  overseas.</span></p> <p><span>  For  some  two  years  now  Germany  has  not  been  paying  the</span><span>  interest  upon  her  debts,  whilst  instalments  of  principal  long  ago</span><span>  ceased.  A  crisis  has  now  been  reached  with  the  refusal  of  Germany,</span><span>  through  the  mouth  of  Dr.  Schacht  (president  of  the  Reichsbank),</span><span>  to  pay  interest  or  any  proportion  of  interest  upon  her  debts,  includ</span><span>  ing  the  Dawes  and  Young  loans.  This  step  amounts  to  repudiation.</span><span>  The  requests,  polite  enough  in  all  conscience,  of  the  British  and</span><span>  French  Governments  for  further  information  on  the  situation,  are</span><span>  declared  by  the  Nazi  organs  to  be.  'mere  bluff'  and  the  principal</span><span>  Nazi  newspaper  states  that,  should  England  take  any  active  steps</span><span>  against  Germany  in  regard  to  these  debts,  Germany  would  'retaliate</span><span>  against  the  whole  British  Empire  which  sells  considerably  more  to</span><span>  Germany  than  it  buys  from  her'.</span><span>  'Whilst  it  may  be  true  that  Germany  buys  more  from  the  British</span><span>  Empire  than  that  Empire  buys  from  her,  the  thought  might  occur</span><span>  even  to  the  Nazi  intelligence  that  it  is  no  benefit  to  sell  to  a  country</span><span>  which  does  not  pay.  It  is  better  to  be  without  the  business.</span><span>  .  Ever  since  the  AVar  period,  German  national  finance  has  been</span><span>  a  stumbling  block  to  Europe.  After  the  inflation  period  the  Dawes</span><span>  loan  was  floated,  for  the  purpose  of  putting  Germany  upon  her</span><span>  financial  feet  and  restoring  her  currency.  When  the  final  reparation</span><span>  settlement  was  arrived  at,  the  Young  loan  was  floated  to  assist  in  that</span><span>  settlement.  Germany  had  the  money  but  reparations  have  been  done</span><span>  away  with.  At  every  turn  Germany  has  scored,  and  she  proposed</span><span>  to  crown  her  victories  of  the  past  by  an  open  repudiation  of  her</span><span>  international  obligations.  It  may  or  it  may  not  be  surprising  that</span><span>  Nazi  finance  should  in  the  end  come  down  to  the  same  level  as  the</span><span>  finance  of  the  Bolshevists,  to  whom  the  Nazi  spirit  is  alleged  to  be</span><span>  so  opposed.</span><span>  The  affair  may  prove  to  be  a  further  lesson,  and  it  may  be</span><span>  hoped  a  lesson  which  will  sink  home,  to  those  who  for  so  long  have</span><span>  argued  that  the  reconstruction  of  world  trade  can  only  be,  or  chiefly</span><span>  be,  accomplished  by  the  financial  reconstruction  of  Europe.  Hun</span><span>  dreds  of  millions  of  pounds  have  been  lent  to  the  countries  of  Central</span><span>  Europe  for  reconstruction  purposes,  with  the  consequence  that,  with</span><span>  one  exception  (Czechoslovakia),  they  are  all  to-day  as  bankrupt  as</span><span>  they  ever  were.</span></p> "

                        "articleText": "<p><span>  GERMAN  AFFAIRS.</span></p> <p><span>  On  Sunday  last  a  plebiscite  was  held  in  Germany,  by</span><span>  which  it  was  supposedly  intended  that  the  people  of  Ger</span><span>  -  many  should  Have  an  opportunity  of  expressing  their</span><span>  opinion  of  the  amalgamation  of  the  two  offices  of  President</span><span>  of  the  Republic  and  Chancellor  in  the  person  of  Adolf</span><span>  Hitler,  the  Chancellor.</span></p> <p><span>  Previous  to  the  plebiscite  an  intensive  campaign  had  been  under</span><span>  taken  by  microphone,  through  the  press,  by  every  sort  of  emotional</span><span>  excitement,  to  ensure  that  the  result  of  the  voting  should  be  in</span><span>  the  affirmative.  Considering  the  circumstances  of  government  in</span><span>  Germany  to-day,  there  could  never  have  been  much  doubt  upon</span><span>  this  point,  because  it  is  an  acknowledged  rule  of  Nazidom,  expressed</span><span>  many  times  by  Herren  Hitler,  Goering  and  Goebbels,  that  there</span><span>  can  be  no  opposition,  no  other  way  of  thinking  in  Germany  to</span><span>  that  which  these  gentlemen  dictate.</span><span>  The  result  of  the  plebiscite  was  in  the  affirmative,  and  it  has</span><span>  even  been  described  as  a  victorious  result.  Upon  examining  the</span><span>  figures,  however,  it  is  quite  clear  that  the  Nazi  Government  is  by  no</span><span>  means  as  popular  as  might  appear  from  the  figures.  About  10  per</span><span>  cent,  of  the  population  had  the  courage  to  vote  'No,'  whilst  almost</span><span>  as  many  again  either  spoilt  their  ballot  papers  or  did  not  vote  at</span><span>  all.  It  is  to  be  assumed  that  those  who  spoilt  their  papers  and  did</span><span>  not  vote  were  definitely  opposed  to  the  present  regime  but  had  not</span><span>  got  the  courage  to  say  so.</span><span>  After  all,  the  present  circumstances  of  Germany  are  particularly</span><span>  unhappy.  The  country  is  on  the  verge  of  bankruptcy;  the  restric</span><span>  tions  upon  food,  clothing  and  raw  materials  are  reminiscent  of  war</span><span>  time  measures:  the  Roman  Catholic  Church  is  deeply  dissatisfied,</span><span>  and  the  Protestant  Church  not  less  so  ;  the  great  Industrialists  view</span><span>  with  horror  the  swing  of  Nazi  economic  doctrine  towards  Com</span><span>  munism  ;  even  in  the  ranks  of  Hitlerdom  there  is  certainly  great</span><span>  unrest.  Foreign  observers  in  the  country  regard  the  situation</span><span>  internally  with  considerable  apprehension.</span><span>  The  events  of  June  30,  when  a  number  of  Storm  Troopers  were</span><span>  shot  out  of  hand,  when  General  von  Schleicher  and  his  wife  were</span><span>  assassinated,  and  an  unknown  number  of  persons  disposed  of,  have</span><span>  left  a  very  sour  impression  in  Germany  as  to  the  future.  The  re</span><span>  ception  accorded  to  the  Chancellor,  when  he  addressed  the  Reichstag</span><span>  a  fortnight  after  those  events,  was  cool  in  the  extreme.  The  per</span><span>  sonal  accounts  of  eye  witnesses  are  now  available  in  Australia,  and</span><span>  confirm  in  every  detail  and  strengthen  the  observations  which  were</span><span>  cabled  to  this  country  at  that  time.  The  position  has  been  summed</span><span>  up  as  representing  the  end  of  Nazism  as  it  has  been  in  the  past,  and</span><span>  the  beginning  of  its  end  altogether.</span><span>  The  internal  position  in  Germany  is  of  the  first  importance,  not</span><span>  only  to  Germany,  but  to  the  rest  of  the  world,  because,  whatever</span><span>  happens  in  that  country  must  seriously  affect  affairs  in  other  parts</span><span>  of  the  world,  particularly  the  present  stage  of  economic  recovery.</span><span>  This  has  been  seen  in  Australia  by  the  fall  in  the  wool  market,  fol</span><span>  lowing  upon  the  embargo  laid  by  Germany  upon  the  import  of  raw</span><span>  material.  It  is  the  continued  uncertainty  as  to  what  will  eventuate</span><span>  in  that  country  which  still  dominates  the  wool  market,  and  indeed,</span><span>  all  other  markets  for  raw  materials.</span><span>  It  is  not  until  Germany  becomes  stabilised  under  one  form  of</span><span>  Government  or  another,  and  until  what  Shakespeare  calls  'the</span><span>  alarums  and  excursions'  in  that  country  cease,  and  its  unhappy</span><span>  people  can  settle  down  to  internal  peace  and  internal  development,</span><span>  that  the  general  situation  can  right  itself.</span></p> "

'  Throughout  the  speech  we</span><span>  seem  to  hear  the  clashing  of  arms,</span><span>  but  with  a  mediaeval  flavour,  as</span><span>  though  some  ancient  chivalry</span><span>  under  the  stress  of  emotion  were</span></p> <p><span>  banging  swords  and  maces  against</span><span>  shields  for'the  especial  purpose  of</span><span>  terrifying  their  enemies. Goods  or  materials  are  taken</span><span>  to  the  amount  of  the  credits  extended.</span><span>  :  Since  1918  credits  have  been  extend</span><span>  ed  to  Germany  through  the  control  re</span><span>  serve  franking  system  in  America  and</span><span>  England,  and  Germany  as  a  conse</span><span>  quence  has  become  so  completely  or</span><span>  ganised  in  air,  field  and  naval  arma</span><span>  ments  that  she  is  able  to  ignore  the</span><span>  League  of  Nations,  defy  the  world  and</span><span>  .hop  over  and  win  unopposed  conquests,</span><span>  and  the  prevaricating,  subtle,  under</span><span>  mining  diplomacy  stills  prevails  to  draw</span><span>  further  goods  and  materials  to  the</span><span>  strorighold.  Blatantly  denying</span><span>  the  responsibility  for  the  last  war,  she</span><span>  may  yet  blame  Britain  for  the  next  be</span><span>  cause  the  world  is  not  willing  to  hand</span><span>  over  mandated  territories  upon  demand.</span><span>  It  must  be  clearly  ,  understood  that  the</span><span>  world  is  not  dealing  with  German</span><span>  people,  who  are  a  very  fine  race.  A</span><span>  gang  of  fiends  who  are  organising  world</span><span>  wide  mass  murder,  hide  behind  all  this</span><span>  vast  camouflage  and  the  German  people</span><span>  are  .  hungry  because  their  resources,</span><span>  energy  and  hundreds  of  millions  Of</span><span>  pounds  of  their  wealth  are  absorbed</span><span>  annually  in  the  maintenance  and  fur</span><span>  ther  development  of  the  mighty  war</span><span>  organisation.</span><span>  The  bluff  about  being  unable  to  pay</span><span>  has  continued  all  too  long. For  six  months'  war</span><span>  she  exacted  a  fine  of  £200,000,000  —  and</span><span>  Alsace-Lorraine! Austria  accepted</span><span>  its  defeat,  and  has  honestly  paid,  as  far</span><span>  as  possible  the  price  of  defeat!  As  a</span><span>  result,  it  has  the  sympathy  and  help  of</span><span>  Europe,  and  is  back  towards  prosper</span><span>  ity. It  is  to  be  sincerely  hoped  that</span><span>  the  Federal  Government  will  not  miss</span><span>  the  opportunity  of  securing  as  many</span><span>  as  possible  ol  those  industrious  people.</span><span>  For  if  we  do  not  secure  them,  Canada</span><span>  or  Argentina  will  gladly  welcome  them</span><span>  to  their  shores. Their</span><span>  activities  were  not  confined  to  one</span></p> <p><span>  crop,  or  one  district.                         "tag": [],
                        "comment": [],
                        "articleText": "<p><span>  GERMAN  TALES  IN  GERMAN</span></p> <p><span>  THE  enterprise  of  the  Melbourne  University</span><span>  Press  in  publishing  \"Five  German  Tales,\"  intended</span><span>  as  \"attractive  reading  matter  for  pupils  '  who</span><span>  have  studied  the  language  for  at  least  one  year,\"  is</span><span>  praiseworthy,  especially  in  war-time.  The  tales</span><span>  chosen  are  \"from  among  the  most  charming  Marchen</span><span>  in  German  literature,\"  but  it  is  questionable  whether</span><span>  they  make  a  suitable  text-book  for  the  readers  the</span><span>  editor  has  in  mind.  German  fairy  tales  are  full  of</span><span>  obsolete  words  and  archaic  constructions  that  may</span><span>  be  attractive  for  the  educated  German  reader,  but</span><span>  are  difficult  for  even  well-advanced  students.  Moreover,</span><span>  German  style  has  changed  greatly  since  the</span><span>  time  of  the  Brothers  Grimm.  The  stark  vigour  of</span><span>  Luther's  prose,  the  Gallic  rococo  of  the  early</span><span>  eighteenth  century,  the  classic  solidity  of  Goethe  and</span><span>  Schiller,  and  even  post-war  German,  differs  widely</span></p> <p><span>  enqugh  to  be  almost  a  different  language.  The</span><span>  sentence  of  seven  lines  (page  78)  is  characteristic</span><span>  of  the  time  of  Schiller  and  Goethe,  but  no  intermediate</span><span>  pupil  in  Germany  to-day  would  be  allowed  to  write</span><span>  in  such  a  style,  any  more  than  a  modern  English</span><span>  child  would  be  encouraged  to  write  in  the  language</span><span>  of  Johnston  or  Goldsmith.  We  think  that  text-books</span><span>  for  beginners  should  make  the  student  acquainted</span><span>  with  the  living  rather  than  the  dead  language  by</span><span>  interesting  him  in  stories  of  contemporary  life.  In</span><span>  practice,  too,  it  would  be  better  if  the  help  provided</span><span>  at  the  end  of  the  book  (notes,  vocabulary,  etc.)  were</span><span>  spread  through  the  book  at  the  head  of  chapters</span><span>  or  at  the  bottom  of  the  page.</span><span>  Five  German  Tales.</span><span>  By  Professor  A.  Lodewyckx.</span><span>  Melbourne</span><span>  University  Press.</span><span>  Price  2/3.</span></p> "

(It  is</span><span>  •only  a  little  more  than  a  centi.ry</span><span>  •since  the  Jews  have  been  permit</span><span>  ted  to  join  the  European  life  with</span><span>  equal  rights—and  that  indeed</span><span>  only  formally,  not  even  practic</span><span>  ally—-and  this  permission  has  al</span><span>  ready  been  revoked  again,  It  is</span><span>  instructive  to  remember  that  cruel</span><span>  fact. And  it  Is  almost  in</span><span>  credible  how  marvellously  they</span><span>  succeeded  in  nearly  every  cultural</span><span>  province.</span></p> <p><span>  At  first  thought  it  may  seem</span><span>  not  worth  the  while  to  remember</span><span>  what  the  Jews  have  achieved  in</span><span>  Germany  and  for  Germany.  In</span><span>  deed  the  wheels  of  history  will  not</span><span>  be  turned  into  any  other  direction</span><span>  by  the  statement  how  much  the</span><span>  Jews  have  added  to  the  benefit</span><span>  of  German  name  and  German</span><span>  fame. So  powerful  was  the  mental</span><span>  energy  that  became  free  and  ru</span><span>  shed  down  into  every  district  of</span><span>  spiritual  activity.  Impossible  to</span><span>  count  down  every  Jew  who  has</span><span>  added  stones  to  the  edifice  of  Ger</span><span>  man  art  and  science.  We  can  give</span><span>  only  a  few  names  out  of  thou</span><span>  sands.  But  we  can  appraise  the</span><span>  real  significance  of  that  powerful,</span><span>  stream  of  spii’itual  fructification</span><span>  only  if  we  consider  that  the  Jews</span><span>  comprising  but  1  per  cent  of  the</span><span>  German  population  at  once  took</span><span>  part  in  the  building  up  of  the  cul</span><span>  tural  life  by  contributors  out</span><span>  numbering  10  or  even  20  times</span><span>  their  actual  proportion  of  the  po</span><span>  pulation.  An  example  may  make</span><span>  it  clear  how  this  miraculous  fact</span><span>  turned  out  to  be  of  almost  in</span><span>  credible  .  effects:  The  Jews  for  in</span><span>  stance  brought  forth  9  remarkable</span><span>  composers  in  a  little  more  than</span><span>  one  century;  the  Germans,  in  or</span><span>  der  to  keep  pace  should  have  had</span><span>  to  muster  900  (!)  equivalent  ta</span><span>  lents  or  take  another  example:</span><span>  About  25  per  cent  of  the  German</span><span>  Nobel-prize  winners  were  Jews,</span><span>  equal  to  five  .times  more  than</span><span>  their  proportion.  And  so  it/-  was</span><span>  in  nearly  every  district  of  cultural</span></p> <p><span>  life.</span></p> <p><span>  At  the  beginning  of  that  “Pe-  ,</span><span>  riod  of  Enlightenment”,  stands  the</span><span>  venerable  figure  of  the  poor  hunch</span><span>  backed  office  clerk  and  great</span><span>  philosopher  Moses  Mendelssohn,</span><span>  the  friend  of  Lessing.  He  was  still</span><span>  deep-rooted  in  Jewish  feelings  and</span><span>  it  was  but  in  his  adult  years  that</span></p> <p><span>  he  learnt  to  write  German.  Pro</span><span>  found  was  his  influence  on  Ger</span><span>  man  philosophy.  (The  fate  of  his</span><span>  children  is  significant;  it  shows</span><span>  how  quickly  by  the  way  of  assi</span><span>  milation  large  and  valuable  parts</span><span>  of  Jewry  have  been  absorbed  by</span><span>  the  German  people:  Two  of  his</span><span>  sons,  baptized,  became  the  found</span><span>  ers’  of  one  of  most  famous  Euro</span><span>  pean  Banks.  His  daughter,  also</span><span>  baptised,  was  renowned  for  her</span><span>  literary  salon  and  played  an  im</span><span>  portant  part  in  the  history  of  Ger</span><span>  man  literature.  His  grandson  Felix</span><span>  Mendelssohn-Bartholdy,  baptised,</span><span>  was  one  of  the  greatest  German</span><span>  composers.  And  many  of  his  des</span><span>  cendents  are  reputed  as  artists</span><span>  and  scientists).  Besides  Mendel</span><span>  ssohn  there  were  many  more  Jew</span><span>  ish  philosophers  as  for  instance</span><span>  Salomon  Maimon,  Otto  Liebmann,</span><span>  Herman  Cohen,  Gustav  ^  Simmel,</span><span>  Gustav  Landauer  etc.  Although,</span><span>  they  were  not  the  great  lonely</span><span>  stars  they  influenced  largely</span><span>  thoughts  and  ideas  in  Germany.</span></p> <p><span>  In  the  discipline  of  Physics,</span><span>  Mathematics  and  Physics  near  to</span><span>  the  province  of  Philosophy,  scores</span><span>  of  Jews  excelled.  The  one  Einstein</span><span>  would  suffice  to  procure  the  Jews</span><span>  a  place  of  honour  in  the  history</span><span>  of  Science.  Only  the  coming  cen</span><span>  turies  can  judge  fully  his  import</span><span>  ance.  But  he  seems  to  be  a  genius</span><span>  the  like  of  whom  mankind  pro</span><span>  duces  only  every  some  centuries  to</span><span>  be  placed  in  line  with  men  like</span><span>  Ptolemy,  Galileo,  Giordano  Bruno</span><span>  and  Newton.  And  there  are  many</span><span>  others  whose  names  can  keep  the</span><span>  field  also  besides  Einstein.  Hertz</span><span>  (theory  .  of  electric  waves),  J.</span><span>  Frank  (theory  of  atoms),  David</span><span>  sohn  (electro  motor),  Marcus</span><span>  (petrol  motor),  Berliner  (micro</span><span>  phone),  Haber  (nitrogen),  Frank</span><span>  (Kali),  Caro  (dyes),  Willstaetter</span><span>  (Chlorophyl),  Bayer,  the  son  of  a</span><span>  Jewish  mother  and  the  founder  of</span><span>  the'  mighty  German  Dye  concern</span><span>  (indigo)  and  practically  thou</span><span>  sands  of  famous  names  more.</span></p> <p><span>  Jews  have  always  been  prepon</span><span>  derant  physicians  and  that  may</span><span>  partly  explain  the  fact  that  there</span><span>  was  nearly  no  inventive  medical</span><span>  achievement  without  Jewish  guid</span></p> <p><span>  ance  or  at  least  Jewish  assistance.</span></p> <p><span>  It  is  almost  impossible  an  under</span><span>  taking  to  enumerate  the  names  of</span><span>  the  countless  medical  pioneers  and</span><span>  only  a  few  ones  may  therefore  be</span><span>  mentioned  who  acquired  wide  pub</span><span>  lic  fame. And  even  men  who  achieved</span><span>  the  most  practical  successes  like</span><span>  Haber  who  saved  Germany  from</span><span>  losing  the  world  war  in  its  first</span><span>  year,  or  Ehrlich  who  released  the</span><span>  world  from  one  of  its  deadliest</span><span>  plagues,  were  not  popular  because</span><span>  the  simple-minded  maxi,  could  not</span><span>  conceive  their  complicated  con</span><span>  structive  work.</span></p> <p><span>  Shall  we  wonder  about  it?  No,</span><span>  for  not  even  the  Jewish  ^masses</span><span>  knew  it.  Even  now  after  the  last</span><span>  years  of  Jewish  persecution  and</span><span>  reawakening  of  Jewish  conscious</span><span>  ness  a  French  Jew  with  whom  I</span><span>  conversed  recently  had  no  idea</span><span>  that  Bergson  and  Andre  Maurois</span></p> <p><span>  were  Jews  and  Anatole  France</span><span>  half  of  Jewish  parentage.</span></p> <p><span>  Must  we  therefore  assume  that</span><span>  all  the  cultural  work  done  by</span><span>  Jews  has  been  in  vain?  Certainly</span><span>  not. Books</span><span>  which  have  been  printed  can  be</span><span>  burnt  but  their  contents  cannot  be</span><span>  burned. Banks. His  grandson  Felix</span><span>  Mendelssohn-Bartholdy,  baptised,</span><span>  was  one  of  the  greatest  German</span><span>  composers.  And  many  of  his  des</span><span>  cendents  :  are  •  reputed  as  artists</span></p> <p><span>  and,  scientistsi).  isesicies  ivienciei</span><span>  ssohn  there  were  many  more  Jew</span><span>  ish  philosophers  as  for  instance</span><span>  Salomon  Maimon,  Otto  Liebmann,</span><span>  Herman  Cohen,  Gustav  Simmel,</span><span>  Gustav  Landauer  etc.  Although,</span><span>  they  were  not  the  great  lonely</span><span>  stars  they  influenced  largely</span><span>  thoughts  and  ideas  in  Germany.</span></p> <p><span>  In  the  discipline  of  Physics,</span><span>  Mathematics  and  Physics  near  to</span><span>  the  province  of  Philosophy,  scores</span><span>  of  Jews  excelled.  The  one  Einstein</span><span>  would  suffice  to  procure  the  Jews</span><span>  a  place  of  honour  in  the  history</span><span>  of  Science.  Only  the  coming  cen</span><span>  turies  can  judge  fully  his  import</span><span>  ance.  But  he  seems  to  be  a  genius</span><span>  the  like  of  whom  mankind  pro</span><span>  duces  only  every  some  centuries  to</span><span>  be  placed  in  line  with  men  like</span><span>  Ptolemy,  Galileo,  Giordano  Bruno</span><span>  and  Newton.  And  there  are  many</span><span>  others  whose  names  can  keep  the</span><span>  field  also  besides  Einstein.  Hertz</span><span>  (theory  of  electric  waves),  J.</span><span>  Frank  (theory  of  atoms),  David</span><span>  sohn  (electro  motor),  Marcus</span><span>  (petrol  motor),  Berliner  (micro</span><span>  phone),  Haber  (nitrogen),'  Frank</span><span>  (Kali),  Caro  (dyes),  Willstaetter</span><span>  (Chlorophyl),  Bayer,  the  son  of  a</span><span>  Jewish  mother  and  the  founder  of</span><span>  the  mighty  German  Dye  concern</span><span>  (indigo)  and  practically  thou</span></p> <p><span>  sands  of  famous  names  more.</span></p> <p><span>  Jews  have  always  been  prepon</span><span>  derant  physicians  and  that  may</span><span>  partly  explain  the  fact  that  there</span><span>  was  nearly  no  inventive  medical</span><span>  achievement  without  Jewish  guid</span><span>  ance  or  at  least  Jewish  assistance.</span><span>  It  is  almost  impossible  an  under</span><span>  taking  to  enumerate  the  names  of</span><span>  the  countless  medical  pioneers  and</span><span>  only  a  few  ones  may  therefore  be</span><span>  mentioned  who  acquired  wide  pub</span><span>  lic  fame.  So  Meyerhof  (transfor</span><span>  mation  of  energy),  Zunz  (physio</span><span>  logy),  Ehrlich  (Salvarsan),  Was</span><span>  sermann  and  Morgenroth  (both</span><span>  diagnosis  of  syphilis,  Freud</span><span>  (psychoanalysis),  Adler  (indivi</span><span>  dual  psychology),  Minkowsky</span><span>  (diabetes),  Boas  (stomach  di</span><span>  seases)  ,  Zondeck  (internal  di</span><span>  seases),  Aschheim  (pregnancy</span><span>  diagnosis)  etc.</span></p> <p><span>  But  how  much  soever.  all  these</span><span>  contributions  have  added  to  the</span><span>  famous  reputation  of  German  cul</span><span>  ture  the  public  in  general  knew</span><span>  and  appreciated  better  the  Jews,</span><span>  who  worked  in  the  sphere  of  the</span><span>  arts.</span></p> <p><span>  In  the  first  line  it  was  the  Jew</span><span>  ish  musicians  who,  even  in  the</span><span>  land  of  music  proper,  attracted</span><span>  the  eyes  or  rather  the  ears  of</span><span>  their  contemporaries.  There  are</span><span>  the  composers  Mendelssohn,  Mey</span><span>  erbeer,  dffenbach,  Moscheles,  Ru</span></p> <p><span>  binstein,  Joachim,  Mahler,  Schoen</span><span>  berg,  Korngold,  there  are  the  con</span><span>  ducted  Walter,  Klemperer,  Klei</span><span>  ber,  there  are  the  countless  prac</span><span>  titioning  musicians  of  world-wide</span><span>  fame  like  Schnabel,  Horowitz,  Ser</span><span>  kin,  Hubermarin,  Kreisler,  Morini,</span><span>  Tauber  arid  scores  of  theni  more.</span></p> <p><span>  In  the-  art  of  painting  it  ’  was</span><span>  Lieberinarin,  Israels,  Lesser  Ury,</span><span>  Chagall;  Feinger,,  Marees  (a  ,half</span><span>  Jew)  etc.  who  helped  to  develop</span><span>  German  artistic  reputation.  That</span><span>  seems  to  be  indeed  a  very  surpris</span><span>  ing  fact.  For-since  the  Jewa,  -pre</span><span>  vented  by  religious  prohibitions,</span><span>  had  riever  excelled  iri  the  field  ;of</span><span>  painting  it  was  all  the  mrir^.ihir.,</span><span>  acuious  that  they  .could  hold  their</span><span>  own  without  ’any  existing1  artistic</span><span>  tradition.  **  /■V</span></p> <p><span>  v  (Continued  6n  page  ‘t</span></p> <p><span>  GERMAN  JEWS  AND  GERMAN  CULTURE</span></p> <p><span>  (Continued  from  Front  page)</span></p> <p><span>  Always  have  the  Jews  been  bear</span><span>  ers  of  a  deep  inner  conscience  and</span><span>  masters  of  the  word.  Since  the</span><span>  days  of  the  Prophets  they  have</span><span>  been  the  proclaimed  and  propa</span><span>  gators  of  teachings,  doctrines  and</span><span>  convictions.  That  may  be  the  ex</span><span>  planation  of  the  immense  part</span><span>  played  by  Jews  in  the  German</span><span>  literature.  The  way  leading  from</span><span>  Heinrich  Heine  to  Stephan  Zweig</span><span>  is  short  in  time  but  overcrowded</span><span>  by  writing,  composing,  teaching</span><span>  and  admonishing  Jews:  Boerne</span><span>  and  Weininger,  Wassermann  and</span><span>  Werfel,  Kaffka  and  Heimann,</span><span>  Schnitzler  and  Hofmannsthal,  Bu</span><span>  ber  and  Mombert,  Toller  and</span><span>  Weiss,  Brod  and  Arnold  Zweig,</span><span>  Doeblin  and  Beer-Hoffmann  are</span></p> <p><span>  only  a  few  names  casually  picked</span><span>  out  of  the  innumerable  spiritual</span><span>  Jews  who  have  influenced  the</span></p> <p><span>  thoughts  and  feelings  of  the  Ger</span><span>  man  people.</span></p> <p><span>  It  is  practically  impossible  even</span><span>  if  the  limited  space  would  not</span><span>  prohibit  it—to  mention  every  do</span><span>  main  where  the  Jews  had  a  share</span><span>  in  the  shaping  of  German  culture.</span><span>  Industry  and  economics:,  sociology</span><span>  and  agriculture,  film  and  theatre</span><span>  dance  and  architecture,  journal</span><span>  istics  and  playwriting,  charity  and</span><span>  art-donations  were  but  a  few  ones</span></p> <p><span>  of  the  vast  provinces  of  Jewish</span></p> <p><span>  collaboration.</span></p> <p><span>  How  is  it  possible  that  in  spite</span><span>  of  all  this  cultural  work  done  by</span><span>  Jews  the  terrible  outbursts  of</span><span>  cruelty  against  the  German  Jews</span><span>  could  happen  ?  Probably  because</span><span>  the  people  did  not  know  how  great</span><span>  the  share  of  the  Jews  in  all  those</span><span>  cultural  achievements  had  been.</span></p> <p><span>  For  however  magnificent  the</span><span>  Jewish  accomplishments  were</span><span>  they  did  not  reach  the  bulk  of  the</span><span>  people.  The  ideas  of  the  Jewish</span><span>  writers'  were  too  elaborate,  too</span><span>  high-brow,  to  be  understood  by</span><span>  the  masses.  They  became  the  spi</span><span>  ritual  food  of  the  intelligentsia,</span><span>  with  the  exception  of  Heine  whose</span><span>  poems  are  recited,  and  sung  by  the</span><span>  whole  of  Germany,  but  mostly</span><span>  without  any  knowledge  who  wrote</span><span>  those  deeply  touching  songs.  And</span><span>  again  the  composers  although</span><span>  some  of  them  being  pacemakers  of</span><span>  new  musical  ways  did  not  pene</span><span>  trate  into  the  people’s  hearts,  be</span></p> <p><span>  side  Mendelssohn  whose  songs</span><span>  went  straight  to  the  people’s  feel</span><span>  ings.  And  even  men  who  achieved</span><span>  the  most  practical  successes  like</span><span>  Haber  who  saved  Germany  from</span></p> <p><span>  losing  the  world  war  in  its  first  I</span><span>  year,  or  Ehrlich  who  released  the</span><span>  world  from  one  of  its  deadliest</span><span>  plagues,  were  not  popular  because</span><span>  the  simple-minded  man  could  not</span><span>  conceive  their  complicated  con</span></p> <p><span>  structive  work.</span></p> <p><span>  Shall  we  wonder  about  it?  No,</span><span>  for  not  even  the  Jewish  masses</span><span>  knew  it.  Even  now  after  the  last</span><span>  years  of  Jewish  persecution  and</span><span>  reawakening  of  Jewish  conscious</span><span>  ness  a  French  Jew  with  whom  I</span><span>  conversed  recently  had  no  idea</span><span>  that  Bergson  and  Andre  Maurois</span><span>  were  Jews  and  Anatole  France</span><span>  half  of  Jewish  parentage.</span></p> <p><span>  Must  we  therefore  assume  that</span><span>  all  the  cultural  work  done  by</span><span>  Jews  has  been  in  vain?  Certainly</span><span>  not.  Material  values  can  be  lost,</span><span>  money,  houses,  diamonds  can  .be</span><span>  destroyed  but  spiritual  values  that</span><span>  have  been  produced  remain.  Books</span><span>  which  have  been  printed  can  be</span><span>  burnt  but  their  contents  cannot  be</span></p> <p><span>  |  burned.  Heads  can  be  cut  off  but</span></p> <p><span>  thoughts  which  they  had  spoken</span><span>  out,  the  songs  which  have  been</span><span>  sung,  cannot  been  drowned,  smoth</span><span>  ered,  hanged.  The  cultural  achive</span><span>  ments  the  Jews  have  produced  in.</span><span>  Germany  will  be  remain  alive  and</span><span>  there  will  be  again  a  time  of</span><span>  peace  when  all  that  Einstein  and</span><span>  Freud,  Mendelssohn  and  Heine</span><span>  have  thought,  said,  written  and</span><span>  sung,  will  again  be  heard,  read</span><span>  and  sung,  and  when  again  will  be</span><span>  thought  of  with  deep  and  kind</span><span>  feelings  of  thankfulness  those  men</span><span>  who  have  served  the  progress  of</span><span>  man  with  the  best  of  their  lives.</span></p> <p><span>  But  something  more  will  come</span><span>  out  again  of  the  marvellous  riches</span><span>  of  Jewish  spirit.  Those  riches</span><span>  which  have  survived  the  centuries</span><span>  of  prosecution  will  remain  in  the</span><span>  same  way  alive  in  spite  of  the  new</span><span>  pains  that  have  come  down  over</span><span>  Jewry.  The  men  who  have  pro</span><span>  duced  all  those  miracles  of  their</span><span>  spirits  have  had  to  go  again  on</span><span>  their  new  travels  throughout  the</span><span>  world.  They  had  to  leave  behind</span><span>  them  their  fortunes,  their  money,</span><span>  even  their  clothes.  But  they  have</span><span>  taken  along  with  themselves  their</span><span>  unbroken  spirit.  That  spirit  wher</span><span>  ever  the  Jews  will  be  driven  out</span><span>  and  wherever  they  will  settle</span><span>  afresh  will  fructify  again  m  inkind</span><span>  for  the  benefit  of  the  human  race</span><span>  and  to  the  honour  of  the  Jewish</span></p> <p><span>  name.</span></p> "

When  they  migrated  to  Poland</span><span>  and  eastwards  they  took  their  language  with  them,  and</span><span>  added  to  it.  It  was  known  as  Judisch  Deutch  or  Jewish</span><span>  German,  and  later  as  Yiddish.</span></p> <p><span>  I  nave  many  times  m  my  life  wished  l  could  speak</span><span>  Yiddish.  I  understand  very  little,  but  have  had  to  pretend  at</span><span>  times  that  I  understand  a  lot.  On  the  other  hand,  1  know</span><span>  people  who  understand  quite  a  lot  and  pretend  they  under</span><span>  stand  only  a  little.</span></p> <p><span>  In  this  roundabout  way  I  am  gradually  getting  to  the</span><span>  point  I  wanted  to  make.
