                        "articleText": "<p><span>  A  GERMAN</span><span>  NOTEBOOK</span></p> <p><span>  By  WILLIAM  FRANKEL</span></p> <p><span>  (The  first  of  too  articles).</span></p> <p><span>  if  lie  possesses  any  sensitivity  at  all,  a</span><span>  Jew  visiting  Germany  for  the  first  time</span><span>  must  undergo  an  intensely  emotional  ex</span><span>  perience.</span></p> <p><span>  He  looks  coldly  and  almost  apprehensively  at</span><span>  the  German  men  and  women  in  the  street:  were</span><span>  they  among  the  persecutors?  Of  the  Germans  with</span><span>  whom  he  comes  into  closer  contact,  the  Jew  won</span><span>  ders:  is  the  hand  I  am  shaking  the  hand  of  one</span><span>  of  the  butchers?</span></p> <p><span>  Naturally,  the  intensity  of  this  reaction  is</span><span>  blunted  after  a  while,  but  there  remains  a  residue</span><span>  very  near  the  surface  that  colours  every  moment</span><span>  of  the  stay  in  Germany.</span></p> <p><span>  So.  of  course,  the  relation</span><span>  ship  between  German  and</span><span>  Jew  Is  bound  to  be  an  ab</span><span>  normal  one.  Nearly  all  the</span><span>  Germans  I  met  during  my</span><span>  visit  felt  it  necessary  to</span><span>  make  some  expression  —  from</span><span>  the  eloquent  to  the  hesitant</span><span>  —  of  their  sense  of  guilt  for</span><span>  the  Nazi  past,  and  to  add</span><span>  some  words  explaining  their</span><span>  own  innocence.  Many  of  them</span><span>  were,  undoubtedly,  both  truth,</span><span>  ful  and  sincere,  but  yet  I  felt</span><span>  that  to  some  extent  even  they</span><span>  resented  being  reminded  of</span><span>  something  they  would  much</span><span>  rather  forget.</span></p> <p><span>  For  my  part,  at  each  of</span><span>  these  encounters  I  could  not</span><span>  avoid  a  feeling  of  some  dis</span><span>  comfort  at  being  the  cause</span><span>  of  shame  and  embarrassment</span><span>  on  the  part  of  these  apparent,</span><span>  ly  decent  Germans.  Yet  I</span><span>  know  that  I  would  have  taken</span><span>  amiss  the  absence  of  their</span><span>  expression  of  guilt  and  of</span><span>  explanation.  I  cannot  but  feel</span><span>  that  this  reaction  of  German</span><span>  and  Jew  will  continue  through,</span><span>  out  the  lives  of  the  genera</span><span>  tion  who  was  involved.</span></p> <p><span>  NO  TRADITION</span></p> <p><span>  The  present  abnormality  in</span><span>  the  relationships  between</span><span>  Germans  and  Jews  was,</span><span>  therefore,  responsible  for  a</span><span>  certain  tension  during  my</span><span>  visit  But  Germany  (like  Is</span><span>  rael).  is  a  country  in  which</span><span>  a  great  deal  is  going  on,  and</span><span>  the  interest  in  observing  this</span><span>  regeneration  overlays  though</span><span>  it  never  entirely  displaces,  the</span><span>  I  sense  of  discomfort</span></p> <p><span>  Certainly,  the  Wirtschafts</span><span>  wunder  —  the  miracle  of</span><span>  German  economic  recovery’—■</span><span>  is  all  nervading.  Shops  are</span><span>  not  only  full  of  expensive</span><span>  merchandise,  they  are  busily</span><span>  selling  it</span></p> <p><span>  Innumerable  and  varied</span><span>  eating  establishments  dispense</span><span>  gargantuan  servings  of  whole</span><span>  some  food  to  portly  diners.</span><span>  New  construction,  skyscrapers,</span><span>  houses,  public  buildings,  trans</span><span>  form  derelict  bombed  sites.</span><span>  The  men  and  women  in  the</span><span>  street  are  patently  well-fed</span><span>  and  well-clothed.</span></p> <p><span>  TENSION</span></p> <p><span>  This  abundant  prosperity</span><span>  has  obvious  implications  for</span><span>  the  prospect  for  democracy</span><span>  in  Germany.  So  long  as  it</span><span>  lasts,  the  German  man-in-the</span><span>  street  will  be  content  with</span><span>  the  Government  which  pro</span><span>  vides  these  benefits.</span></p> <p><span>  But  Germany  has  no  tra</span><span>  dition  of  democracy.  Its</span><span>  citizens  have  been  condition</span><span>  ed  to  respond  to  authoritar</span><span>  ian  leadership.</span></p> <p><span>  One  of  the  many  everyday</span><span>  examples,  is  the  exaggerated</span><span>  difference  still  accorded  to</span><span>  uniforms  and  titles.  I  have</span><span>  no  doubt  that  the'  present</span><span>  administration  has  a  sincere</span><span>  desire  to  establish  a  soundly</span><span>  based  democratic  system  in;</span><span>  Germany  and  today’s  pros</span><span>  perity  is  helping  to  achieve</span></p> <p><span>  it.</span></p> <p><span>  But  should  there  be  a</span><span>  serious  economic  or  political</span><span>  crisis,  a  new  type  of  total</span><span>  litarianlsm  might  very  well</span><span>  emerge.  As  a  leading  trade</span><span>  unionist  put  •  it  to  me.  “I</span><span>  would  not  put  my  hand  in</span><span>  the  fire  for  German  democ</span><span>  racy.”</span></p> <p><span>  It  is  a  pity  that  many  who</span><span>  understand  the  fragility  of</span><span>  German  democracy  try  to:</span></p> <p><span>  protect  it  by  over-emphasis</span><span>  upon  the  fight  against  former</span><span>  Nazis.  Undoubtedly  their  re</span><span>  tention  in  positions  of  ap</span><span>  parent  influence  exercises  a</span><span>  harmful  effect  on  public</span><span>  opinion.-A  new  totalitarian</span><span>  ism,  however,  can  be  brought</span><span>  about  by  a  wave  of  emotion</span><span>  alism  and  anti-rationalism</span><span>  that  may  flare  up  In  a  crisis.</span><span>  The  new  right  vsdng  radical</span><span>  parties  are  the  ones  to  watch.</span><span>  By  diverting  energies  to  the</span><span>  proscription  of  old  Nazis</span><span>  (who  will  not  be  the  new</span><span>  Nazis)  the  real  sources  of  the</span><span>  future  danger  may  be</span><span>  ignored.</span></p> <p><span>  EDUCATION</span></p> <p><span>  What,  therefore,  can  be</span><span>  done  so  that  a  new  Germany</span><span>  does  not  ever  again  become</span><span>  militaristic,  nationalistic  and</span><span>  racist?  The  education  of  the</span><span>  rising  generation  in  democ</span><span>  ratic  ways  and  to  a  realisa</span><span>  tion  of  the  crimes  of  Nazism</span><span>  is  not  a  complete  Insurance</span><span>  against  another  recession  into</span><span>  savagery  (nothing  is),  but  it</span><span>  is  an  aspect  than  can  only  be</span><span>  neglected  at  the  nation’s  peril.</span></p> <p><span>  I  believed  the  German</span><span>  educationists  who  told  me</span><span>  what  they  were  trying  to  do,</span><span>  for  they  were  enlightened  and</span><span>  Intelligent  people.  Ideal  cur</span><span>  ricula  are  drawn  up  but  they</span><span>  might  never  be  applied  in</span><span>  practice  because  of  opposi</span><span>  tion  by  parents  and  teachers</span><span>  who,  naturally,  want  to  avoid</span><span>  the  discovery  of  their  own</span><span>  guilt  to  the  children.</span></p> <p><span>  As  the  opinions  I  heard</span><span>  of  the  effectiveness  of  the</span><span>  schools  programme  were  so</span><span>  varied,  I  decided  to  make  my,</span><span>  own  test</span></p> <p><span>  Without  anyone  else  being</span><span>  present.  I  met  the  top  classes</span><span>  of  two  schools.  One  was  a</span><span>  grammar  school  and  the</span><span>  average  age  of  the  boys  was</span><span>  17.  They  all  had  a  fairly</span><span>  good  knowledge  of  the  origins</span><span>  and  rise  of  Hitlerism.  They</span><span>  knew  something  about  the</span><span>  causes  of  the  war  and  of</span><span>  Hitler’s  invasion  of  neutral</span><span>  countries  (though  they  thought</span><span>  it  was  justified  in  a  “total</span><span>  war”).  And  they  knew  about</span><span>  the  persecution  of  the  Jews,</span><span>  (the  reason  —  they  were  ter</span><span>  i  ribly  rich  and  Hitler  wanted</span></p> <p><span>  their  money  to  start  a  war),</span><span>  though  not  of  other  minor</span><span>  ities.</span></p> <p><span>  NAZIS</span></p> <p><span>  Most  of  their  parents  had</span><span>  been  Nazis,  but  had  explained</span><span>  their  membership  to  their</span><span>  children  as  having  been  due</span><span>  to  economic  reasons  such  as</span><span>  employment  and  getting  school</span><span>  places.</span></p> <p><span>  In  the  second  school,  which</span><span>  approximates  more  to  our</span><span>  secondary  modern,  I  spoke  to</span><span>  the  top  class  of  boys  who</span><span>  were  about  15  year  old.  They</span><span>  knew  very  little  about  Hitler</span><span>  and  the  war  but  they  all</span><span>  knew  the  figure  of  six  mil</span><span>  lion  Jews  who  had  been</span><span>  killed.  I  gathered,  however,</span><span>  that  they  had  learned  this</span><span>  from  television  and  not  from</span><span>  school.</span></p> <p><span>  The  Cologne  swastika</span><span>  smearing  of  December,  1959,</span><span>  came  as  a  profound  shock  to</span><span>  liberal  elements  in  Germany</span><span>  and  the  repercussions  are  by</span></p> <p><span>  no  means  ended.</span></p> <p><span>  One  was  a  recognition  that</span><span>  the  educational  programme</span><span>  had  been  allowed  to  drift</span></p> <p><span>  almost  into  stagnation  Educ</span><span>  ation  is  a  responsibility  of  the</span><span>  Laender  not  the  Federal</span><span>  Government  “Controversial”</span><span>  issues,  like  the  teaching  of</span><span>  Germany’s  past,  are  suscept</span><span>  ible  to  local  pressure,  and</span><span>  that  Is  one  of  the  reasons  why</span><span>  more  has  not  been  done.  Ef</span><span>  forts  have  been  unsuccessful</span><span>  to  establish  a  Federal  Minis</span><span>  try  of  Education  which  might</span><span>  be  expected  to  tackle  the  sub</span><span>  ject  with  greater  vigour.                         "articleText": "<p><span>  GERMAN  COMPENSATION</span></p> <p><span>  ADOPTION</span></p> <p><span>  Prepared  for  “Jewish  News  by  Dr.  0.  Freyer,</span></p> <p><span>  Sydney.</span></p> <p><span>  ^HE  final  Compensation  Law  (Schlussentschae</span></p> <p><span>  digungsgesetz)  is  likely  to  be  enacted  at  the</span><span>  end  of  June,  and  probably  comes  into  operation  at</span><span>  the  beginning  of  July.</span></p> <p><span>  After  deliberation  for  twc</span><span>  years,  the  Compensation  Law</span><span>  Committee  of  the  German</span><span>  Parliament  submitted  a  ma</span><span>  jority  report  to  the  Lower</span><span>  House  on  May  13  and  the</span><span>  second  and  third  readings  of</span><span>  the  respective  draft  legisla</span><span>  tion  was  expected  to  take</span><span>  place  soon  after.</span></p> <p><span>  The  Report,  based  on  the</span><span>  draft  previously  submitted  by</span></p> <p><span>  the  German  Government  in</span><span>  November,  1903,  if  enacted</span><span>  will  result  in  wide-spread</span><span>  changes  in  the  structure  of</span><span>  the  compensation  legislation,  i</span></p> <p><span>  It  is  expected  that  the  law</span><span>  will  be  adopted  on  the  basis</span><span>  of  this  Report,  with  minor</span><span>  alterations.</span></p> <p><span>  IRON  CURTAIN</span></p> <p><span>  The  main  features  of  the</span><span>  Report  include_</span></p> <p><span>  (a)  Claims  of  persecutees</span><span>  who  left  the  Iron  Curtain</span><span>  countries  after  October  1,</span><span>  1953  .  (so  called'  “post  ‘53</span><span>  cases”)_</span></p> <p><span>  A  fund  will  be  created</span><span>  amounting  to  DM  700,000,000</span><span>  from  which  the  claims  of</span><span>  this  group  will  be  satisfied.</span></p> <p><span>  Persecutees  entitled  to  com</span><span>  pensation  are  those  who  were</span><span>  deprived  of  their  liberty  for</span><span>  a  period  not  less  than  G</span><span>  months  (the  mere  wearing</span></p> <p><span>  of  a  “David  Star”  or  the  i</span><span>  living  under  legality  is  not</span><span>  sufficient)  or  those  who  are</span><span>  a.t  the  present  time  at  least</span><span>  80%  incapacitated  or  widows</span><span>  who  lost  their  husbands  as</span><span>  a  result  of  persecution  and</span><span>  who  did  not  re-marry.</span></p> <p><span>  The  basic  compensation  will</span><span>  amount  to  DM  2,000.  How</span><span>  ever,  persons  who  are  over</span><span>  the  age  of  G5  years  are  en</span><span>  titled  to  DM  2,500  and  widows</span><span>  who  lost  their  husbands  as</span><span>  n  result  of  persecution</span><span>  DM  3,000.  Widow’s  who  were</span><span>  deprived  of  their  liberty  for</span><span>  not  less  thdn  1  year  are</span><span>  entitled  to  DM  5,000.</span></p> <p><span>  This  basic  compensation</span><span>  will  be  paid  immediately  af</span><span>  ter  the  case  of  each  ap</span><span>  plicant  has  been  proved.</span></p> <p><span>  The  additional  compensa</span><span>  tion  will  be  determined  on</span><span>  the  basig  of  funds  remaining</span><span>  after  satisfying  all  applicants</span><span>  in  respect  of  their  basic  com</span><span>  pensation  and  in  determining</span><span>  this  additional  compensation</span><span>  tlie  following  graduations  will</span><span>  apply:—</span></p> <p><span>  (x)  Persecutees  who  were</span><span>  deprived  of  their  liberty  for</span><span>  1  or  2  years  will  receive  a</span><span>  single  fixed  amount</span></p> <p><span>  (xx)  Persecutees  who  were</span><span>  deprived  of  their  liberty  for</span><span>  2  to-  3  years  will  receive</span><span>  double  the  fixed  amount.</span></p> <p><span>  (xxx)  Persecutees  who</span><span>  where  deprived  of  their  liber</span></p> <p><span>  >  ty  for  3  to  4  years  will  re</span><span>  ,•  ceive  treble  the  fixed  amount.</span><span>  i  (xxxx)  Persecutees  who</span><span>  .  were  deprived  of  their  liber</span><span>  .  ty  for  more  than  4  years  will</span></p> <p><span>  receive  four  times  the  fixed</span><span>  :  amount.</span></p> <p><span>  (xxxxx)  Widows  will  re</span><span>  ’  ceive  5  times  the  fixed</span><span>  !  amount.</span></p> <p><span>  The  maximum  additional</span><span>  compensation  will  be  five</span><span>  times  the  fixed  amount.</span></p> <p><span>  OTHER  GROUNDS</span></p> <p><span>  There  are  no  special  pro</span><span>  visions  for  compensation  in</span><span>  respect  of  “loss  of  health”,</span><span>  however,  the  Government  is</span><span>  entitled  to  divert  the  balance</span><span>  remaining  of  the  afore</span><span>  mentioned  funds  in  order  to</span><span>  satisfy  the  claims  of  perse</span><span>  cutees  who  suffered  exces</span><span>  sive  loss  of  health.</span></p> <p><span>  (b)  Special  Drovision  for</span><span>  persecutees  being  non-Ger</span><span>  man  Nationals  who  were</span><span>  persecuted  on  grounds  other</span><span>  than'  racial  or  religious  (Po</span><span>  les,  Czech,  Russians,  Ukrain</span><span>  ians  etc.).</span></p> <p><span>  Compensation  ■  for  loss  of</span><span>  health  is  provided  for  per</span><span>  sons  who  held  the  status  of</span><span>  Political  Refugees  on  Octo</span><span>  ber  1,  1953.  This  is  provided</span><span>  in  one  or  the  other  of  the</span><span>  following  cases:—</span></p> <p><span>  (i)  Persons  who  suffer-1</span><span>  ed  injuries  as  a  result  of</span><span>  being  ill-treated  through  the</span><span>  ignoring  of  human  rights  and</span><span>  therefore  at  the  present  time</span><span>  are  permanently  incapacitated</span></p> <p><span>  to  the  extent  of  not  less</span><span>  than  25%. provisions  for</span><span>  “loss  of  health”  in  respect  of</span><span>  concentration  camp  in-mates.</span></p> <p><span>  Persons  who  were  interned</span><span>  iin  a  concentration author</span><span>  ised  to  determine  by  way  of</span></p> <p><span>  decree  what  camps  are  to</span><span>  be  regarded  as  concentration</span><span>  camps,  having  in  mind  that</span><span>  camps  under  supervision  of</span><span>  the  S.C.:  will  not  be  the  only</span><span>  ones  covered  by  same.</span></p> <p><span>  (e)  Opening  of  “Loss  of</span><span>  Health”  claims  which  such</span><span>  claims  were  repudiated.</span></p> <p><span>  If  a  case  was  repudiated</span><span>  only  on  medical  grounds  it</span><span>  may                         "articleText": "<p><span>  THIS  GERMAN</span><span>  THOROUGHNESS</span></p> <p><span>  By  a  cunning  legal  tricK,  west  German  law</span><span>  makers  appear  1o  have  sneaked  through  the  West</span><span>  German  parliament  a  law  amendment  which,</span><span>  unless  rescinded,  may  release  from  prosecution</span><span>  most  Nazi  criminals  still  unpunished.</span></p> <p><span>  The  loophole  provision  is  so  complicated  that</span><span>  it  evaded  the  vigilance  of  those  members  of  the</span><span>  West  German  parliament  who  are  genuinely  in</span><span>  favour  of  continuing  prosecution  of  Nazis  involved</span><span>  in  mass  murder;  but  the'Federal  Supreme  Court,</span><span>  in  a  test  case  decided  on  May  21st,  ruled  that  the</span><span>  new  legal  amendment  is  valid  law.</span></p> <p><span>  Stripped  of  the  legal  verbiage  under  the  Ger</span><span>  man  Penal  Code,  an  accessory  to  a  crime  is</span><span>  equally  legally  responsible  with  the  main  culprit,</span><span>  and  thus  a  person  accessory  to  murder  can  be</span><span>  dealt;  with  exactly  as  the  murderer  himself.</span></p> <p><span>  In  September  last  year,  an  apparently  harm</span></p> <p><span>  less  amendment  to  the  Penal  Code  was  sneaked</span><span>  through  parliament;  most  of  the  clauses  of  the</span><span>  amendment  were  in  fact  perfectly  straightforward</span><span>  minor  emendations  dealing  with  cases  of  unclear</span><span>  wording  and  similar  deficiencies.</span></p> <p><span>  One  clause;  however,  which  was  represented</span><span>  to  parliament  as  a  method  of  relieving  minor</span><span>  offenders—traffic  offenders,  for  Instance—of  over</span><span>  severe  penalties,  vitally  amended  Paragraph  50</span></p> <p><span>  of  the  Penal  Code.</span></p> <p><span>  Under  the  old  version  of  this  paragraph,</span><span>  accessories  were  equally  responsible  wilh  the</span><span>  main  culprit;  in  the  amended  version,  accessories</span><span>  were  allotted  a  lesser  share  of  legal  responsibility</span><span>  unless  it  could  be  shown  that  they  were  acting</span><span>  \"from  base  motives  or  with  malice  aforethought\".</span></p> <p><span>  It  is  today  clear  that  this  clause  was  inserted</span><span>  by  pro-Nazi  legal  draftsmen,  who  wished  to</span><span>  create  a  loophole  for  Nazi  offenders;  but  the</span><span>  catch  was  not  spotted  by  legislators,  and  the</span><span>  .amendment  passed  parliament  without  challenge.</span></p> "

from</span><span>  their  responsibility  for  the  maintenance</span><span>  of  peace,  from  their  endeavour  to  make</span><span>  a  contribution  to  detente  and  security  in</span><span> non-discrimination.\"</span><span>  Article  three  stipulates  that  in  ac</span><span>  cordance  with  the  United  Nations  Char</span><span>  ter  the  GDR  and  the  FRG  \"shall  settle</span><span>  their  disputes  only  by  peaceful  means</span></p> <p><span>  and  refrain  from  the  threat  or  use  of</span><span>  force.\"</span><span>  \"They  affirm  the two  states. Badger,  Vice-Chancellor,  Univer</span><span>  sity  of  Adelaide  and  a  member  of  the</span><span>  Adelaide  Club;  Ian  Hay  ward,  Joint</span><span>  Managing-Director  of  John  Martin  &</span><span>  Co.  Ltd.,  Director  of  South  Australian</span><span>  Insurance  Holdings  Ltd.,  and  also  a</span><span>  member  of  the  Adelaide  Club;  J.  R.  Dri-</span><span>  dan,  Chairman  of  the  Electricity  Trust</span><span>  of  South  Australia;  John  Rob  bins,-  a  lec</span><span>  turer  in  Politics,  University  of  Adelaide;</span><span>  and  Jim  Shannon,  anti-communist  sec</span><span>  retary,  S.A.  Trades  &  Labor  Council.</span><span>  Machinery  for  worker  participation  in</span><span>  management  has  been  introduced  by</span><span>  government  legislation  in  West  Germany</span><span>  on  a  wider  scale  than  any  other  ad</span><span>  vanced  capitalist  country.  With  Chris</span><span>  tian  Democratic  Union  and  Social  De</span><span>  mocratic  Party  support  the  Codetermina-</span><span>  tion  Law  was  passed  in  1951,  under</span><span>  which  the  practice  was  instituted  in  the</span><span>  coal  and  steel  industries.  Further  legis</span><span>  lation  in  the  following  year  gave  legal</span><span>  status  to  worker  participation  in  man</span><span>  agement  in  all  private  and  public  com</span><span>  panies.</span><span>  The  ideology  built  around  codetermina-</span><span>  tion,  known  as  Mitbestimmung,  was  an</span><span>  attempt  to  narrow  political  and  econo</span><span>  mic  differences  between  management</span><span>  and  worker  to  compel  them  to  collabor</span><span>  ate  in  the  factory,  thus  opening  the  way</span><span>  to  the  harmonious  social  and  economic</span><span>  reconstruction  of  postwar  West  Ger</span><span>  many.  As  Herbert  J.  Spiro  wrote  in</span><span>  The  Politics  of  German  Codetermination</span><span>  (Harvard  University  Press,  1958):  \"Co-</span><span>  determination  became  a  vast  educational</span><span>  scheme  designed,  over  a  period  of  years,</span><span>  to  raise  the  workers'  level  of  understand</span><span>  ing  and  thereby  to  help  bring  about  so</span><span>  cial  peace  and  thus-  reduce  the  extent</span><span>  of  the  sphere  of  political  conflict,  or  at</span><span>  least  its  violence\",  (p.  8).</span><span>  The  evidence  shows  clearly  that  par</span><span>  ticipation  leads  to  close  identification</span><span>  with  management.  To  quote  from  Adolph</span><span>  Sturmthal's  Workers'  Control  (Harvard</span><span>  University  Press,  1964):  \"But  the  change</span><span>  was  not  automatically  one  to  a  system</span><span>  of  democratic  partnership  but  rather  to</span><span>  joint  paternalism.  The  significant  fact</span><span>  is  that  in  many  cases  the  works'  coun</span><span>  cil  has  joined  in  the  system  and  has  be</span><span>  come  a  partner  in  a  management  team</span><span>  which  administers  the  labor  force  of  the</span><span>  enterprise  with  authority  and  benevol</span><span>  ence.\"  (p.  68).</span><span>  It  is  clear  that  managers  in  Germany</span><span>  regard  worker  participation  in  manage</span><span>  ment  as  a  means  to  reduce  the  influence</span><span>  of  unions  inside  the  factory,  thereby  re</span><span>  ducing  the  ability  of  workers  to  unite</span><span>  in  presenting  demands  to  management.</span><span>  The  famous  labour  lawyer  and  political</span><span>  scientist  Franz  Neumann  wrote  in  Ger</span><span>  many  and  the  Future  of  Europe,  edited</span><span>  by  Hans  J.  Morgenthau  (University  of</span><span>  Chicago  Press,  1952):  \"It  has  become  in</span><span>  creasingly  doubtful  to  me  if  any  program</span><span>  of  codetermination  is  viable  and  desir</span><span>  able,  and  I  have  become  more  and  more</span></p> <p><span>  convinced  that  in  reality  the  program</span><span>  far  from  achieving  anything,  may  actu</span><span>  ally  destroy  the  little  militancy  that  is</span><span>  left  in  the  German  labor  movement.\"  (p.</span><span>  103).</span><span>  Participation  in  management  in  capi</span><span>  talist  countries  is  essentially  an  experi</span><span>  ence.  that  mystifies  the  workers  as  to</span><span>  their  real  position.  Real  power  in  West</span><span>  Germany  has  not  been  placed  in  the</span><span>  hands  of  the  workers.  Management  still</span><span>  take  all  important  policy  decisions;  the</span><span>  factories  are  still  owned  by  the  share</span><span>  holders;  the  workers  are  still  hired  labor.</span><span>  Mitbestimmung  is  a  capitalist  theory  of</span><span>  industrial  democracy,  the  latest  attempt</span><span>  to  abandon  the  notion  of  class  struggle</span><span>  and  to  entice  the  workers  away  from</span><span>  socialism.</span><span>  Understandably,  it  holds  considerable</span><span>  attraction  for  the  technocratic  Premier</span><span>  of  South  Australia  who  informed  the  Na</span><span>  tional  Youth  Council  in  1969  that  \"pri</span><span>  vate  enterprise  is  a  meaningless  phrase\"</span><span>  and  who  asserted  before  the  American</span><span>  Chamber  of  Commerce  in  Australia  in</span><span>  1970  that  the  appropriation  of  private</span><span>  capital  was  a  \"totally  discredited  idea.\"</span></p> "

                        "articleText": "<p><span>  German  Film  Makers</span></p> <p><span>  Two  leading  German  film  makers,</span><span>  Ms  He|ma  Sanders  and  Mr.  Dieter  Hasemann,</span><span>  will  visit  the  campus  \"next  week.</span><span>  Ms  Helma  Sanders  is  a  distinguished  film</span><span>  maker  and  one  ôf  the  group  of  directors</span><span>  of  the  New  German  Cinema  to  achieve</span><span>  international  recognition.  Her  best  known</span><span>  film  to  date  is  Shirin's  Wedding,  a  story</span><span>  about  the  plight  of  a  \"guestworker\"  in</span><span>  Europe,  a  Turkish  woman  who  comes  to</span><span>  live  and  work  in  West  Germany.</span><span>  This  film  has  won  the  Critic's  Prize  at</span><span>  the  Locarno  Film  Festival  1976  and  was</span><span>  successfully  premiered  in  Australia  at  last</span><span>  year's  Sydney  Film  Festival.</span><span>  Brian  Baxter  writes  about  Shirin's</span><span>  Wedding:  \"The  film's  quality  lies  in  its</span><span>  resonances,  not  the  intellectual  arguments</span><span>  (Ms  Sanders)  evoked  in  earlier  movies.</span><span>  Helma  Sanders  has  directed  not  only  a</span><span>  fierce  indictment  of  contemporary  Ger  :</span><span>  many,  but  —  more  importantly  —  a  portrait</span><span>  of  a  woman  at  the  mercy  of  society.</span><span>  \"Few  movies  have  so  sympathetically</span><span>  and  systematically  chartered  the  decline</span><span>  and  fall  of  a  human  being,  nor  as</span><span>  accurately  related  them  to  the  responsible</span><span>  society.\"</span><span>  Helma  Sanders  will  be  on  campus  on</span><span>  Friday,  April  24. <p><span>  (from  the  German  Tribune,  a  weekly  review  of</span><span>  the  German  Press)</span></p> <p><span>  </span></p> <p><span>  Even  if  an  armistice  agreement  is  signed,</span><span>  none  of  the  problems  that  have  made  the</span><span>  Middle  East  a  continually  ticking  time</span><span>  bomb  will  be  solved,  the  two  overwhelming</span><span>  obstacles  to  peace  being  the  problem  of  the</span><span>  homeless  Palestinians  and  the  Arabs’  hurt</span><span>  pride  at  continually  sustaining  defeats  and</span><span>  being  so  unable  to  help  themselves.</span><span>  </span></p> <p><span>  Israel’s  growing</span><span>  reluctance  to  return  the</span><span>  territories  occupied  in  1967</span><span>  in  return  for  Arab</span><span>  recognition  of  the  Jewish</span><span>  state  is  likewise  an  ob-</span><span>  stacle.</span></p> <p><span>  There  can  be  little  doubt</span><span>  that  Israel’s  policy  in</span></p> <p><span>  recent  years  has  been</span><span>  based  on  a  feeling  of  such</span><span>  military  superiority  over</span><span>  the  other  side  that</span><span>  Jerusalem  was  intent  on</span></p> <p><span>  itself  deciding  the  form</span><span>  possible  negotiations  were</span><span>  to  take  and  the  extent  to</span><span>  which  they  were  to  go.</span></p> <p><span>  The  Arab  governments</span><span>  have  not  played  ball,  and</span><span>  even  if  they  and  Israel  had</span><span>  reached  agreement  on</span><span>  negotiations  there  would</span><span>  still  be  the  Palestinians,</span><span>  who  are  operating  in-</span><span>  creasingly  independently  and</span></p> <p><span>  ever  more  intently  on</span><span>  destroying  the  Jewish</span><span>  State.</span></p> <p><span>  The  Palestinians  (and  for</span><span>  long  enough  the  Arab,</span><span>  governments  too)  have</span><span>  invariably  counted  on</span><span>  massive  Soviet  support,</span><span>  much  as  Israel  has  relied</span><span>  on  continuing  aid  from  the</span><span>  United  States.</span></p> <p><span>  In  Cairo  and  Damascus,</span><span>  not  to  mention  other  Arab</span><span>  capitals,  growing  doubts</span></p> <p><span>  have unjustifiable</span><span>  feeling  that  continuation  of</span></p> <p><span>  the  current  situation</span><span>  midway  between  war  and</span><span>  peace  was  probably  most</span><span> Soviet</span><span>  Union  and  unhindered</span><span>  petroleum  supplies  as  it  is</span><span>  in  good  relations  with</span><span>  Israel.</span></p> <p><span>  This  being  the  case, In  n  similar  \"crock\"</span><span>  type  bottle,  it  will  sell  at  the  same</span><span>  price  as  Black  Tower  (about</span><span>  S3.60).</span></p> <p><span>  These  three  are  stereotyped</span><span>  wines  of  fairly  high  quality  which</span><span>  depend  for  their  success  on  the</span><span>  continuity  of  their  style  and  stan</span><span>  dard  from  year  to  year,  country</span><span>  to  country  and  bottle  to  bottle.</span></p> <p><span>  Licbfraumilch  docs  not  comc</span><span>  from  one  German  district.  It  can</span><span>  be  a  blend  but,  whatever  the  case,</span><span>  it  is  a  matter  of  German  Wine</span><span>  Law  that  it  has  its  origin  either</span><span>  in  the  Rhcinhcsscn,  Rhcingau,</span><span>  Nahe  or  Rheinpfalz  districts  ol</span><span>  the  Rhine  Valley.</span></p> <p><span>  The  quality  of  Licbfraumilch</span><span>  can  be  varied  but  in  fact,  what</span><span>  ever  the  brand  name  or  shipper,</span><span>  the  standard,  the  flavour  and  the</span><span>  quality  is  much  the  same  and  it</span><span>  is  extremely  unlikely  that  an  Aus</span><span>  tralian  palate  could  pick  at  a</span></p> <p><span>  -</span></p> <p><span>  A  selection  of  German  whites.</span></p> <p><span>  \"blind\"  tasting  one  brand  from</span></p> <p><span>  another.</span></p> <p><span>  ft  is  immensely  important,</span><span>  therefore,  that  you  shop  around.</span><span>  A  large  number  of  stores  in  the</span><span>  capital  cities  have  Licbfraumilch</span><span>  at  priccs  varying  from  SI.95  to</span><span>  S2.50  a  bottle  which  makes  them</span><span>  more  than  competitive  with  most</span><span>  Australian  whites  in  a  similar</span><span>  pricc  bracket  and  of  a  similar</span><span>  style.</span></p> <p><span>  The  lowest  quality  German</span><span>  whites  —  Tafclwein  —  do  not</span><span>  seem  to  be  imported  into  Aus</span></p> <p><span>  tralia.</span></p> <p><span>  A  qualitatswein  must  come</span><span>  from  a  particular  region,  be  made</span><span>  from  certain  grape  varieties  and</span><span>  have  an  alcoholic  strength  of  8'^</span><span>  per  cent  by  volume.  Under  pres</span><span>  ent-day  German  Wine  Law,  a</span><span>  quality  wine  must  carry  the  name</span><span>  of  the  vineyard,  vineyard  area  or</span></p> <p><span>  district.</span></p> <p><span>  Licbfraumilch  has  a  special</span><span>  ruling.  It  must  be  a  qualitaiswcin</span><span>  which  has  passed  the  test  and  has</span><span>  an  official  examination  number.</span><span>  Most  of  the  other  quality  wines</span></p> <p><span>  arc  district  wines,  that  is  wines</span><span>  which  do  not  come  from  any</span><span>  particular  maker  or  village  but</span><span>  arc  from  anywhere  within  a  dis</span><span>  trict  wfv'ch  imparts  a  similar  taste</span><span>  to  all  its  wines.</span></p> <p><span>  Wc  might  say  that  the  Hunter</span><span>  Valley  is  a  district  in  this  sense.</span><span>  Such  a  district  or  particular  area</span><span>  is  called  a  Bcrcich  and  if  the  label</span><span>  docs  not  bear  the  name  of  the</span><span>  vineyard  locality,  the  word</span><span>  Bercich  must  appear  first  on  the</span><span>  label.  We  might  say,  for  example,</span><span>  that  Pokolbin  is  the  vineyard</span><span>  locality  (or  grosslage)  in  the  dis</span><span>  trict  (or  Bercich)  of  Hunter  Val</span><span>  ley.</span></p> <p><span>  Most  of  the  cheaper  German</span><span>  wines  (apart  from  Licb</span><span>  fraumilch)  imported  into  Aus</span><span>  tralia  are  district  or  Bercich</span><span>  wines.  We  see,  accordingly,  such</span><span>  names  as  Bcrcich  Nierstcin,</span><span>  Bereich  Johannisberg,  Bereich</span><span>  Bcrnkastel  and  so  on. Before  the  new</span><span>  German  Wine  Law,  wine  from</span><span>  the  area  surrounding  the  village</span><span>  of  Nicrstein  in  the  Rhcinhcssen</span></p> <p><span>  region  was  labelled  simply</span></p> <p><span>  \"Niersteiner\".</span></p> <p><span>  Now  it  must  be  called  Bcreich</span><span>  Nicrstein.'</span></p> <p><span>  As  you  can  see,  I  am  not  trying</span><span>  to  teach  you  the  intricacies  of</span><span>  German  Wine  Law  but  merely  to</span><span>  point  out  to  you  that  there  are</span><span>  German  wines  on  the  market</span><span>  which  might  have  queer  sounding</span><span>  titles  but  are  very  good  and  ex</span><span>  tremely  reasonable  in  price.</span></p> <p><span>  Fairly  familiar  names  to  Aus</span></p> <p><span>  tralians  are  Saar-Ruwer  and</span><span>  Bcrnkastel  from  the  Moscl  Val</span></p> <p><span>  ley;  Nicrstein  and  Bingcn  from</span><span>  the  Rhcinhcssen;  Johannisberg</span><span>  from  the  Rhcingau.  Look  for  the</span><span>  word  Bcrcich  before  these  names</span></p> <p><span>  today  and  you  will  know  that  the</span></p> <p><span>  label  describes  a  wine  from</span><span>  grapes  grown  within  the  bound</span><span>  aries  of  the  district  named.</span></p> "

                        "articleText": "<p><span>  German  writer  visits  Canberra</span></p> <p><span>  \"My  mother  and</span><span>  father  and  brother  were</span><span>  murdered  by  the</span><span>  Nazis\",  Mr  Marcel</span><span>  Reich-Rainicki  said</span><span>  yesterday.  \"I  suppose  I</span><span>  escaped  by  a  near</span><span>  xniracle.  That  is  all\".</span></p> <p><span>  '  Mr  Reich-Rainicki,  a</span><span>  leading  Geirnan  writer  and</span><span>  literary  critic  arrived  in</span><span>  Canberra  from  Hobart</span><span>  yesterday  during  a  tour  of</span><span>  the  cultural  and  literary</span><span>  centres  of  Australia  and</span><span>  New  Zealand.  He  will</span><span>  leave  Canberra  on  Mon</span><span>  day.  !</span></p> <p><span>  He  is  to  give  conferences</span><span>  and  lectures,  and  conduct</span><span>  seminars  at  universities  on</span><span>  topics  such  as  'Literature</span><span>  today  —  Why  and  for</span><span>  Whom',  'German  Con</span><span>  temporary  Writers  and</span><span>  Polities',  and  'Literary</span><span>  Life  in  a  Divided  Ger</span><span>  many'.</span></p> <p><span>  His  tour  is  sponsored  by</span><span>  tbe  Goethe  Institute  in</span><span>  JVIu.th,  which  is  annually</span><span>  sending  outstanding  repre</span><span>  sentatives  of  the  German</span><span>  contemporary  literary</span><span>  scene  to  Australia  and</span><span>  New  Zealand.</span></p> <p><span>  Mr  Reich-Rainicki  was</span><span>  born  in  1920  in  the  Polish</span><span>  town  o£  Wloclawek,  his</span><span>  father  being  Polish  and  his</span><span>  mother  German.  From</span><span>  1929  the  family  lived  in</span></p> <p><span>  Berlin.</span></p> <p><span>  Deported  to</span></p> <p><span>  Poland</span></p> <p><span>  Shortly  after  he  gradu</span><span>  ated  from  the  Fichte  Col</span><span>  lege  in  Berlin  in  1938  the</span><span>  family  became  victims  of</span><span>  the  Hitlerian  policy,</span><span>  Marcel  being  deported  to</span><span>  Poland.  From  1940  to</span><span>  1943  he  lived  in  the  ghetto</span><span>  of  Warsaw,  where,  mirac</span><span>  ulously,  he  managed  to</span><span>  escape  th*  terror  of  the</span></p> <p><span>  SS.</span></p> <p><span>  Mr  Reich-Rainicki</span></p> <p><span>  After  the  war  he  began</span><span>  working  as  a  freelance</span><span>  writer  and  lecturer  for  a</span><span>  publishing  house  in</span><span>  Poland,  with  German</span><span>  literature  as  his  main</span><span>  interest.</span></p> <p><span>  He  began  to  publish</span><span>  editions  in  Polish  of</span><span>  Goethe,  Fontana,  Hein</span><span>  rich  Mann  and  Thomas</span><span>  Mann,  Herman  Hesse  and</span></p> <p><span>  many  others,  \"Thereby</span><span>  proving  my  teacher  right</span><span>  when  he  forecast  that  I</span><span>  would  be  a  critic  and  not</span><span>  a  novelist  or  dramatist  in</span><span>  my  own  right\".</span></p> <p><span>  \"I  edited  also  an/  an</span><span>  thology  of  German  novels</span><span>  and  short  stories  which</span><span>  were  written  by  writers  in</span><span>  exile  from  1932  to  1945'T,</span></p> <p><span>  be  said.</span></p> <p><span>  In  1958  Mr  Reich</span><span>  Ranicki  settled  perman</span><span>  ently  in  Hamburg,  where</span><span>  he  lives  with  his  wife  and</span><span>  24-year-old  son.  Since</span><span>  I960  he  has  been  the  liter</span><span>  ary  critic  of  the  German</span><span>  weekly  Die  Zeit,  and  is  a</span><span>  contributor  to  the  Encyclo</span><span>  paedia  Britannica.</span></p> <p><span>  He  has  achieved  fame</span><span>  for  books  such  as  'German</span><span>  Literature  Today',  pub</span><span>  lished  in  I960,  and  critical</span><span>  evaluations  of  writers  such</span><span>  as  Boell,  Duerenmatt,</span><span>  John  son  and  Grass.  He</span><span>  has  also  worked  Ti  I</span></p> <p><span>  aa  guest  professor  at</span></p> <p><span>  universities  in  the  USA,</span><span>  Canada,  Israel  and  Swe</span></p> <p><span>  den.</span></p> <p><span>  In  Canberra  Mr  Reich</span><span>  Rainicki  was  to  give  a</span><span>  lecture  in  the  German</span><span>  Reading  Room,  Bailey  Ar</span><span>  cade,  Civic,  last  night  at</span><span>  the  invitation  of  the  Aus</span><span>  tralian  Goethe  Society  in</span><span>  Canberra. Stoljar,  acting  head  of</span><span>  the  department.</span></p> <p><span>  A  special  feature  of  Mr</span><span>  Reich-Rainicki's  visit  to</span><span>  Canberra  will  be  his  meet</span><span>  ing  with  the  Canberra</span><span>  composer  Mr  Larry  Sitsky,</span><span>  professor  of  Music  at  the</span><span>  School  of  Music,  Canberra,</span><span>  ■whose  opera  'Lenz',  on  the</span><span>  theme  of  the  short  novel</span><span>  of  the  same  name  by  Georg</span><span>  ■  Buechner,  will  have  its</span><span>  world  premier*  by  tho  Aus</span></p> <p><span>  tralian  Opera  in  Melbourne</span><span>  in  spring.</span></p> <p><span>  Buechner's  drama  'Woy</span><span>  zck'  will  be  presented  by</span><span>  the  German  Theatre  En</span><span>  semble  Die  Bruecke  on</span><span>  September  4  in  the  Can</span></p> <p><span>  berra  Theatre.</span></p> "

                        "articleText": "<p><span>  GERMAN  THRILLER</span></p> <p><span>  IS  INGENIOUS</span></p> <p></p> <p><span>  'NIGHTS  Of  The  Long</span></p> <p><span>  Knives'  is  another  of  H,  H.</span><span>  Kirst's  excellent  German</span><span>  thrillers.  The  plot  is</span></p> <p><span>  ingeniously  intricate,  the</span><span>  tension  is  cleverly  sustained,</span><span>  the  attention  to  social  detail</span><span>  is  impressive  and  the</span><span>  narrative  technique  is</span></p> <p><span>  brilliant</span></p> <p><span>  The  story  opens  with  a  murder</span><span>  in  Lugano,  Switzerland.  The</span><span>  police  discover  that  the  victim,</span><span>  Heinz-Hermann  Norden,  a</span><span>  reserved  and  studious  German</span><span>  expatriate,  was  once  a  member</span><span>  of  the  infamous  Wesel  Group,  an</span><span>  elite  unit  of  Hitler's  SS.</span></p> <p><span>  Their  search  for  Norden's</span><span>  killers  leads  them  back  to  the</span><span>  Germany  of  the  early  1930s</span><span>  when  the  Group  was  formed  by</span><span>  SS  General  Waldemar  Wesel.</span></p> <p><span>  Its  members  —  six  ruthless</span><span>  young  fanatics,  trained  in  the</span><span>  techniques  of  terror  and</span><span>  assassination  —  were  responsible</span><span>  for  the  deaths  of  many  of</span><span>  Hitler's  opponents  at  the</span><span>  beginning  of  the  Nazi  era.  ||</span></p> <p><span>  NIGHTS  OF  THE  LONG</span><span>  KNIVES</span></p> <p><span>  By  H  H.  Kirst</span></p> <p><span>  Collins  279pp  $9.55</span></p> <p><span>  Reviewer:</span></p> <p><span>  PETER  KAY</span></p> <p><span>  ||  Reconstructing  the  past,  the</span><span>  police  follow  the  activities  of  tbe</span><span>  Wesel  Group  through  the</span><span>  pre-war  years  and  beyond,  from</span><span>  the  liquidation  of  Ernst  Rohm,</span><span>  erstwhile  SA  Chief  of  Staff  and</span><span>  former  intimate  of  the  Fuhrer,  to</span><span>  the  pilot  project  that  provided  a</span><span>  model  for  every  extermination</span><span>  camp  from  Auschwitz  to  Belsen.</span></p> <p><span>  Their  investigations  reveal</span></p> <p><span>  that  bitter  feuds  and  rivalries</span><span>  between  members  of  the  Group</span><span>  had  grown  in  intensity  over  the</span><span>  years  and  had  ultimately  erupted</span><span>  into  violence,  more  than  40  years</span><span>  later  in  Lugano.</span></p> <p><span>  Finally  the  killers  are</span><span>  identified,  but  it  appears  for  a</span><span>  time  that  one  of  them  will  escape</span><span>  until  an  exhilarating  last-page</span><span>  twist  neatly  completes  the</span></p> <p><span>  denouement.</span></p> "

                        "articleText": "<p><span>  pilbara</span><span>  pets</span></p> <p><span>  GERMAN</span><span>  SHEPHERD</span></p> <p><span>  When  asking  a  friend  who  owns  one  of</span><span>  these  magnificent  breed,  the  difference</span><span>  between  the  Alsatian  and  German  Shep-</span><span>  herd,  I  was  immediately  asked  if  I  knew</span><span>  anything  about  dogs.  I  was  told  I  would</span><span>  have  to  be  pretty  silly  not  to  know  the</span><span>  difference  —  none.</span></p> <p><span>  During  the  World  Wars  the  British  dropped</span><span>  the  name  German  Shepherd  and  decided  on  the</span><span>  name,  Alsatian  Wolf  Dog.  This  is  probably  why</span><span>  a  lot  of  people  associate  the  German  Shepherd</span><span>  with  the  wolf,  but  it  is  totally  incorrect.</span><span>  In  fact,  in  spite  of  their  wolf-like  appear-</span><span>  ance,  the  German  Shepherd  belongs  to  the  breed</span><span>  which  have  the  least  traces  of  wolves.</span><span>  The  Shepherd  can  be  traced  farther  back</span><span>  in  time  than  any  other  breed.  The  oldest  of</span><span>  dogs  resembling  the  Shepherd  is  about  twenty</span><span>  thousand  years  old.</span><span>  The  breed  in  early  times  was  originally</span><span>  used  for  hunting  and  as  a  watch  dog.  More</span><span>  recently  they  have  been  used  as  Shepherd</span><span>  dogs  watching  cattle,  hence  the  name.</span><span>  They  were  also  once  regarded  as  the  only</span><span>  dogs  suitable  of  guiding  the  blind.</span><span>  They  are  now  also  used  as  police  dogs,</span><span>  where  their  duties  entail:--  tracking,  rescue</span><span>  and  messenger  carriers.  Above  all  they  are</span><span>  an  excellent  family  pet.</span><span>  They  seem  quite  suited  to  the  climate  of</span><span>  the  Pilbara.</span><span>  I  must  sympathize  with  the  owners  of  a</span><span>  German  Shepherd  for  it  seems  that  they  are</span><span>  always  the  first  to  have  the  finger  pointed  at</span><span>  them  when  there  is  any  trouble.  Doberman</span><span>  owners  often  have  the  same  problem—  I  know</span><span>  I've  got  one.</span></p> "

                        "articleText": "<p><span>  TROOPS</span></p> <p><span>  ?</span></p> <p><span>  BONN,  Tues,  AAP  —  West</span><span>  German  commandos  attacked  behind</span><span>  the  blinding  flash  of  special  grenades</span><span>  and  swarmed  aboad  a  hijacked  Lufthansa</span><span>  airline  at  Mogadisau  in  Somalia</span><span>  to  kill  three  terrorists  and  free  unharmed</span><span>  86  hostages  in  a  seyen-minute</span><span>  raid  today.</span><span>  The  West  German  Government  announced</span><span>  that  a  woman  hijacker  was  wounded</span><span>  and  captured.</span></p> <p><span>  The  spectacular  raid  on  the  jet  parked</span><span>  on  a  runway  at  Mogadishu,  in  north-east  Africa,</span><span>  came  about  90  minutes  before  a  deadline</span><span>  set  by  the  hijackers  for  the  killing  of  the  hostages.</span><span>  It  ended  a  five-day  ordeal  that  covered:</span><span>  about  11,000  kilometres  and  took  the  plane  to</span><span>  six  countries.</span><span>  Among  those  rescued  were  11  West  Ger-.</span><span>  man  beauty  queens  and  an  American-  woman.</span><span>  Mrs  Christine  Santiago,  44,  of  Santee,  California</span><span>  and-  her  five-year-old  son.</span><span>  .  Authorities  said,  the  -hostages  would  return</span><span>  to  Frankfurt  international  Airport  in  West</span><span>  Germany  late  this  afternoon.</span><span>  Two  ot  the  hijackers  were  members  of.  a</span><span>  West  German  terrorist  gang  and  two  of  them</span><span>  members  of  an  extremist  wing  of  the  Palestine</span><span>  Liberation  Organisation.</span><span>  Three  were  shot  dead  before  they  could</span><span>  carry  out  their  threat  to  blow  up  the  plane,</span><span>  and  one  German  raider,  the  woman,  was  wounded,</span><span>  the.  Government  said,</span><span>  Using  special  grenades  creating  a  blinding</span><span>  flash  and  deafening  noise,  28  men  of  Unit</span><span>  .9  of  the  Federal-Border  Troops  blew  open  the</span><span>  Boeing  737's  doors  about  midnight,  the  Government</span><span>  said.</span><span>  A  swift  shoot-out  ensued  in  which  the  hijackers</span><span>  were  shot  dead  and  within  seven  minutes</span><span>  all  the  hostages  had  left  the  plane.</span><span>  About  60  luen  of  the  crack  German  Unit</span><span>  9  flew,  aboard  a  Lufthansa  Boeing  707  from  the</span><span>  Greek  island  of.Crete  to  Mogadishu  yesterday,</span><span>  landing  after  dark.</span><span>  to</span><span>  The  raid  was  directed  by  GerdBoeden,</span><span>  head  of  the  anti-terrorist  squad  of  the  German</span><span>  Federal  Police,  and  Ulrich  Wegener,  head  of  the</span><span>  raiding  troops.  Spokesmen  said  they  had  been</span><span>  secretly  following  the  hijacked  aircraft  on  its</span><span>  trip.</span><span>  Lufthansa  spokesman  Frank  Cesarz  said</span><span>  the  raid  had  been  planned  to  the  last  detail.</span><span>  \"The  men  of  the  frontier  protection  troops  had</span><span>  trained  for  a  long  time  on.  an  aircraft  of  the</span><span>  same  type,\"  he  said.</span><span>  The  border  guards  are  the  senior  military</span><span>  arm  of  West  Germany.</span><span>  They  were  the  first  armed  unit  formed</span><span>  after  World  War  2.  Their  prime  mission  is  to'</span><span>  guard.  West  Germany's  border  and  they  also</span><span>  provide  elite  troops  that  guard  the  Chancellor,</span><span>  President  and  other  Government  officials.</span><span>  They  wear  a  'green  uniform,  boots  and  unmistakable</span><span>  coal-shuttle  helmets  with  leather</span><span>  flaps  at  the  rear.  :</span><span>  The  lightning  •  raid  resembled  the  Israeli</span><span>  raid,  at  Entebbe  Airport  in  Uganda  on  July  4,</span><span>  1976,  when  Israeli  commandos  flew  secretly  into</span><span>  the  airport  and  rescued  102  hijacked  hostages</span><span>  in  a  shoot-out  with  Arab  and  West  German</span><span>  terrorists.</span></p> <p><span>  The  hijackers  seized  the  German  Boeing</span><span>  737  plane  at  midday  last  Thursday  over  the</span><span>  French  Riviera  as  it  was  flying  from  Majorca</span><span>  to  Frankfurt.  They  later  forced  the  plane  to</span><span>  fly  to  Rome,  Cyprus,  Bahrain,  Dubai.  Aden  and</span><span>  finally  Somalia.</span><span>  All  over'</span><span>  ^  ••:•«••  ML</span><span>  J.O</span><span>  HI  1lit^S</span><span>  •  m  m  w  w  w</span><span>  They  demanded  the  release  of  13  terrorist</span><span>  prisoners  held  in  German  and  Turkish  jails</span><span>  and  a  $U.S.15.5  million  (K13  million)  ransom.</span><span>  Both  Germany  and  Turkey  stood  firm  as  one</span><span>  deadline  after  another  set  by  the  hijackers</span><span>  came  and  went.</span><span>  Jubilation  in  Germany  was  dampened  by</span><span>  the  death  of  Juergen  Schumann,  the  37-yearold</span><span>  captain  of  the  plane  who  was.  shot  to  death</span><span>  yesterday.  The  hijackers  unceremoniously  dumped</span><span>  his  body  from  the  aircraft  while  the  hostages</span><span>  watched  in  horror.,</span><span>  There  was  still  no  word  on  the  fate  of</span><span>  .industrialist  Hanns-Martin  Schleyer,  62,  kidnapped</span><span>  by  West  German  terrorists  on  September  5.</span><span>  An  ultimatum  on  his  life  expired  on  Sunday.</span><span>  His  kidnappers  had  tied  his  fate  to  the  demands</span><span>  of  the  four  hijackers.</span><span>  The  special  plane  carrying  all  the  hostages</span><span>  left  Mogadishu  at  5.30  am.</span><span>  Injured  passengers  were,  given  first  aid</span><span>  by  Somali  and  German  doctors  in  the  airport</span><span>  waiting  room.Some  of  the  injured  were  taken</span><span>  to  Medina  hospital  in  Mogadishu  for  treatment</span><span>  and  then  returned  to  the  airport  for  the  flight</span><span>  home:</span><span>  The  Somali  news  agency,  Sonn  a,  quoted</span><span>  Information  Minister  Abdulkasim  Salad-  Hasan</span><span>  as  saying  the  rescue  operation  was  completed</span><span>  in  10  minutes.</span><span>  The  Minister  added  the  rescue  was  carried</span><span>  out  \"by  Somali  security  forces  in  conjunction</span><span>  with:  some  German  technical  experts.\"</span><span>  He  said  his  Government  had  no  option</span><span>  but  to  use  force  \"to  save  the  lives  of  innocent</span><span>  passengers,  once  all  other  channels  had  been</span><span>  exhausted.\"</span><span>  Sonna.said  there  was  \"great.rejoicing\"  at</span><span>  Mogadishu's  small  airport  over  the  success  of</span><span>  the  raid.</span><span>  A  Lufthansa  spokesman  said  details  of</span><span>  the  raid  were  sketchy.</span><span>  Commandos  practised  attacking  an  identical</span><span>  plane  before  being  sent  to  Mogadishu,</span><span>  sources  said.  .  .  .  ..  .</span><span>  They  stormed  into  the  aircraft  through</span><span>  emergency  exits  on  both  wings,  without  any</span><span>  warning  to  the  occupants  of  the  plane,  the</span><span>  Lufthansa  spokesman  said.</span><span>  Informed  sources  said  commandos  found</span><span>  that  the  hijackers  had  placed  explosives  inside</span><span>  the  plane  and  poured  petrol  onto  the  aisle  carpeting,</span><span>  apparently  to  cause  \"a  fire  in  the  event</span><span>  of  an  attack.  Passengers  were  bound  in  their</span><span>  seats,  the  sources  said.</span><span>  There  was  some  shooting,  causing  bullet</span><span>  damage  to  the  inside  of  the  aircraft,  the  spokesman</span><span>  said.  There  was  no  panic.  The  passengers</span><span>  were  evacuated  as  fast  as  possible  by  sliding</span><span>  down  inflated  slides  from  the  emergency  exits.</span><span>  The  three  stewardesses  directed  the  evacuation,</span><span>  he  said.</span></p> <p><span>  no</span><span>  news</span><span>  BONN,  Tues. German  Government</span><span>  sources  appealed  to  the</span><span>  kidnappers  to  release</span><span>  the  62-year-old  head  of</span><span>  the  West  German  Employers</span><span>  Federation.</span><span>  Meanwhile,  leaders</span><span>  of  world  airline  pilots</span><span>  today  called  for  a  48-</span><span>  hour  strike  to  back,</span><span>  demands  for  a  special</span><span>  debate  in  the  United</span><span>  Nations  General  Assembly</span><span>  on  the  problem</span><span>  of  hijacking.  .</span><span>  A  statement  issued</span><span>  by  the  International</span><span>  Federation  of  Airline</span><span>  Pilots  Associations</span><span>  said:  \"This,.is  the.  last</span><span>  chance  to  fix  hijacking</span><span>  problem?.\"  .</span><span>  In  Stuttgart  the  three</span><span>  surviving  leaders  of</span><span>  West  Germany's  notorious</span><span>  Baader-Meinho£</span><span>  guerrillas  all  committed</span><span>  suicide  in  jail*</span><span>  here  early  today.</span><span>  They  shot  themselves</span><span>  through  the  head.</span><span>  Andreas. The  Frank</span><span>  furt-Lod  flight  and  the  Lod</span><span>  Atarot  flight  would  be</span><span>  booked  on  separate  tickets.</span></p> <p><span>  The  German  Foreign</span><span>  Ministry  spokesman  statec</span><span>  that  his  government  op</span><span>  posed  Frankfurt-Atarot</span><span>  flights.</span></p> <p><span>  From  a  legal  standpoint,</span><span>  .  the  spokesman  said,  there</span></p> <p><span>  was  no  difference  whether</span><span>  the  flights  were  direct  or</span><span>  included  a  stop-over  at</span></p> <p><span>  Lod.</span></p> "

                        "snippet": "“OUR volunteers come because they feel responsibility for the history of our country and a responsibility for the future of our country. We",
                        "troveUrl": "https://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article263193859?searchTerm=german+date%3A%5B1980-01-01T00%3A00%3A00Z+TO+1989-12-31T00%3A00%3A00Z%5D",
                        "tag": [],
                        "comment": [],
                        "articleText": "<p><span>  German  volunteers</span></p> <p><span>  By  MYRA  NOVECK/Jerusalem  Post  Reporter</span></p> <p><span>  “OUR  volunteers  come  because</span><span>  they  feel  responsibility  for  the  his</span><span>  tory  of  our  country  and  a  responsibil</span><span>  ity  for  the  future  of  our  country.  We</span><span>  want  to  push  for  the  development  of</span><span>  reconciliation  and  peace,”  says  20</span><span>  year-old  Christianna  Dahm  of  Col</span><span>  ogne,  a  volunteer  for  Action  for</span><span>  Reconciliation  and  Peace  Services,  a</span><span>  group  of  young  Germans  whose  goal</span><span>  is  to  encourage  reconciliation  be</span><span>  tween  Germany  and  countries  that</span></p> <p><span>  suffered  under  the  Nazis.</span></p> <p><span>  The  group  has  160  volunteers  in</span><span>  nine  countries.  Nearly  a  quarter  of</span><span>  the  volunteers  work  in  Israel.  The</span></p> <p><span>  idea  for  the  original  organization</span><span>  came  out  of  a  discussion  by  German</span><span>  Protestant  clergymen,  led  by  Lothar</span><span>  Kreissig  in  the  late  Fifties,  who  “were</span><span>  looking  for  a  way  to  overcome  the</span><span>  problems  of  relations  between  Ger</span><span>  mans  and  other  nations  as  a  result  of</span></p> <p><span>  the  war  and  the  Holocaust,”  says</span><span>  Dahm.</span></p> <p><span>  In  Israel  the  organization  concen</span><span>  trates  on  working  with  the  elderly  -</span><span>  particularly  German-  and  Yiddish</span><span>  speaking  persons  who  were  the</span></p> <p><span>  direct  victims  of  Nazism  -  as  well  as</span><span>  with  handicapped  children.  Volun</span><span>  teer  jobs  include  teching  extra</span><span>  curricular  subjects,  tutoring,  work  in</span><span>  homes  for  the  aged  and  home  visits</span><span>  to  the  elderly.</span></p> <p><span>  Action  for  Reconciliation  is  an</span><span>  18-month  programme,  although  a</span><span>  West  German  law  just  passed  and</span><span>  lengthening  army  service  will  mean</span></p> <p><span>  new  male  volunteers  will  in  future</span></p> <p><span>  participate  for  two  years  if  they</span><span>  choose  to  join  the  Action  group  and</span><span>  thus  fulfil  their  national  service  re</span></p> <p><span>  quirement  as  an  alternative  to  army</span><span>  service.  The  programme  begins  with</span></p> <p><span>  a  one-month  seminar  in  West</span></p> <p><span>  Gemany,  which  includes  visits  to</span><span>  concentration  camps,  work  in  the</span><span>  camp  museums  and  discussions  with</span></p> <p><span>  former  inmates.</span></p> <p><span>  The  volunteers  then  go  to  the</span><span>  country  of  their  choice.  The  Israeli</span><span>  contingent  spends  the  first  three</span><span>  months  in  a  work-language-study</span><span>  programme  on,  a  kibbutz  before</span><span>  being  sent  to  serve  in  institutions</span></p> <p><span>  around  the  country.  In  most  cases,</span><span>  the  institution  provides  room  and</span><span>  board,  and  sometimes,  pocket</span><span>  money.  If  it  can’t  afford  that  and</span><span>  Action  officials  think  it’s  important</span><span>  enough,  the  organization  foots  the</span><span>  bill,  but  resources  are  limited.</span></p> <p><span>  Two-thirds  of  the  organization’s</span><span>  national  budget  comes  from  private</span></p> <p><span>  donations.</span></p> <p><span>  The  volunteers  say  they  rarely</span><span>  encounter  anti-German  feeling</span><span>  here,  although  they  say  earlier</span><span>  groups  had  more  problems,  and</span></p> <p><span>  some  kibbutzim  still  refuse  to  take</span><span>  German  volunteers.  On  the  other</span></p> <p><span>  hand,  many  of  the  elderly  with</span><span>  whom  they  work  feel  more  comfort</span><span>  able  speaking  German  than  Hebrew</span><span>  and  still  feel  an  attachment  to  Ger</span><span>  man  culture.</span></p> <p><span>  “it’s  the  second  generation  that  is</span><span>  more  of  a  problem,”  says  28-year</span></p> <p><span>  old  Einat  Weiss,  housemother  at  a</span><span>  seminar  centre  serving  the  volun</span><span>  teers,  who  explains  that  the  Israeli</span><span>  born  children  of  refugees  or  Holo</span><span>  caust  survivors  see  only  the  negative</span><span>  side  of  Germany  while  the  parents</span><span>  remember  “another”  Germany.</span></p> <p><span>  Ironically,  Israel’s  economic</span></p> <p><span>  crunch  has  made  it  harder  for  the</span><span>  Germans  to  find  suitable  volunteer</span><span>  work.</span></p> <p><span>  Apart  from  having  contact  with</span><span>  kibbutz  members,  the  volunteers</span><span>  also  spend  weekends  with  city  fami</span></p> <p><span>  lies.</span></p> <p><span>  “You  get  to  know  a  country  and</span><span>  the  people  get  to  know  you  and</span><span>  maybe  after  that  they’ll  think  a  little</span><span>  differently,”  says  volunteer  Bern</span><span>  hard  Rohrbacher,  20,  from  Bonn.</span><span>  That’s  the  sigh  of  reconciliation',</span><span>  adds  Dahm.  “It’s  small  steps  and</span></p> <p><span>  hard  work.”</span></p> "

The</span><span>  first  German-language  Free</span><span>  School  for  Jews  was  opened  in</span><span>  Berlin  by  David  Friedlaender  in</span><span>  1778  the  aim  being  the  replace</span><span>  ment  of  Yiddish,  still  the  vernac</span><span>  ular  of  the  Jewish  people,  by  the</span><span>  German  language. He</span><span>  wrote  biting  satires  on  the  Ger</span><span>  man  Parliament,  which  landed</span><span>  him  in  grave  conflict  with  the  Ger</span><span>  man  authorities.                         "list": [],
                        "id": "213734006",
                        "url": "https://api.trove.nla.gov.au/v3/newspaper/213734006",
                        "heading": "German Feminist Films",
                        "category": "Article",
                        "title": {
                            "id": "1104",
                            "title": "Filmnews (Sydney, NSW : 1975 - 1995)"
                        },
                        "date": "1980-03-01",
                        "page": "13",
                        "pageSequence": "13",
                        "relevance": {
                            "score": 122.65252685546875,
                            "value": "very relevant"
                        },
                        "snippet": "For Australian women making films, reliant on grant monies and the nontheatrical market for distribution, the experience of West German feminist film",
                        "troveUrl": "https://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article213734006?searchTerm=german+date%3A%5B1980-01-01T00%3A00%3A00Z+TO+1989-12-31T00%3A00%3A00Z%5D",
                        "tag": [],
                        "comment": [],
                        "articleText": "<p><span>  German  Feminist  Films</span></p> <p><span>  For  Australian  women  making  films,</span><span>  reliant  on  grant  monies  and  the  non-</span><span>  theatrical  market  for  distribution,  the</span><span>  experience  of  West  German  feminist  film</span><span>  makers  provides  an  interesting  com</span><span>  parison.</span><span>  The  films  brought  together  by  the</span></p> <p><span>  Goethe  Institute  and  screened  in  a  series</span><span>  of  programs  across  Australia  recently</span><span>  were,  by  and  large,  made  with  money</span><span>  from  television  and  the  guarantee  of</span><span>  T.V.  exposure.</span><span>  As  Dr  Jutta  Brueckner,  the  film  maker</span><span>  who  accompanied  the  tour  explains  (see</span><span>  interview),  the  films  presented  are  not</span><span>  typical  or  representative  of  the  body  of</span><span>  West  German  women's  film  production.</span><span>  No  short  films  appeared  in  the  program,</span><span>  for  example.</span><span>  But  the  collection  did  reveal  an  en</span><span>  couraging  diversity  of  styles  and  sub</span><span>  ject  matter,  linked  by  the  common  theme</span><span>  of  alienation  both  from  the  prevailing</span><span>  image  of  woman  and  from  confining'</span><span>  mores.</span><span>  Do  Right  and  Fear  No  One  is  the</span><span>  earlier  of  Brueckners  two  films.  When</span><span>  she  began  it  she  knew  next  to  nothing</span><span>  about  the  mechanics  of  making  a  film,</span><span>  but  a  great  deal  about  her  protagonist,</span><span>  Gerda  Siepenbrink  (Jutta's  mother),  the</span><span>  kind  of  lower  middle  class  woman  who</span><span>  grew  up  after  World  War  1  and  matured</span><span>  during  the  Nazi  era.</span><span>  From  a  fatherless  and  hence  poor</span><span>  family,  Gerda  was  raised  in  an  even  more</span><span>  relentlessly  conformist  environment  than</span><span>  her  peers.  Her  mother  didn't  want  people</span><span>  to  say  her  daughters  ran  wild  for  want  of</span><span>  paternal  control,  so  they  were  kept  at</span><span>  home,  sewing,  during  their  non-working</span><span>  hours.</span><span>  When  the  insurance  money  for  her</span><span>  husband's  death  arrived  Gerda's  mother,</span><span>  short  of  funds  for  daily  necessities,  in</span><span>  vested  it  in  a  good  family  burial  plot.</span><span>  JBeyond  every  other  consideration,  res:</span><span>  pectability  was  the  most  important</span><span>  human  achievement  in  her  eyes,  and  this</span><span>  rite  instilled  in  her  daughters.</span></p> <p><span>  Brueckner  constructed  the  film  of</span><span>  animated  still  photographs  combined</span><span>  with  Gerda  narrating  the  richly  ironic</span><span>  soundtrack  in  a  curiously  deadpan</span><span>  fashion,  perhaps  still  unaware  of  the  ab</span><span>  surdity  of  investing  in  death  in  the  midst</span><span>  of  life.</span><span>  The  opening  section  of  the  film  uses</span><span>  the  photographs  of  August  Sander  who</span><span>  attempted,  in  his  work,  to  construct  a</span><span>  composite  portrait  of  Germany  during</span><span>  the  pre-war  years  and  whose  work  was</span><span>  subsequently  banned  and  burned  by  the</span><span>  Nazis.  There  is  very  little  camera  move</span><span>  ment  in  this  section,  with  each  image</span><span>  replacing  the  next  at  a  measured  pace.</span><span>  The  photographs  are  of  different</span><span>  people  and  unrelated  to  the  narration</span><span>  except  in  so  far  as  Gerda  is  representative</span><span>  of  many  of  her  country  men  and  women</span><span>  of  the  era.</span><span>  When  the  protagonist  begins  to</span><span>  develop  a  personality  based  less  on  her</span><span>  background  and  more  on  .her  consider</span><span>  ation  of  the  forces  that  have  shaped  her</span><span>  life,  her  own  image  takes  the  place  of  the</span><span>  historic  photographs.  As  she  takes  on  a</span><span>  more  challenging  job,  the  pace  of  the</span><span>  images  quickens,  climaxing  in  her  dis</span><span>  covery  that  her  husband  has  been  seeing</span><span>  another  woman,  which  is  illustrated  by  a</span><span>  rapid  series  of  blurred  images,  conveying</span><span>  the  uncontrollable  fury  of  a  woman</span><span>  wronged.</span><span>  A  portrait  of  both  a  generation  and</span><span>  one  woman  plodding  towards  emanci</span><span>  pation,  Do  Right  and_  Fear  No  One  ex</span><span>  presses  a  gently  guarded  optimism  about</span><span>  the  possibilities  for  change  within  a  life</span><span>  time.</span><span>  But  what  happens  when  the  con</span><span>  ventions  and  expectations  are  gone?</span><span>  Brueckner  looks  at  a  contemporary  Gerda</span><span>  -  Rita  Rischak  —  in  her  second  film,</span><span>  A  Totally  Neglected  Girl  (subtitled  How</span><span>  Low  Can  a  Girl  Sink?).  Like  Gerda,  Rita</span><span>  is  real,  this  time  one  of  the  film  maker's</span><span>  best  friends.  She  lives  with  her  righteous</span><span>  and  oider-obsessed  parents  and  her  five-</span></p> <p><span>  year-old  illegitimate  son.  But  the  location</span><span>  and  particulars  aside,  Rita  could  be  any</span><span>  one  and  the  persistent  self-hatred  she</span><span>  espouses,  combined  with  half-formed</span><span>  dreams  of  a  glamorous  (or  at  least  self-</span><span>  fulfilling)  existence,  must  be  familiar  to</span><span>  many  many  women.</span><span>  Although  the  men  in  her  life  are</span><span>  ciphers,  vapid  and  transient,  (including</span><span>  the  one  who  has  fathered  her  son)  and</span><span>  she  no  longer  bothers  hiding  her  con</span><span>  tempt  for  them,  she  still  expects  one  per</span><span>  fect  specimen  to  turn  up  and  wisk  her</span><span>  away  from  her  drab  life  into  a  fantasy</span><span>  world  of  love,  beauty,  motherhood  and</span><span>  eternal  youth.</span><span>  Rita's  tussle  between  dreams  and</span><span>  reality  is  played  out  over  one  day  in  her</span><span>  life,  one  on  which  she  has  to  find  a  new</span><span>  job  or  tell  her  parents  how  she  had  to</span><span>  leave  her  old  one.</span><span>  For  its  sheer  hopelessness,  A  Totally</span><span>  Neglected  Girl  is  a  frightening  film,</span><span>  salvaged  from  complete  despair  by  the</span><span>  heroine's  witty  perceptions  of  her  pre</span><span>  dicament  combined  with  her  spunk  in</span></p> <p><span>  the  lace  ot  the  wall  of  conformity  around</span><span>  her.</span><span>  In  An  All  Round  Reduced  Personality,</span><span>  Helke  Sanders  (not  to  be  confused  with</span><span>  Helma  Sanders,  director  of  Heinrich  and</span><span>  Shirrin's  Wedding)  examines  another  di</span><span>  mension  of  encirclement.  She  juxtaposes</span><span>  a  personality  under  seige  with  a  city,</span><span>  Berlin,  similarly  surrounded.</span><span>  Edda  Chiemnykewski  (played  by</span><span>  Sanders  herself);  mother,  lover,  freelance</span><span>  photojournalism  and  member  of  a</span><span>  women's  photographic  project,  juggles  a</span><span>  myriad  of  daily  demands  on  her  time</span><span>  while  trying  to  remain  herself,  a  growing</span><span>  personality.</span><span>  The  film's  title  derives  from  a  slogan,</span><span>  \"the  all-round  realised  socialist  person</span><span>  ality\"  broadcast  on  East  German  radio.</span><span>  Disenchanted  with  both  east  and  west,</span><span>  and  caught  geographically  between  the</span><span>  two,  Edda's  attention  focuses  instead  on</span><span>  the  thousands  of  minor  issues  and  irrit</span><span>  ations  that  make  up  an  individual's  ex</span><span>  istence  and  on  the  integration  of  the</span><span>  personal  and  the  political.</span><span>  The  two  come  together  when  the</span><span>  women's  photography  group  is  asked  to</span><span>  prepare  a  photographic  exhibition  de</span><span>  picting  Berlin  from  a  woman's  viewpoint.</span></p> <p><span>  The  view  turns  out  to  be  less  conform-</span><span>  ingly  female  than  the  city  fathers  had</span><span>  hoped,  illustrating,  very  gently,  that</span><span>  women  are  people  too.</span><span>  An  All  Round  Reduced  Personality  is</span><span>  a  disarmingly  low-key  film,  riddled  with</span><span>  cynicism  but  never  bleak,  and  shot  with  a</span><span>  documentary  feel.</span><span>  The  single  true  documentary  in  the</span><span>  collection  is,  by  contrast,  a  dramatised</span><span>  re-enactment  of  a  woman's  experiences  as</span><span>  a  battered  wife,  and  what  she  does  about</span><span>  it.  The  Power  of  Men  is  the  Patience  of</span><span>  Women  (Cristina  Perincioli)  fuses  the</span><span>  experiences  of  several  women  who  found</span><span>  their  way  to  a  Berlin  women's  refuge  to</span><span>  create  the  central  character,  Addi.</span><span>  Addi  endures  a  violent  husband  be</span><span>  cause  of  her  economic  dependence  on</span><span>  him.  Their  young  son,  increasingly  dis</span><span>  turbed  by  events  at  home  and  sent  home</span><span>  by  his  kindergarten  because  of  his  anti</span><span>  social  behaviour,  heightens  her  isolation.</span></p> <p><span>  When  she  sees  a  documentary  about  a</span><span>  women's  refuge  on  television  she  simply</span><span>  calls  a  cab  and  leaves  without  turning  off</span><span>  the  set.</span><span>  The  film  does  not  moralise,  or  even</span><span>  accuse.  Nor  does  it  fall  into  the  trap  of</span><span>  portraying  the  villain  as  a  self-propelled</span><span>  ogre.  Susceptible  to  violent  outbursts  and</span><span>  alternately  cruel  and  then  concerned.</span><span>  Addi's  husband  is  himself  the  product  of</span><span>  an  uncaring  background  -  an  adult</span><span>  version  of  what  his  son  is  well  on  the  way</span><span>  to  becoming.</span><span>  Though  the  refuge,  to  which  Addi</span><span>  eventually  escapes,  is  presented  as  a  sal</span><span>  vation,  the  film  in  general  avoids  a  tone</span><span>  of  grating  self-congratulation  that  some</span><span>  times  characterises  feminist  documentaries</span><span>  about  the  movement's  achievements.</span><span>  Staff  of  the  Paddington  Town  Hall,</span><span>  where  these  films  were  shown  in  Sydney,</span><span>  tell  of  a  man  who  periodically  comes  in</span><span>  to  enquire  about  screenings  by  the  Gothic</span><span>  Institute.</span><span>  What  he  probably  has  in  mind  are</span><span>  films  like  Elfi  Mikesch's  I  Often  Think  of</span><span>  Hawaii  and  Ulrike  Ottinger's  Madam  X  —</span><span>  an  Absolute  Dictator,  two  murky  ex</span><span>  amples  of  supposedly  feminist  aesthetic.</span><span>  I  Often  Think  of  Hawaii  is  a  stulti</span><span>  fying  boring  film  about  the  stultifying</span><span>  boring  lives  led  by  people  forced  to  live</span><span>  in  housing  estates  and  work  at  lousy,</span><span>  repetitive,  poorly-paid  jobs.</span><span>  Mikesch  focuses  most  of  her  attention</span><span>  on  the  pipe-dreams  of  one  such  family  -</span></p> <p><span>  turning  her  subjects  into  objects  of  in</span><span>  tellectual  curiosity  fop  the  well-educated.</span><span>  Films  such  as  this  echo  Martin  Nicklaus'</span><span>  celebrated  remarks  about  sociologists:</span><span>  Professional  palms  turned  upwards  and</span><span>  professional  eyes  cast  downwards.  They</span><span>  should  be  viewed  as  a  sort  of  cinematic</span><span>  colonialism  and  do  nothing  to  advance</span><span>  the  cause  of  feminism  or  anything  else.</span><span>  In  Madame  X,  Ulrike  Ottinger  indulges</span><span>  in  another  kind  of  feminist  myth-making,</span><span>  with  a  141  minute  endurance  test  that</span><span>  owes  a  lot  to  Lord  of  the  Flies.  Ottinger</span><span>  has  gathered  together  seven  women  repre</span><span>  senting  seven  different  female  stereotypes,</span><span>  put  them  out  to  sea  on  a  junk  and  left</span><span>  them  to  it.  Meanwhile  she  experiments</span><span>  with  a  variety  of  encounters  and  camera</span><span>  angles  which  are  supposed  to  prove  (I</span><span>  think)  that  we  are  all  trapped  by  the  past</span><span>  and  forging  a  new  society  is  going  to  be  a</span><span>  lot  more  difficult  than  Utopians  imagine.</span><span>  Most  of  the  budget  for  this  film</span><span>  appears  to  have  been  squandered  by  the</span><span>  art  department  and,  in  particular,  on</span><span>  some  wonderfully  lavish  costumes.  The</span><span>  rest  of  the  production  is  an  obscure</span><span>  celebration  of  the  amateurish  which,  had</span><span>  it  been  directed  by  a  man,  would  not</span><span>  have  rated  a  showing.</span></p> <p><span>  What,  for  me,  is  confusing  about  these</span><span>  films  is  that  they  seem  to  have  so  little</span><span>  in  common  with  the  films  of  men  like</span><span>  Herzog,  Wenders,  Fassbinder  and  Haupt</span><span>  that  have  been  shown  here  and  it  is  not</span><span>  enough  to  say  defiantly  that  women</span><span>  make  films  differently  from  men.  The</span><span>  aest-known  contemporary  German  films</span><span>  have  a  sense  of  self-assurance.  These</span><span>  films,  by  and  large,  do  not.</span><span>  People  steeped  in  the  Australian</span><span>  feminist  film  tradition  also  will  find  very</span><span>  little  in  these  films  with  which  they</span><span>  would  feel  familiar.  Australian  women's</span><span>  films  seem  to  have  a  sense  of  purpose  -</span><span>  conflicting  purpose  often  —  but  purpose</span><span>  nonetheless.</span><span>  By  contrast,  these  German  women's</span><span>  films  have  a  strong  grasp  of  the  flaws  in</span><span>  the  present,  know  exactly  what  was</span><span>  wrong  with  the  past  and  have  almost</span><span>  nothing  to  say  about  the  future.</span></p> <p><span>  Barbara  Alysen</span></p> <p><span>  Redupers</span></p> <p><span>  RONDA</span><span>  MACGREGOR</span><span>  ?</span><span>  RIM  EDITOR</span><span>  A</span><span>  PHONE  622  080</span></p> "
