                        "articleText": "<p><span>  Picture:  Rauler</span></p> <p><span>  Larry  Robinson,  of  the  Montreal  Canadiens,  catches  a  high  stick  in  the  face  from  from  Brad  McCrimmon,  of  the  Calgary  Flames,</span></p> <p><span>  during  first  period  action  at  Calgary.  The  Canadiens  won  4-3.</span></p> <p><span>  German  tenuis  unwinds</span></p> <p><span>  By  DAVID  IRVINE</span></p> <p><span>  Never  before  have  the  Germans,  a  nation  with</span><span>  no  great  tradition  in  tennis,  known  such  success  as</span></p> <p><span>  in  1988.</span></p> <p><span>  Apart  from  his  Davis  Cup  heroics,  Boris  Becker</span><span>  was  a  worthy  winner  of  the  Masters  while,  on  ¡he</span><span>  women's  front,  Steffi  Graf  recorded  only  the  third</span><span>  Grand  Slam  of  all  time  —  then  burnished  it  with</span><span>  Olympic  gold.</span></p> <p><span>  Since  Becker's  first  Wimbledon  triumph  at  17,</span><span>  the  number  of  players  throughout  West  Germany</span><span>  is  said  to  have  doubled  to  over  two  million.</span></p> <p><span>  Yet  still  the  feeling  persists  that,  though  the</span><span>  personalities  are  projected,  the  game  itself  remains</span><span>  a  lesser  relation  of  soccer  and  even  handball.</span></p> <p><span>  Many  believe  —  and  perhaps  with  good  reason</span><span>  —  that  Becker  and  Graf  will  do  even  better  next</span><span>  year.  If  they  do,  their  impact  through  television</span><span>  will  again  be  limited.  Already  it  seems  the  main</span><span>  channels  will  be  priced  out  of  the  Wimbledon</span><span>  market.  West  Germans,  it  seems,  are  still  not  con</span><span>  vinced  that  Becker  and  Graf  are  the  sort  of  catalyst</span><span>  Björn  Borg  was  to  a  generation  of  Swedes.</span></p> <p><span>  \"Here  in  Sweden,\"  they  observe,  \"tennis  is  avail</span><span>  able  for  all.  In  Germany  people  are  still  priced</span></p> <p><span>  out.\"</span></p> <p><span>  They  also  say  —  and  the  evidence  tends  to</span><span>  support  them  —  that  even  someone  as  talented  as</span><span>  Carl-Uwe  Steeb,  who  made  the  cup  triumph  possi</span><span>  ble  by  beating  Mats  Wilander,  prefers  the  comfort</span><span>  of  the  Bundesliga,  where  sponsorship  can  bring</span><span>  lucrative  rewards,  to  the  competitive  demands  of</span></p> <p><span>  the  circuit.</span></p> <p><span>  League  tennis,  which  extends  the  clay-court  sea</span><span>  son,  has  been  the  bane  of  a  succession  of  West</span><span>  German  national  coaches.  A  decade  ago  Rolf</span><span>  Gehring  and  Uli  Pinner  were  among  Europe's  best,</span><span>  but  they  never  sought  to  prove  it  on  a  world-wide</span></p> <p><span>  stage.</span></p> <p><span>  In  Becker  and  Graf,  though,  their  nation  has</span><span>  been  blessed  with  two  superstars  possessing  an</span><span>  insatiable  appetite  for  success.  Becker  says  he  is</span><span>  ready  to  lift  his  game  to  a  new  level.</span></p> <p><span>  \"Now  I  have  a  pretty  good  backhand  and  a</span><span>  better  volley.  But  it's  more  that  my  approach  has</span><span>  changed.  I'm  taking  it  more  seriously  than  before.\"</span></p> <p><span>  Since  losing  to  Stefan  Edberg  in  this  year's  Wim</span><span>  bledon  final  —  his  greatest  disappointment  in  1988</span><span>  —  Becker  has  been  beaten  onlj  twice.  From  April</span><span>  to  December,  Graf  lost  just  once.  \"But  we  both  like</span><span>  winning,\"  he  grins  as  if  in  explanation.</span></p> <p><span>  Though  Becker  made  his  mark  first,  it  is  Grafs</span></p> <p><span>  influence  which  is  perhaps  more  apparent.  A  re</span><span>  cent  survey  showed  that  German  girls  arc  as  eager</span><span>  to  play  like  her  as  Americans  are  to  follow  Chris</span><span>  Evert's  example.  As  not  one  Evert  clone  has  suc</span><span>  ceeded  since  Tracy  Austin  and  Andrea  Jaeger  \"re</span><span>  tired  hurt\"  this  could  mean  that  if  Evert  and</span><span>  Martina  Navratilova  choose  to  quit  —  which  may</span><span>  well  happen  during  the  next  two  years  —  European</span><span>  domination  of  the  women's  game  will  be  almost</span><span>  complete.  Graf,  who  hits  her  ground  strokes  with</span><span>  such  ferocity,  has  little  to  fear  from  the  game's</span><span>  base-liners  and  has  shown,  increasingly,  that  the</span><span>  forecourt  holds  no  terrors  for  her.</span></p> <p><span>  Becker,  who  raised  some  eyebrows  in  New  York</span><span>  recently  by  declaring  that  clay  was  his  favourite</span><span>  surface,  has  emerged  as  a  genuine  all-court  compet</span><span>  'itor  over  the  past  year  —  and  seems  more  deter</span><span>  mined  than  ever  to  match  Gottfried  von  Cramm,</span><span>  the  only  German  ever  to  win  the  French  title.</span></p> <p><span>  Von  Cramm  won  the  French  twice,  was  run</span><span>  ner-up  three  times  at  Wimbledon  and  once  at</span><span>  Forest  Hills,  and  was  twice  US  doubles  champion</span><span>  with  Henner  Henkel.  Few  doubt  Becker  can  im</span><span>  prove  on  that.  For  Graf  a  unique  second  successive</span><span>  Grand  Slam  in  1989  is  the  immediate  goal.</span></p> <p><span>  —  Guardian</span></p> "

 were  not</span><span>  unlike  those  faced  by  people</span><span>  escaping  from  other  parts  of</span><span>  war-time  Europe,  he  said.</span></p> <p><span>  Professor  Waller  was</span></p> <p><span>  speaking  at  the  launching  of</span><span>  a  book  “Community  of  Fate”</span><span>  by  Dr  John  Foster  in  B’nai</span></p> <p><span>  B’rith  House.</span></p> <p><span>  The  function  was  organised</span><span>  jointly  by  the  Victorian  B’nai</span><span>  B’rith  Council  and  the</span></p> <p><span>  publishers  Allen  and  Unwin</span></p> <p><span>  Australia.</span></p> <p><span>  The  book  contains  essays  by</span><span>  14  members  of  the  communi</span><span>  ty  who  fled  Germany  in  Wbrld</span><span>  War  II  and  settled  in</span><span>  Melbourne.</span></p> <p><span>  Professor  Whller  said  the</span></p> <p><span>  query  on  where  do  I  come</span><span>  from  is  a  Jewish  question.</span></p> <p><span>  “Those  in  the  book  know,</span><span>  and  knew,  from  whence  they</span></p> <p><span>  came.</span></p> <p><span>  “They  had  their  origins  in</span><span>  various  parts  of  Germany.</span></p> <p><span>  “Where  am  I  is  another</span></p> <p><span>  Jewish  question  and  this  too</span><span>  they  know.</span></p> <p><span>  “They  fled  to  what  to  all  in</span><span>  tents  and  purposes  is  the</span><span>  farthest  part  of  the  Jewish</span></p> <p><span>  world.</span></p> <p><span>  “Why  they  are  here  is</span><span>  something  that  is  less  known.</span></p> <p><span>  INFLUENCE</span></p> <p><span>  “One  tiling  is  sure  -</span><span>  Kristallnacht  had  its  effect</span><span>  and  that  is  why  people  are</span></p> <p><span>  here.</span></p> <p><span>  “In  many  of  the  chapters,</span><span>  there  is  a  feeling  of  how  un</span><span>  just  the  situation  was.                         "articleText": "<p><span>  yiwiH'i.'Miiw</span></p> <p><span>  German  Schwimmwagen</span></p> <p><span>  DURING  WW2  and  the</span><span>  period  leading  up  to  it</span><span>  Germany  produced  many</span><span>  deadly,  but  some  interest-</span></p> <p><span>  ing  weapons  and  vehi</span><span>  cles.</span><span>  Among  them  was  the</span><span>  Schwimmwagen.</span><span>  The  Schwimmwagen  ,  was  an</span><span>  amphibious  cousin  of  the</span><span>  Kuebelwagen,  pride  of  the  Wehr-</span><span>  macht  and  \"Rommel's  Raiders\".  ;</span><span>  The  Schwimmwagen  shared</span><span>  the  mechanicals  of  the  Kuebel</span><span>  wagen,  but  its  history  goes  back</span><span>  to  1932  when  a  German  indus-</span><span>  trialist,  Hans  Trippel,  unveiled  a</span><span>  prototype  ,  amphibious;  car  with</span><span>  four-wheel-drive  arid  .  a  four-  1</span><span>  cylinder  engine.</span><span>  Trippel's  amphibious  car  was</span><span>  meant  to  be  used  for  sporting</span><span>  interests  oply,  but  as  war  clouds</span><span>  .gathered,  it  was  .quickly  con</span><span>  verted  to  military  use.;.</span><span>  Trippel  took  over  the  Ettore</span><span>  Bugatti  plant  '  and  used  ;  and  evaluated  .in  field</span><span>  trials  in  1940,  a  second  genera</span><span>  tion'  was  put  into  production,</span><span>  consisting  of  a  Volkswagen  floor-  :</span><span>  pari  attached  to  a  flat-bottom  of.</span><span>  sheet  metal  capped  .  with  nose</span><span>  and  tail  fairings.</span><span>  ,  The  power  plant  was  a</span><span>  .  1  ,134  cc  flat-four,  an  increase  in  .</span><span>  size  over  the  Kuebels  ,  original</span><span>  985  cc.;</span><span>  ,  ;                         "snippet": "IF imitation is the sincerest flattery, then German vintners must feel very flattered in light of the increasing proliferation of 'German-style' wines.",
                        "troveUrl": "https://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article126878688?searchTerm=german+date%3A%5B1980-01-01T00%3A00%3A00Z+TO+1989-12-31T00%3A00%3A00Z%5D",
                        "tag": [],
                        "comment": [],
                        "articleText": "<p><span>  'German-style'  proliferation</span></p> <p><span>  By  BRENT  WHYTE*</span></p> <p><span>  If  imitation  is  the;sincerest  flattery,  then</span></p> <p><span>  German  vintners  must  feel  very  flattered  in  light</span><span>  of  the  increasing  proliferation  of'German-style'</span></p> <p><span>  wines.</span></p> <p><span>  The  first  'German-style'  wines  were  produced  well</span><span>  over  a  century  ago  by  German  emigrants  whose</span><span>  vinicuitural  traditions  and  skills  were  transplanted</span><span>  miles  away  from  the  Rhine  and  Mosel  valleys.</span></p> <p><span>  Even  today  wines  are  grown,  produced  and  bottled</span><span>  in  places  where  large  numbers  of  Germans  immi</span><span>  grated  —  such  as  North  and  South  America,  Aus</span><span>  tralia,  South  Africa  —  which  are  generically  called</span><span>  'Rhine'  or  'Mosel'  wines.  However,  these  new-world</span><span>  wines  which  are  named,  bottled  and/or  labelled  to</span><span>  resemble  German  wines  do  not  necessarily  have  any</span><span>  relation  to  any  emigrant  heritage.</span></p> <p><span>  These  are  often  produced  by  large  corporations</span><span>  which  have  implemented  the  recommendations  of</span><span>  marketing  research  departments  to  produce  and  pack</span><span>  age  an  imitation  of  a  quality  product  which  has</span><span>  already  achieved  public  acceptance.  Advertising  and</span><span>  promotional  campaigns  play  up  the  'German'  charac</span></p> <p><span>  ter  of  these  wines.</span></p> <p><span>  In  spite  of  their  old-world  appellations  these  'Ger</span><span>  man-style'  wines  are  usually  found  only  in  the  new</span><span>  world  countries  where  they  are  produced.</span></p> <p><span>  Another  breed  of  'German-style'  wine  has  recently</span><span>  emerged  which  is  distributed  worldwide.  Para</span><span>  doxically,  this  new  imitator  is  produced  right  at  home</span><span>  in  Germany  ...  paying  compliment  to  German  ex</span><span>  pertise,  in  vinicuitural  technology.  These  'German</span><span>  style'  wines  are  made  from  grapies  or  blends  of  wines</span><span>  from  different  EEC  countries  which  are  transported</span><span>  into  Germany  to  be  made  into  wine  or  blended,  then</span><span>  put  into  containers  (bottles,  casks  ,  or  tanks)  and</span></p> <p><span>  marketed.  Because  the  final  stage  of  production  takes</span><span>  place  in  Germany,  these  wines  may  be  labelled</span><span>  'Product  of  Germany'-—  even  though  the  wine  itself</span><span>  is  not  necessarily  of  German  origin.</span></p> <p><span>  ,  Often  these  table  wines  from  different  countries</span><span>  of  the  EEC  are  given  German-sounding  names  and</span><span>  German-looking  bottles  and  labels.  Add  to  this  the</span><span>  German  name  and  address  of  the  producer  or  bottler</span><span>  or  shipper  —  which  must  appear  on  the  label  —  and</span><span>  the  consumer  can  easily  mistake  one  of  these  'German</span><span>  style'  wines  for  an  authentic  German  wine.</span></p> <p><span>  There  is  an  easy  way  to  identify  an  authentic</span><span>  German  wine:  look  for  the  wine's  official  quality</span><span>  control  number,  the  'A.P.Nr',  on  the  label.</span></p> <p><span>  A  German  wine  bearing  an  'A.P.Nr.'  offers  the</span><span>  \"consumer  the  following  guarantee.</span></p> <p><span>  The  wine  is  100  per  cent  German  in  origin  and  the</span></p> <p><span>  name  of  a  designated  wine-growing  region  within</span><span>  Germany  —  or  the  umbrella  geographical  designa</span><span>  tion  \"Liebfraumilch\"  —  must  appear  on  the  label.</span><span>  And  the  wine  has  passed  a  three-stage  test,  beginning</span></p> <p><span>  with  Government  inspections  in  the  vineyards  at</span><span>  harvest  time,  followed  by  a  laboratory  analysis  of</span><span>  the  young  wine,  arid  ending  with  a  blind  sensory</span><span>  test  conducted  by  professional  wine  tasters  at</span><span>  Government  testing  stations.  The  final  two  digits</span><span>  of  the  'A.P.Nr.'  indicate  the  year  in  which  the  wine</span><span>  passed  the  test.</span></p> <p><span>  One  reason  that  more  'German-style'  wines  are</span><span>  appearing  in  supermarkets  and  wine  shops  around  the</span><span>  world,  often  displayed  in  the  midst  of  authentic</span><span>  German  wines,  is  that  the  supply  of  German  wines</span><span>  is  limited  by  natural  factors.</span></p> <p><span>  The  weather  greatly  influences  the  quantity  of</span><span>  wine  able  to  be  produced  each  year.  At  present,  supply</span></p> <p><span>  vwine</span></p> <p><span>  is  tight  due  to  the  1980  and  1981  harvests  which,  when</span><span>  combined,  equal  slightly  more  than  one  year's  average</span><span>  production.</span></p> <p><span>  Furthermore,  the  vineyards  on  the  slopes  along  the</span><span>  Rhine  and  Mosel  are  situated  between  riverbanks  and</span><span>  forested  hillsides,  and  thus  cannot  be  expanded.  As</span><span>  demand  for  German  wine  continues  to  increase  both</span><span>  at  home  and  abroad  some  distributors  are  trying  to</span><span>  meet  the  need  with  'German-style*  wines.</span></p> <p><span>  Even  the  best  imitation  cannot  substitute  for  the</span><span>  real  thing.  Authentic  German  wine  has  a  character</span></p> <p><span>  and  tradition  of  its  own.</span></p> <p><span>  Certain  elements  which  contribute  to  the  unique</span><span>  character  of  German  wine  can,  of  course,  be  suc</span><span>  cessfully  \"relocated\"  abroad:  grape  varieties,  techno</span><span>  logical  improvements,  even  winemakers.  But  other</span><span>  factors,  such  as  the  soil  and  climatic  conditions  where</span><span>  German  wines  grow,  will  always  remain  indigenous  to</span><span>  Germany.</span></p> <p><span>  This  is  why  a  German  Riesling  wine  has  a  bouquet</span><span>  and  taste  which  is  distinct  from  that  of  an  American</span><span>  or  Australian  Riesling  wine.  The  one  is  not  necessarily</span><span>  better  or  worse  than  the  other,  they  are  by  nature</span></p> <p><span>  different.</span></p> <p><span>  And  so  it  is  with  German  wine  and  'German-style'</span><span>  wine:  no  matter  how  much  alike  they  appear,  they  are</span><span>  by  nature  different.</span></p> <p><span>  *Mr  Whyte  is  the  manager,  German  Wine</span></p> <p><span>  Information  Service,  North  Sydney.</span></p> "

                        "articleText": "<p><span>  GERMAN  ARMS  TO  SAUDI?</span></p> <p><span>  JERUSALEM,  (JTA):  Deputy  foreign  minister  Yehuda  Ben  Meir  warned  of</span><span>  a  cloud  that  could  darken  Israeli-German  relations:  the  possibility  that  Bonn</span><span>  might  sell  advanced  weaponry  to  Saudi  Arabia  or  other  Arab  countries.</span></p> <p><span>  Delivering  a  key-note</span><span>  speech  on  the  opening  day  of</span><span>  the  annual  meeting  of  the</span><span>  Israel-Germany  Friendship</span><span>  Associations,  Ben-Meir  said</span><span>  Israel  could  not  agree  with</span><span>  nor  acquiesce  in  such  a</span><span>  prospect.</span></p> <p><span>  Israeli  sources  forecast  in</span><span>  tensified  diplomatic  action</span><span>  by  Jerusalem  in  the  weeks</span><span>  ahead  designed  to  forestall</span><span>  any  arms  sales.</span></p> <p><span>  Recently,  following</span><span>  Chancellor  Helmut  Kohl’s</span></p> <p><span>  visit  to  Saudi  Arabia,  Ger</span><span>  man  officials  sought  to</span><span>  distinguish  between  offensive</span><span>  weapons,  such  as  the</span><span>  Leopard  Two  tank,  and</span><span>  defensive  weapons  such  as</span><span>  anti-tank  devices  and  anti</span><span>  aircraft  systems.</span></p> <p><span>  But  Israel  has  declared</span><span>  firmly  that  it  recognises  no</span><span>  such  distinction. The  German  president</span><span>  offered  to  accompany  Herzog  because  of  the  great</span><span>  importance  he  attaches  to  the  visit,  which  he</span><span>  called  “an  extraordinary  event  in  the  relations</span><span>  between  the  two  countries  and  the  two  peoples.”</span></p> <p><span>  Von  Weiszaecker  also  said  that  his  visit  to  Israel</span></p> <p><span>  in  1985  and  Herzog’s  visit  to  Germany  were  just</span></p> <p><span>  two  events  in  the  development  of  bilateral  rela</span><span>  tions.                         "snippet": "Thomas Keneally’s novel brings back memories to hundreds of Jewish Holocaust survivors of the man who became the greatest figure in their",
                        "troveUrl": "https://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article261323922?searchTerm=german+date%3A%5B1980-01-01T00%3A00%3A00Z+TO+1989-12-31T00%3A00%3A00Z%5D",
                        "tag": [],

                        "articleText": "<p><span>  Book  Review</span></p> <p><span>  Righteous  German</span></p> <p><span>  TERENCE  PR1TTIE</span></p> <p><span>  Schindler’s  Ark.  By  Thomas</span><span>  Kepeally.  Hodder  &  Stoughton.</span></p> <p><span>  Thomas  Keneally’s  novel  brings</span><span>  back  memories  to  hundreds  of  Jewish</span><span>  Holocaust  survivors  of  the  man  who</span><span>  became  the  greatest  figure  in  their</span></p> <p><span>  lives,  i</span></p> <p><span>  In  Jerusalem’s  Yad  Vashem  a</span><span>  handful  of  the  elect  have  been</span><span>  honoured  by  trees  planted  in  memory</span><span>  of  “Righteous  Gentiles”  —  men  and</span><span>  women  who  risked  their  lives  to  save</span><span>  those  of  Jews  in  the  black  days  of  Nazi</span><span>  persecution.  High  among  these  is  the</span><span>  name  of  Oskar  Schindler,  a  Sudeten</span><span>  Gentian  who  against  all  SS  pressure</span><span>  insisted  on  employing  Jews  in  his  war</span><span>  time  factories  near  Cracow  in  Poland,</span><span>  Jews  who  were  never  beaten  or  killed</span><span>  and  whom  he  treated  with  respect  and</span><span>  even  affection  —  those  with  whom  he</span><span>  had  most  contact  were  referred  to  as</span><span>  “Schindler’s  Children”  and  many  of</span><span>  them  remained  in  close  contact  with</span><span>  him  up  to  the  time  of  his  death,  in</span><span>  October  1974.  At  a  rough  estimate  he</span><span>  helped  to  save  the  lives  of  about  1200</span><span>  Jews.</span></p> <p><span>  This  he  did  not  only  by  treating</span><span>  them  well  and  feeding  them  in  a  way</span><span>  which  would  have  been  deemed</span><span>  lucullan  by  the  inmates  of</span><span>  concentration-camps,  but  by  using  his</span><span>  personal  good  relations  with  the  SS  to</span><span>  prevent  their  deportation  to  such</span><span>  places  of  horror.  When  some  of  the</span><span>  women  from  his  Brinnlitz  factory  were</span><span>  removed  to  Auschwitz,  he  followed</span><span>  them  there  and  argued  stoutly  and</span><span>  stubbornly  for  their  return  to  his  care.</span><span>  His  case  was  that  they  were  all  skilled</span><span>  workers  —  his  factories  produced</span><span>  mainly  enamel  ware  but  munitions  too</span><span>  —  and  that  their  departure  had</span><span>  disrupted  production.  Keneally  tells</span><span>  the  almost  unbelievable  story  how</span><span>  Schindler  won  his  case,  and  how  the</span><span>  SS  authorities  at  Auschwitz,  even</span><span>  while  busy  with  their  extermination,</span><span>  returned  all  “his  Jews”  to  him,  and  to</span><span>  safety.</span></p> <p><span>  This  was  a  typical  instance  of  Oskar</span><span>  Schindler’s  “chutzpa.”  He  was  no</span><span>  intellectual.  He  was,  intriguingly,  a</span><span>  man  of  few  principles;  he  drank  a  great</span><span>  deal,  he  was  habitually  unfaithful  to</span><span>  his  wife  and  unashamedly</span><span>  promiscuous,  he  had  not  the  slightest</span><span>  hesitation  in  using  the  black  market</span><span>  and  bribing  whenever  expedient  —  to</span><span>  gain  the  concession  of  safeguarding</span><span>  ‘‘his  Jews”  from  the  SS,  he  used  an</span><span>  interesting  admixture  of  .diamonds,</span><span>  alcohol  and  ham.  But  he  had  what  the</span><span>  Nazis  would  have  considered  a</span><span>  shocking  “weakness”  —  for  Jews.  By</span><span>  presenting  the  story  as  a  novel,</span><span>  Keneally  tries  to  show  how  something</span><span>  ,deep  within  Schindler,  some</span><span>  unexplained  instinct,  prompted  his</span><span>  determination  to  succour  and  defend</span><span>  the  Jews  in  his  care.</span></p> <p><span>  He  met  no  heroic  end,  dying  of</span><span>  hardening  of  the  arteries  which  may</span><span>  well  have  been  brought  on  by  his</span><span>  drinking  habits.  He  was  none  the  less  a</span><span>  “Righteous  Gentile”  for  all  that  —  if</span><span>  only  because,  with  the  end  of  the  war</span><span>  in  sight,  he  made  a  birthday-speech</span><span>  in  front  of  members  of  the  dreaded  SS,</span></p> <p><span>  promising  that  he  would  stick  the  war  \\</span></p> <p><span>  out  until  “his  Jews”  were  safe  and  i</span><span>  free.  He  was  37,  and  risking  the  whole</span></p> <p><span>  second  half  of  his  life.  His  life,  both  l</span><span>  before  and  after  the  war,  was  that  of  a</span></p> <p><span>  drinker  and  businessman  and  totally  /  j</span></p> <p><span>  unmemorable  and  after  the  war  he  had  i</span><span>  to  be  helped  repeatedly  by  survivors</span></p> <p><span>  among  “his  Jews.”  Yet  he  was  one  of  j</span></p> <p><span>  that  small  band  of  Germans  who  ?</span><span>  needed  a  recognisable  challenge  to  his</span><span>  true  morality,  and  who  rose  to  the</span><span>  occasion.</span></p> <p><span>  Keneally’s  novel  has  just  won  the  !</span><span>  Booker  Prize,  Britain’s  premier  i</span><span>  literary  award,  and  deservedly  so.</span><span>  After  talking  to  many  surviving</span></p> <p><span>  “Schindler  Jews”  about  their  ]</span><span>  memories,  he  has  presented  his  story  j</span><span>  as  “faction”  —  a  detailed,</span></p> <p><span>  documented  true  story  presented  and  .  *</span><span>  built  up  as  fiction  —  but  he  draws  a  *</span><span>  convincing  picture  which  lingers  in  the  1</span><span>  mind  of  the  total  Jewish  nightmare  of  1</span><span>  the  Holocaust  and  of  one  ordinary  |</span></p> <p><span>  German’s  stand  against  it.</span></p> "

com</span></p> <p><span>  mercial  concerns  are  being  actively</span><span>  encouraged  to  use  the  Philippines  as</span><span>  a  base  for  computer  software  development</span><span>  activities.</span></p> <p><span>  The  call  came  from  Dr  Victor  Sandoval,  president</span><span>  of  Nixdorf  Computer  Philippines  Inc.,  during  an  ad</span><span>  dress  in  Bonn  to  members  of  West  Germany's  presti</span><span>  gious  Deutsche'  Industrie  und  Handelskammer</span><span>  (DIHT)  —  the  West  German  Chamber  of  Commerce.</span></p> <p><span>  Dr  Sandoval  was  a  member  of  a  high-powered  Fili</span><span>  pino  investment  promotion  group,  headed  by  Philip</span><span>  pines  president  Corazon  Aquino,  which  recently</span><span>  toured  West  Germany,  France  and  Belgium.</span></p> <p><span>  Dr  Sandoval  told  DIHT  members  that  with  1992</span><span>  approaching,  Europeans  will  have  to  think  of  the  'glob</span><span>  alisation  of  end-user  markets  as  well  as  production</span></p> <p><span>  resources.'</span></p> <p><span>  A  single,  unique  characteristic  of  computer  software</span><span>  —  the  fact  that  it  is  perfectly  transportable  and  can  be</span><span>  shipped  over  telephone  lines  at  extremely  high  speeds</span><span>  —  made  this  globalisation  unavoidable.</span></p> <p><span>  \"The  location  of  the  end-user  market  relative  to  the</span><span>  location  of  the  production  plant  becomes  immaterial,\"</span><span>  said  Dr  Sandoval.</span></p> <p><span>  \"The  software  producer  can  thus  set  up  a  plant</span><span>  where  production  facilities  and  input  resources  are</span><span>  optimal,  and  still  be  in  a  position  to  market  the  pro</span></p> <p><span>  duct  world-wide.</span></p> <p><span>  \"In  the  information  technology  field,  generally,</span><span>  hardware  costs  are  decreasing  and  software  costs  are</span><span>  climbing;  Germany  is  no  exception,\"  Dr  Sandoval</span></p> <p><span>  said.</span></p> <p><span>  In  Germany,  the  services  of  software  professionals</span><span>  are  not  only  expensive,  they  are  difficult  to  recruit.</span></p> <p><span>  Viewed  from  this  standpoint,  according  to  Dr  San</span><span>  doval,  the  Philippines  is  one  of  the  most  attractive</span><span>  countries  in  the  world  for  software  production,  for  a</span><span>  variety  of  reasons:</span></p> <p><span>  •  The  Philippines  offers  a  large  pool  of  easily</span><span>  trainable  staff;  from  a  population  of  60  million,  a</span><span>  company  can  be  very  selective  in  recruitment.</span></p> <p><span>  •  Englishes  universally  spoken.</span></p> <p><span>  •  Salaries  in  the  computer  sector  are  at  about  80  per</span><span>  cent  of  corresponding  salary  levels  in  Germany.</span></p> <p><span>  •  In  general,  operating  costs  in  the  Philippines  are</span><span>  lower  than  in  other  countries  around  the  region.</span></p> <p><span>  •  The  Philippines  boasts  an  adequate  network  of</span><span>  data-quality  transmission  links  to  all  major  centres  of</span></p> <p><span>  the  world.</span></p> <p><span>  Dr  Sandoval  said  that  typically,  software  activities</span><span>  in  the  Philippines  covera  wide  spectrum,  including  the</span><span>  coding  of  program  routines,  the  testing  of  programs,</span><span>  the  development  of  application  software  packages,  and</span><span>  the  conversion  of.programs  to  suit  new  conditions.</span></p> <p><span>  He  said  that  while products  meet  the  special  requirements  of  its</span><span>  Asian  customers,\"  said  Dr  Sandoval.</span></p> "

                        "articleText": "<p><span>  GERMAN  JEWS</span></p> <p><span>  WITH  THE  recent  publication  of  Volume</span><span>  1  of  German-Jewish  History  in  Modern</span><span>  Times  ,  a  four-volume  series  has  been</span><span>  launched  to  detail  the  history  of  the  Jews</span><span>  in  German-speaking  countries  from  the</span><span>  first  Jewish  settlements  in  the  Middle</span><span>  Ages  to  the  Holocaust.</span></p> <p><span>  Sub-titled  Tradition  and</span></p> <p><span>  Enlightenment:  1600-1780  (Columbia</span><span>  University  Press,  435pp,  US$50.00),  and</span><span>  edited  by  Professor  Michael  Meyer  of</span><span>  Hebrew  Union  College,  this  first  volume</span><span>  focuses  on  the  Jewish  world  in  Central</span></p> <p><span>  Europe  from  the  beginning  of  the  so</span><span>  called  modern  period  to  the  advent  of  the</span><span>  prolonged  struggle  for  Jewish  emancipa</span></p> <p><span>  tion.</span></p> <p><span>  T^s  a  project  of  the  Leo  Baeck</span></p> <p><span>  Institute,  the  series  aims  to  advance</span><span>  scholarship  of  the  Jews  in  German</span><span>  speaking  lands.                         "articleText": "<p><span>  German  industry</span></p> <p><span>  I  am  bedazzled  at  you.  You  who  drive  BMWs</span><span>  and  Volkswagens,  you  who  use  Siemens  equip</span><span>  ment,  you  who  fly  Lufthansa,  you  who  use</span><span>  Hugo  Boss  and  who  listen  to  BASF  tapes.</span></p> <p><span>  Are  you  not  the  very  same  people  who</span><span>  were  repelled  by  the  conduct  of  German</span><span>  industry  portrayed  in  black  and  white  in</span><span>  Schindler’s  List? Presently  there  is  a  class  action  under</span><span>  way  against  numerous  German  companies,</span></p> <p><span>  the  total  assets  of  which  amount  to  well  above</span></p> <p><span>  US  $630  billion.  That  is  the  approximate  sum</span><span>  of  the  empires,  whose  foundations  were  built</span><span>  at  gun  point  and  built  by  Jewish  and  non</span></p> <p><span>  Jewish  slave  and  forced  labourers.</span></p> <p><span>  Yet  you  endorse  their  products. The  larger  of  these  figures  is  com</span><span>  parable  to  two  years  on  the  dole.</span></p> <p><span>  For  up  to  six  years  of  barbarities  that  nei</span><span>  ther  you  nor  I  have  the  right  even  to  attempt</span></p> <p><span>  to  describe.</span></p> <p><span>  The  vast  majority  of  these  assaulted  human</span><span>  beings  are  in  their  late  70s.                         "articleText": "<p><span>  German  crimes  trial</span></p> <p><span>  ACCUSED  Nazi  war  criminal  Jo-t</span><span>  sef  Schwammberger  was  indicted</span><span>  last  month  in  court  at  Stuttgart,</span></p> <p><span>  West  Germany,  on  charges  of,</span><span>  murdering  “at  least  50  Jews”  dur</span><span>  ing  World  War  II.  He  also  was</span><span>  charged  as  an  accessory  to  the</span><span>  murder  of  at  least  3,377  other  peo</span><span>  ple,  according  to  the  World  Jew</span><span>  ish  Congress,  which  learned  of  the</span><span>  indictment  from  the  Jewish  com</span><span>  munity  of  West  Berlin.  Schwamm</span><span>  berger  admitted  to  ordering  the</span><span>  execution  of  one  person  under</span><span>  “special  circumstances,”  but  other</span><span>  than  that,  “he  has  completely  de</span><span>  nied  his  crimes,”  according  to  Hel</span><span>  mut  Kronbacher,  spokesman  for</span><span>  the  prosecutor’s  office.</span></p> <p><span>  Schwammberger,  78,  who  is  be</span><span>  ing  held  at  the  Stammheim  maxi</span><span>  mum  security  prison,  was</span><span>  extradited  from  Argentina  in  May,</span><span>  after  a  long  proceeding  that  in</span><span>  cluded  his  hospitalisation  in  an  Ar</span><span>  gentine  hospital  for  a  mysterious</span><span>  coma.  The  Stuttgart  court  found</span><span>  him  fit  to  stand  trial.  The</span><span>  prosecutor’s  office  said  the  trial</span><span>  would  probably  begin  early  next</span><span>  year.  That  would  likely  make</span><span>  Schwammberger  the  first  alleged</span><span>  Nazi  war  criminal  to  be  tried  in  a</span><span>  unified  Germany.  A  guilty  verdict</span><span>  would  bring  a  life  sentence.</span></p> <p><span>  A  former  lieutenant  in  the  Waf</span><span>  fen  SS  and  commandant  of  several</span><span>  concentration  camps  in  Poland,</span><span>  Schwammberger  allegedly  was</span><span>  known  for  his  particularly  cruel</span><span>  killings  of  Jews.  He  has  been  ac</span><span>  cused  by  survivors  of  camps  of</span><span>  Jewish  areas  in  the  Polish  towns  of</span><span>  Przemysl,  Mielec,  Rozwadow  and</span><span>  Stalowa-Wola  of  smashing</span></p> <p><span>  children’s  heads  against  walls,</span><span>  throwing  people  alive  into  fires</span><span>  and  shooting  people  point-blank.</span><span>  Witnesses  said  they  saw</span><span>  Schwammberger  use  pliers  to  re</span><span>  move  gold  teeth  from  prisoners.</span><span>  He  was  known  as  the  “butcher  of</span><span>  Rozwadow.”</span></p> <p><span>  After  the  war,  Schwammberger</span><span>  was  arrested  in  Austria  with  bags</span><span>  of  jewellery  stolen  from  Jews,</span><span>  which  he  admitted  under  question</span><span>  ing.  He  escaped,  probably  in  1948,</span><span>  to  Argentina  with  what  is  believed</span><span>  to  have  been  help  from  Odessa,  a</span><span>  Nazi  fugitive  network.  Before</span><span>  escaping  detention  in  1945,</span><span>  Schwammberger,  an  Austrian  by</span><span>  birth,  admitted  having  shot  about</span><span>  35  Jews,  according  to  the  Austrian</span><span>  police.  The  Austrian  police  files</span><span>  were  obtained  by  the  Anti</span><span>  Defamation  League  of  B’nai</span></p> <p><span>  B’rith.</span></p> <p><span>  The  indictment  in  Stuttgart</span><span>  stems  from  a  warrant  for</span><span>  Schwammberger’s  arrest  that  West</span><span>  Germany  issued  in  1972.  Addi</span><span>  tional  charges  against  him  were</span><span>  made  in  recent  years.  The  Wiesen</span><span>  thal  Centre  expects  to  play  a  strong</span><span>  role  at  the  trial,  having  represen</span><span>  tatives  present  and  bringing  new</span><span>  witnesses  to  testify,  “including</span><span>  some  whom  we  recently  found  and</span><span>  others  who  were  frightened  of  go</span><span>  ing  on  their  own,”  Rabbi  Marvin</span><span>  Hier  of  the  Los  Angeles-based</span><span>  Simon  Wiesenthal  Centre  said.</span></p> <p><span>  “At  this  trial,  there  will  be  more</span><span>  witnesses  to  testify  against  Josef</span><span>  Schwammberger  than  there  was  at</span><span>  any  Nazi  war  criminal  trial  of  re</span><span>  cent  memory,  including  Adolf</span><span>  Eichmann,”  he  said.</span></p> <p><span>  (Jewish  lelegraphic  Agency)</span></p> "

The  acti</span><span>  vists  feel  that  perhaps  some  5,000</span><span>  Jews  in  Germany  go  uncounted  be</span><span>  cause  of  failure  to  register  as  such.</span></p> <p><span>  The  German  government  col</span><span>  lects  taxes  for  recognised  religious</span><span>  communities.  The  authorities</span><span>  transfer  to  the  churches  10  percent</span><span>  of  the  income  tax  revenues  col</span><span>  lected  from  the  churches’  mem</span><span>  bers.                         "snippet": "GEOFF page's recent A Reader's Guide to Contemporary Australian Poetry discusses the work of 100 contemporary poets,",
                        "troveUrl": "https://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article127277985?searchTerm=german+date%3A%5B1990-01-01T00%3A00%3A00Z+TO+1999-12-31T00%3A00%3A00Z%5D",

                            {
                                "lastupdated": "2017-07-04T04:43:22Z",
                                "value": "Fay Zwicky (nee Rosefield) (1933-2017) - Poet"

                            {
                                "lastupdated": "2013-11-09T05:54:54Z",
                                "value": "Geoff Page"

                                "lastupdated": "2013-11-09T06:00:30Z",
                                "value": "Rosemary Dobson"

                        ],
                        "comment": [],
                        "articleText": "<p><span>  Australian-German  links</span></p> <p><span>  MADE  IN  AUSTRALIA.  Australian  Poet-</span></p> <p><span>  ry  Today.  Gegenwartsdichtung  Austral-</span></p> <p><span>  ians.  The  OZIit  Collection  Vol  3.  Bilin-</span><span>  gual.  Edited  by  Cisela  Triesch  and  Rudi</span><span>  Krausmann.  Cangan  Books  Australia.</span><span>  317pp.  $29.95.</span></p> <p><span>  Reviewer:  RALPH  ELLIOTT.</span></p> <p><span>  Geoff  PAGE's  recent  A  Read-</span></p> <p><span>  er's  Guide  to  Contemporary</span><span>  Australian  Poetry  discusses</span><span>  the  work  of  100  contemporary  poets,</span></p> <p><span>  neatly  arranged  alphabetically  from</span><span>  Robert  Adamson  to  Fay  Zwicky.  For</span><span>  good  measure,  the  book  concludes</span><span>  with  a  list  of  100  other  poets  sug-</span><span>  gested  as  no  less  worthy  of  the  read-</span><span>  er's  attention,  and  I  can  think  of</span><span>  other  poets  who  deserve  a  place  in</span><span>  either  list,  like  Canberra's  Michael</span><span>  Thwaites  and  Geoff  Page  himself,</span><span>  who  modestly  excluded  himself,  but</span><span>  who  does  Figure  in  Made  In  Austra-</span></p> <p><span>  lia.</span></p> <p><span>  That  Gisela  Triesch's  and  Rudi</span><span>  Krausmann's  bilingual  anthology  is</span><span>  restricted  to  a  mere  80  poets  is  due</span><span>  to  each  poem  being  faced  by  a  trans-</span><span>  lation  into  German.  Forty-six  of</span><span>  these  poets  also  figure  in  Page's</span><span>  Guide,  and  there  is  more  than  coinci-</span><span>  dental,  at  times  verbal,  similarity  be-</span><span>  tween  Page's  lengthy  introduction  to</span><span>  contemporary  Australian  poetry  and</span><span>  Volker  Wolfs  German  introduction</span><span>  to  the  bilingual  anthology.  Who  is</span><span>  echoing  whom  is  not  for  me  to  spec-</span></p> <p><span>  ulate.</span></p> <p><span>  Wolf  is  one  of  the  group  of  transla-</span><span>  tors  which  also  includes  the  two  edi-</span><span>  tors,  charged  with  the  gargantuan</span><span>  task  of  rendering  into  German  verse</span><span>  the  enormous  variety  of  language</span><span>  and  styles  represented  in  poems  as</span><span>  diverse  as  Les  Murray's  \"The  people</span><span>  are  eating  dinner  in  that  country</span><span>  north  of  Legge's  Lake\"  and  Ania</span><span>  Walwicz's  performance  poems  (i.e.</span><span>  poetic  prose  pieces)  \"Australia\"  and</span></p> <p><span>  \"The  Tattoo\".</span></p> <p><span>  Inevitably,  the  translations  vary</span><span>  considerably.  Where  Australian  poets</span><span>  use  rhyme,  like  Rosemary  Dobson,</span><span>  Chris  Wallace-Crabbe,  and  Eva  John-</span><span>  son,  this  is  ignored  by  the  transla-</span><span>  tors,  and  the  distinctive  cadences  of</span></p> <p><span>  individual  poems  are  often  lost,  espe-</span><span>  cially  where  short  English  words  are</span><span>  rendered  by  lengthy  German  nouns</span><span>  or  verbs,  an  extreme  example  being</span><span>  Bruce  Dawe's  \"like  a  traffic-report</span><span>  helicopter  over  the  bankup\"  which</span><span>  becomes  the  monstrous  \"wie  ein  Ver-</span><span>  kehrsueberwachungshubschrauber</span><span>  ueber  dem  Stau\".  Jack  Davis's  rhyth-</span><span>  mic,  melodic  \"We  welcome  the  sun</span><span>  down  that  heralds  the  dark\"  explodes</span><span>  into  the  prosy  \"Wir  begruessen  den</span><span>  Sonnenuntergang,  der  die  Dunkelheit</span><span>  ankuendigt\".</span></p> <p><span>  Occasionally  one  wonders  whether</span><span>  the  translators  really  caught  the  po-</span><span>  et's  meaning.  In  Geoff  Page's  \"Small</span><span>  town  Memorials\"  the  final  four  lines</span><span>  appear  to  me  to  refer  to  the  two</span><span>  world  wars  in  reverse  order:  \"The</span><span>  next  bequeathed  us/Parks  and</span><span>  pools/But  something  in  that  first/De-</span><span>  manded  stone.\"  The  translation  turns</span><span>  both  \"next\"  and  \"first\"  into  plural</span><span>  nouns,  which  does  not  make  much</span><span>  sense.  In  Judith  Beveridge's  \"In  the</span><span>  Park\"  the  line  \"of  the  moon  adrift\"</span><span>  becomes  \"des  Mondes,  der  fei\",</span><span>  which  I  assume  is  a  misprint  for</span><span>  \"frei\".  And  are  Laurie  Duggan's</span><span>  \"Qantas  Bags\"  really  \"Tueten\"  in</span><span>  German,  a  word  which  connotes  ice</span><span>  cream  cones  and  even  breathalyzers</span><span>  rather  than  cabbin  baggage?</span></p> <p><span>  Admittedly,  these  are  trifling  cav-</span><span>  ils  in  a  book  well  furnished  with</span><span>  good  German  translations,  and  they</span></p> <p><span>  are  unlikely  to  detract  from  the  en-</span><span>  joyment  which  Austrian  or  German</span><span>  or  Swiss  readers  will  derive  from  the</span><span>  poems  in  this  excellent  anthology.</span><span>  Moreover,  considering  the  steady  in-</span><span>  flux  of  English  words  into  contempo-</span><span>  rary  German,  of  which  visitors  to</span><span>  German-speaking  countries  or  view-</span><span>  ers  of  Derrick  must  be  very  con-</span><span>  scious,  it  seems  quite  proper  that</span><span>  Jennifer  Strauss's  \"sand  and  sex\"</span><span>  should  appear  as  \"Sand  und  Sex\"  or</span><span>  that  Robert  Harris's  \"junkies\"  should</span><span>  appear  as  \"die  Junkies\"  in  Rudi</span><span>  Krausmann's  translation.  Even  the</span><span>  retention  of  \"possum\"  in  the  German</span><span>  text  of  some  poems  seems  appropri-</span><span>  ate,  although  in  another  poem  the</span><span>  word  is  rendered  by  the  German</span></p> <p><span>  word  \"Beutelratten\".</span></p> <p><span>  Most  of  the  translations  do  justice</span><span>  to  the  original  Australian  poems.  In</span><span>  a  few  instances  they  seem  almost  an</span><span>  improvement  on  the  originals,  which</span><span>  is  not  unknown  in  the  history  of  po-</span><span>  etic  translations.  Nancy  Cato's  \"The</span><span>  Dead  Swagman\"  reads  very  well  in</span><span>  the  German  version,  where  the  pen</span><span>  ultimate  line  \"die  Wurzeln  und  Kno-</span><span>  chen  beruehren  sich  auf  dem  Boden\"</span><span>  suggests  an  even  closer  intimacy  of</span><span>  the  dead  man  and  the  tree  than  the</span><span>  original.  Other  renderings  which</span><span>  have  struck  me  as  particularly  felici-</span><span>  tous  are  Krausmann's  translations  of</span><span>  Kate  Llewellyn's  \"Finished\"  and  the</span><span>  German  version  by  Krausmann  and</span><span>  Gerald  Ganglbauer  of  Richard  Tip-</span><span>  ping's  \"Mangoes\".  The  German  writ-</span><span>  er  Hans  Magnus  Enzensberger  trans-</span><span>  lated  (except  for  one  stanza)  the</span><span>  longest  poem  in  the  book,  John  Tran-</span><span>  ter's  \"The  False  Atlas\";  it  is  a  re-</span><span>  markably  close  yet  wholly  idiomatic</span><span>  German  rendering.</span></p> <p><span>  As  Gisela  Triesch  points  out  in</span><span>  her  postscript,  almost  half  the  poets</span><span>  here  represented  are  women,  and</span></p> <p><span>  there  is  a  fair  selection  of  Aboriginal</span><span>  and  ethnic  writers.  They  all  rightly</span><span>  belong  in  an  anthology  of  \"Austra-</span><span>  lian  Poetry  Today\",  and  the  themes</span><span>  which  many  of  their  poems  address,</span><span>  like  Eva  Johnson's  \"Right  To  Be\",</span><span>  Hyllus  Maris's  \"Spiritual  Song  of  the</span><span>  Aborigine\",  or  Marita  Kefala's  \"They</span><span>  Are  Still  Coming\",  continue  to  be</span><span>  highly  topical  in  Australia  today.</span></p> <p><span>  The  arrangement  of  the  poets  in</span><span>  Made  in  Australia  is  by  date  of  birth,</span><span>  beginning  with  Margaret  \"Diesendorf,</span><span>  who  was  born  in  1912  and  died  two</span><span>  years  ago,  and  leading  up  to  poets</span><span>  born  in  1960.  Obviously,  editorial</span><span>  preference  and  available  space  deter-</span><span>  mined  inclusions  and  omissions,  but</span><span>  few  readers  will  dispute  that  it  is  a</span><span>  well-balanced,  carefully  selected  an-</span><span>  thology.  The  inclusion,  as  the  last</span><span>  poem,  of  Maureen  Watson's  \"Step-</span><span>  ping  Out\"  with  its  final  \"I  don't</span><span>  walk,  I  strut,/\"Cause  now,  I'm  liber-</span><span>  ated\"  provides  a  very  moving  end-</span><span>  ing.  There  are  no  dates  alongside  her</span></p> <p><span>  name.</span></p> <p><span>  The  only  thing  I  miss  in  this</span><span>  otherwise  highly  commendable  book</span><span>  are  brief  biographical  notes,  such  as</span><span>  Geoff  Page  provides  in  his  Guide.</span><span>  Australian  readers  can  turn  to  the</span><span>  recent  second  edition  of  The  Oxford</span><span>  Companion  to  Australian  Literature,</span><span>  but  others?  However,  it  is  the  poems</span><span>  themselves  that  matter,  and  there  is</span><span>  God's  Plenty  in  Made  in  Australia,  a</span><span>  book  of  which  lovers  of  poetry  may</span><span>  well  feel  proud.</span></p> <p><span>  Made  in  Australia:  Australian  Poetry  To-</span><span>  day  will  be  launched  al  Tilley's,  Lyne-</span><span>  ham,  on  Tuesday  at  8pm,  by  Dr  Anna</span><span>  Jankovic,  First  Secretary,  Embassy  of</span><span>  Austria.  At  the  launch  there  will  be  read-</span><span>  ings  by  Rosemary  Dobson,  Alan  Gould,</span><span>  Rudi  Krausmann,  and  Geoff  Page.  In-</span><span>  quiries:  249  7068.</span></p> "

                        "list": [],
                        "id": "261621720",
                        "url": "https://api.trove.nla.gov.au/v3/newspaper/261621720",
                        "heading": "feature German antisemitism",
                        "category": "Article",
                        "title": {
                            "id": "1695",
                            "title": "The Australian Jewish News (Sydney, NSW : 1990 - 2008)"
                        },
                        "date": "1996-06-21",
                        "page": "24",
                        "pageSequence": "24",
                        "relevance": {
                            "score": 122.65967559814453,
                            "value": "very relevant"
                        },
                        "snippet": "I THOUGHT we were finally done with the “Hitler-arrived-h om-outer-space-in1933” explanation of German anti-semitism. Yet Professor Bill Rubinstein,",
                        "troveUrl": "https://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article261621720?searchTerm=german+date%3A%5B1990-01-01T00%3A00%3A00Z+TO+1999-12-31T00%3A00%3A00Z%5D",
                        "tag": [],
                        "comment": [],
                        "articleText": "<p><span>  ^feciture/</span></p> <p><span>  German  antisemitism</span></p> <p><span>  Colin  Tatz</span></p> <p><span>  1  THOUGHT  we  were  finally  done  with</span></p> <p><span>  the  “Hitler-arrived-h  om-outer-space-in</span><span>  1933”  explanation  of  German  anti</span><span>  semitism.  Yet  Professor  Bill  Rubinstein,</span><span>  reviewing  Daniel  Goldhagen’s  Hitler’s  Will</span><span>  ing  Executioners  (AJN  31/5/96),  revisits  this</span><span>  mischief.  Perhaps  not  mischief  —  rather,</span><span>  some  appallingly  bad  history.</span></p> <p><span>  It  is  “simply  wrong\",  he  declares,  to  say</span><span>  “that  Germany  was  pervasively  antisemitic</span><span>  before  Hitler  came  to  power”.  There  was  a</span><span>  “golden  age  of  Jewish  achievement”,  typi</span><span>  fied  by  Berlin  giving  Einstein  “a  princely</span><span>  official  residence”  in  1930.  Jews,  he  con</span><span>  tends,  were  “universally  accepted  in</span><span>  Weimar  Germany”;  most  had  good,  “even</span><span>  excellent  relations  with  their  Gentile  neigh</span><span>  bours  until  1938”  —  in  fact,  he  writes,  most</span><span>  didn’t  perceive  Germany  as  “murderously</span><span>  anti-Jewish  even  after  1933”  and  “most  Ger</span><span>  mans  remained  where  they  were  until  after</span><span>  Kristallnacht”.</span></p> <p><span>  In  so  saying,  Rubinstein  deplores  the</span><span>  “ahistoricity  which  bedevils  so  many  works</span></p> <p><span>  on  the  Holocaust\".</span></p> <p><span>  My  concern  is  with  his  unhistoriCity.</span><span>  What  can  and  should  be  said  about  the</span><span>  position  of  German  Jews  from  the  end  of</span><span>  the  19th  century  until  1933  in  the  cultural,</span><span>  political,  academic,  scientific,  social  and</span><span>  even  sporting  fields?</span></p> <p><span>  Modern  German  antisemitism  began  with</span><span>  the  peasant  riots  of  1819.  And  while  there</span><span>  are  different  antisemitisms,  much  of  the</span><span>  content  forms  a  continuity.  From  the  mid</span><span>  dle  of  the  last  century,  the  Jew  was  depict</span><span>  ed  in  literature  as  being  without  soul,  with</span><span>  out  the  traditional  humble  German  virtues,</span><span>  uprooted,  troublesome,  malevolent,  shift</span><span>  less.  Much  of  the  literature  followed  Gus</span><span>  tav  Freytag’s  character  Veitel  Itzig,  who  was</span><span>  ugly,  grasping,  without  a  shred  of  humani</span><span>  ty.  Hermann  Godsche’s  novels  revealed  the</span><span>  Jews  as  conspirators  against  the  Gentile</span></p> <p><span>  world.</span></p> <p><span>  Wilhelm  Marr,  who  coined  the  word</span><span>  “Antisemitism”  and  founded  the  Antisemite</span><span>  League  in  1879,  placed  much  store  in  these</span><span>  literary  pieces.  His  “Semitism”  was  invent</span><span>  ed  to  distinguish  between  German  and  Jew,</span><span>  not  between  Christian  and  Jew.  Through</span><span>  his  works  and  those  of  Eugen  Duhring  and</span><span>  Heinrich  von  Treitschke,  the  stereotype  of</span><span>  the  dangerous  Jew  was  integrated  into  the</span><span>  dynamics  of  the  Volkisch  struggle  against  a</span><span>  state  that  didn’t  represent,  for  them,  the</span><span>  true  will  of  the  German  Volk.</span></p> <p><span>  As  early  as  1895,  Hermann  Ahlwardt</span><span>  introduced  a  Reichstag  Bill  to  close  Ger</span><span>  many’s  borders  to  “Israelites  who  are  not</span><span>  citizens  of  the  Reich”.  Teutons  wanted  no</span><span>  more  Jews,  people  of  a  different  race  and</span><span>  culture,  people  who  would,  as  cholera  bacil</span><span>  li,  cause  the  death  of  Germans.  Mixing  the</span><span>  metaphor,  he  saw  them  as  beasts  of  prey</span><span>  who  had  best  be  exterminated.  But  tramps,</span><span>  beggars  and  social  nuisances  were  differ</span><span>  ent:  they  were  “Germans  like  us\"  —  some</span><span>  thing  the  Jew  could  never  be.  The  Bill  was</span><span>  defeated  by  167  to  51  in  favour  —  but  suc</span><span>  ceeded  in  1906.</span></p> <p><span>  The  German  rather  than  the  Nazi  state</span><span>  had  a  view  of  the  Jews  as  a  biologically</span><span>  determined  race.  Frenchman  Comte  Arthur</span><span>  de  Gobineau’s  works  on  “the  essential</span><span>  inequality  of  the  human  races”  postulated</span><span>  that  mixed  and  mongrel  man  had  finally</span><span>  come  together  in  a  “pure  blood  type”  and</span><span>  that  Jews,  as  “baneful  germ  plasms”,  were</span><span>  the  omnipresent  danger  to  that  purity.  De</span><span>  Gobineau  societies  spread  throughout  Ger</span><span>  many,  aided  by  Wagner  and  his  son-in-law,</span><span>  Houston  Stewart  Chamberlain.  They  spear</span><span>  headed  an  antisemitism  which,  while  not</span><span>  yet  physically  murderous,  was  homicidal  in</span><span>  language,  spirit  and  intent.  From  then  on,</span><span>  journals  and  university  departments  of</span><span>  “racial  hygiene”  flourished  —  well  before</span><span>  Hitler.  Volkisch  belief,  now  substantiated</span><span>  by  “science”,  owed  nothing  to  Hitler,  but</span><span>  much  to  Imperial  and  Weimar  Germany.</span></p> <p><span>  Legally,  Jews  received  little  justice  and</span><span>  almost  no  satisfaction  from  the  Weimar</span><span>  courts.  The  Centralverein  fur  deutsche</span><span>  Staatsburger  judischen  Glaubens,  founded  in</span><span>  1893,  spent  decades  fighting  attacks,  calum</span><span>  nies  and  libels  on  Jews,  using  Paragraph</span><span>  130  of  the  Criminal  Code  (on  incitement  to</span><span>  racial  violence)  and  then,  in  despair  at  the</span><span>  courts  finding  any  favour  for  Jews,  using</span><span>  Paragraph  166  on  crimes  against  religion.</span></p> <p><span>  The  chief  defamer  was,  of  course,  Julius</span><span>  Streicher  and  his  Der  Sturmer.  In  the  “Great</span></p> <p><span>  24</span></p> <p><span>  Nuremberg  Ritual  Murder  Trial”  of  1929,</span><span>  Streicher  was  charged  with  suggesting  that</span><span>  some  unsolved  deaths  were  Jewish  ritual</span><span>  murders.  He  was  given  two  months  in</span><span>  prison,  but  nearly  every  other  case  brought</span><span>  against  him  resulted  in  acquittal  because</span><span>  he  argued,  successfully,  that  he  was  never</span><span>  attacking  the  Jewish  religion,  but  the  sepa</span></p> <p><span>  rate  Jewish  race!</span></p> <p><span>  In  1924  a  judge  came  to  the  aid  of  a  news</span><span>  paper  editor  charged  with  incitement</span><span>  against  Jews.  This  was  “far  from  incite</span><span>  ment”,  he  ruled:  “even  the  best  men  of  our</span></p> <p><span>  An  illustration  from  one  ot  Julius  Streicher’s  antisemitic  children’s  books  depicts  blond  German  children  rejoicing  as  grossly  caricatured  Jewish</span><span>  chddren  are  expelled  from  school.  Sbartav  oflhe  Dictators,  Time  Life  Books</span></p> <p><span>  nation  share  this  view”  (of  Jews).  A  Berlin</span><span>  court  rejected  a  Jewish  landlord’s  claim  of</span><span>  defamation  against  an  evicted  foreign  ten</span><span>  ant  who  called  him  “a  German  swine”.  The</span><span>  startling  judgment  was  that  “despite  his</span><span>  German  citizenship,  the  plaintiff  does  not</span><span>  fall  into  the  category  of  persons  popularly</span><span>  connoted  by  the  word  ‘German’.”  Und  so</span><span>  weiter'm  the  pre-Hitlerian  courts.</span></p> <p><span>  The  German  Youth  Movement,  the  Wan</span><span>  denogel,  was  based  on  the  concept  of  Volk</span><span>  —  that  is,  German  faith,  heroism,  tradition,</span><span>  lore  and  all  the  Nordic  virtues.  By  1914,  92</span><span>  percentre  of  the  local  chapters  reported</span><span>  they  had  no  Jewish  members;  in  fact,  84</span><span>  percent  had  specific  constitutional  clauses</span><span>  banning  Jews.  Blau  Weiss,  the  Blue  and</span><span>  White  Jewish  Youth  Movement,  was  found</span><span>  ed  in  1916  in  self-recognition  of  Jews  as  sep</span></p> <p><span>  arate  from  the  mainstream.</span></p> <p><span>  How  comfortable  could  Jews  be  in  such</span><span>  environments?  German  students  were</span><span>  swept  up  by  Volkisch  ideology,  their  frater</span><span>  nities  embracing  virulent  hostility  to  all</span><span>  things  Jewish.  The  Jews  were  “the  enemy</span><span>  within”  —  something  they  expressed  vio</span><span>  lently.</span></p> <p><span>  Die  Mitteilungsblatter,  the  major  Jewish</span><span>  journal  devoted  to  combatting  anti</span><span>  semitism,  had  much  to  report.  Thus,  when</span><span>  a  distinguished  legal  professor  told  his</span><span>  class  to  read  the  works  of  two  Jewish  legal</span><span>  theorists,  he  was  jeered  and  decried.  In</span><span>  1920  Berlin  University  students  threatened</span><span>  to  riot  if  the  university  went  ahead  with  a</span><span>  memorial  service  for  the  assassinated  For</span><span>  eign  Minister,  the  Jewish  Walter  Rathenau.</span></p> <p><span>  As  ever,  the  only  protection  for  Jews  was</span><span>  to  form  their  own  fraternities,  starting  as</span><span>  early  as  1896.  As  ever,  they  were  ostracised</span></p> <p><span>  by  university  authorities  and  closed  (down</span><span>  at  every  opportunity.  Heidelberg  University</span><span>  decreed  that  “the  very  existence  of  a  Jew</span><span>  ish  fraternity  is  sufficient  to  endanger</span><span>  peace  amongst  the  students”.</span></p> <p><span>  The  highest  form  of  social  interaction</span></p> <p><span>  among  students  was  duelling,  for</span><span>  sport  and  for  honour.  Early  on,  Ger</span><span>  man  students  barred  Jews  from  this  signifi</span><span>  cant  activity.  Smash  the  Jewish  conspiracy</span><span>  and  the  Volk  will  flourish  —  that  was  the</span><span>  message  from  noisy  students  and  very</span><span>  silent,  very  acquiescent  professors.</span></p> <p><span>  Jews  were  excluded  from  the  socially</span><span>  important  gymnastic  organisations.  As</span><span>  always,  they  had  to  form  their  own  Tumer</span><span>  schaften.  Gershom  Scholem  has  written</span><span>  poignantly  about  the  assimilating,  German</span><span>  loving,  German-craving  Jews.  The  German</span><span>  liberals  asked:  what  kind  of  civilisation  or</span><span>  religion  or  culture  or  “race”  is  this  that  sur</span><span>  renders  itself  in  this  way?  And  the  Jew</span><span>  haters  asked:  what  kind  of  fifth  column,</span><span>  what  kind  of  bacillus,  is  this  that  invades</span><span>  us,  that  purports  to  be  “us”  when  it  so</span><span>  patently  isn’t,  and  can’t  be?  Crushed  by  this</span><span>  dilemma,  German  Jewish  male  youth  resort</span><span>  ed  to  suicide  in  cosmic  numbers  between</span><span>  the  wars.  Suicide  a  litmus  of  “excellent  rela</span><span>  tions”  within  Germany?</span></p> <p><span>  Einstein,  his  “princely  official  residence\"</span><span>  notwithstanding,  was  hated  by  many.  As</span><span>  one  Nobel  Laureate  observed:  “A  Jew  con</span><span>  spicuously  lacks  understanding  for  the</span><span>  truth,  in  contrast  to  the  Aryan  research  sci</span></p> <p><span>  entist.”</span></p> <p><span>  Rubinstein’s  “golden  age”  of  achievement</span><span>  really  began  with  the  creation,  in  Septem</span><span>  ber  1933,  of  the  first  (and  only)  Jewish  roof</span><span>  body,  the  Reichsuertretung  der  Deutschen</span><span>  Juden,  under  Rabbi  Leo  Baeck.  Under  the</span><span>  direction  of  Martin  Buber,  Jewish  adult  edu</span><span>  cation  programs  led  to  Schocken  Books</span><span>  publishing  5000  tiles  between  1933  and</span><span>  1938.  A  great  achievement  —  but  how</span><span>  “golden\"  were  the  dynamics  that  gave  rise</span></p> <p><span>  to  it?</span></p> <p><span>  So  what  did  the  majority  of  German  Jews</span><span>  perceive  about  their  world?  How  comfort</span></p> <p><span>  able  were  they  in  a  society  in  which  they</span><span>  believed  they  were  integrated  and  accept</span><span>  ed,  in  which  they  pursued  German-ness</span><span>  rather  than  Jewishness,  but  which  degrad</span></p> <p><span>  ed  them  in  special  laws,  denied  them  judi</span><span>  cial  fairness,  excluded  them  from  the  social</span><span>  and  sporting  life  of  universities,  despised</span><span>  them  in  mainstream  literature,  excoriated</span><span>  them  as  racially  different  —  and  danger</span></p> <p><span>  ous?</span></p> <p><span>  What  they  did,  Professor  Rubinstein,  was</span><span>  leave,  in  great  numbers.  To  the  best  of  any</span><span>  one’s  knowledge,  there  were  566,602  Jews</span><span>  in  Germany  in  1933  —1  a  mere  0.86  percent</span><span>  of  the  population.  By  1941,  347,103,  or  60</span><span>  percent,,  had  left.  More,  significant  is  that</span><span>  252,400,  or  just  on  45  percent,  had  left</span></p> <p><span>  before  Kristallnacht,  and  before  the  forced</span><span>  emigration  policy  got  fully  under  way.</span></p> <p><span>  The  years  tell  their  own  story:  63,400  left</span><span>  in  1933,  mainly  due  to  the  “de-Judaising\"  of</span><span>  the  public  service;  45,000  emigrated  in  1934</span><span>  because  of  panic,  uncertainly,  alarm  at  the</span><span>  desecration  of  shules  and  the  increase  in</span><span>  arbitrary  arrests.  Enough  Jews  thought</span><span>  1935  “a  good  year”  —  the  year  the  Nurem</span><span>  berg  Laws  made  them  non-citizens;  the  feel</span><span>  ing  was  that  they  could  accommodate  to</span><span>  this  if  this  was  the  worst  that  was  to  be.</span><span>  “Let’s  wait  another  winter,”  they  ratio</span><span>  nalised,  even  though  the  optimists  knew</span><span>  there  could  be  no  return  to  early  Weimar.</span><span>  Only  35,000  left.  The  following  year  was</span><span>  also  a  “good”  one,  the  Olympic  year,  when</span><span>  34,000  emigrated.  1937  was  the  best  year</span><span>  yet;  there  appeared  to  be  an  “accommoda</span><span>  tion”  of  sorts  and  the  number  of  Jews  in</span><span>  concentration  camps  was  low  —  only  7000!</span><span>  The  following  year,  in  the  10  months  before</span><span>  November  9,49,000  Jews  left.</span></p> <p><span>  Hitler  didn  t  arrive  with  an  X-File  package</span><span>  called  antisemitism.  There  were  two  (or</span><span>  more)  antisemitisms  in  Germany  and  it  cer</span><span>  tainly  was  Hitler  who  radicalised  the  tradi</span><span>  tional  form  of  it.  Rubinstein  asserts  that</span><span>  Jews  were  comfortable  with  the  Weimar</span><span>  brand  and  “enjoyed  excellent  relations”</span><span>  with  their  despisers  and  detractors.  If  that</span><span>  is  true,  then  it  tells  us  something  about</span><span>  some  German  Jews  and  their  perceptions,</span><span>  or  absence  of  them.  To  say  that  they  were</span><span>  happy  is  not  to  say  that  there  was  no</span><span>  objectively  visible  and  provable  danger</span><span>  intrinsic  to  their  past  and  their  present.</span></p> <p><span>  Colin  Tatz  is  Professor  of  Politics  at  Mac</span><span>  quarie  University  and  director  of  Macquarie’s</span><span>  Comparative  Genocide  Studies  Centre.</span></p> "

                        "snippet": "LONDON, Thursday: Two years ago Germany was written off as the sclerotic giant that could recover its economic",
                        "troveUrl": "https://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article132461950?searchTerm=german+date%3A%5B1990-01-01T00%3A00%3A00Z+TO+1999-12-31T00%3A00%3A00Z%5D",
                        "tag": [],
                        "comment": [],
                        "articleText": "<p><span>  German  inflation  beaters</span></p> <p><span>  By  WILL  HUTTON</span></p> <p><span>  LONDON,  Thursday:  Two</span><span>  years  ago  Germany  was  written</span><span>  off  as  the  sclerotic  giant  that</span><span>  could  recover  its  economic  dy-</span><span>  namism  only  if  it  \"Thatcher-</span><span>  ised\"  its  corporatist  economic</span><span>  structure.</span></p> <p><span>  Today,  it  is  beginning  to  re-</span><span>  sume  its  role  as  the  feared  su-</span><span>  per  competitor.</span></p> <p><span>  The  source  of  comparative  ad-</span><span>  vantage  is  simple:  it  is  the</span><span>  country's  capacity  to  mobilise</span><span>  resources  for  investment,  giving</span><span>  it  the  highest  capital  stock  per</span><span>  worker  in  Europe.</span></p> <p><span>  The  debate  about  whether  the</span><span>  resulting  wages  and  social  wel-</span><span>  fare  system  are  too  expensive</span><span>  is,  in  a  sense,  besides  the  point.</span></p> <p><span>  Germany  has  an  investment</span><span>  system  which  gives  it  the</span><span>  wealth  for  such  complaints  to</span><span>  be  possible.</span></p> <p><span>  The  key  is  the  mobilisation  of</span><span>  huge  flows  of  cheap,  low-mar-</span><span>  gin,  long-term  bank  finance  to</span><span>  support  the  build-up  of  industri-</span><span>  al  capital.</span></p> <p><span>  The  German  \"Mittelstand\",</span><span>  the  family  owned  medium-sized</span><span>  companies  which  form  the  back-</span><span>  bone  of  German  industry,  is  a</span><span>  beneficiary  of  the  system  as</span></p> <p><span>  much  as  the  giant  international</span><span>  combines.  Herein  lies  the</span><span>  source  of  German  productivity</span><span>  and  innovation.</span></p> <p><span>  It  is  also  why  there  is  such  a</span><span>  strong  financial  and  industrial</span><span>  interest  in  low  inflation.  Lend-</span><span>  ing  long-term  loans  is  not  very</span><span>  easy  if  the  price  level  keeps  in-</span><span>  creasing  in  an  unstable  and  un-</span><span>  predictable  way  —  if  the  loan's</span><span>  value  halves  in  real  terms  over</span><span>  its  life,  then  making  such  a</span><span>  loan  is  inherently  unattractive.</span></p> <p><span>  The  more  long-term  the  loan,</span><span>  the  greater  the  risk  —  and  thus</span><span>  the  greater  the  interest  in  infla-</span><span>  tion  being  low.</span></p> <p><span>  Thus,  the  success  of  the  Bun-</span><span>  desbank,  praised  by  the  British</span><span>  Right  for  its  anti-inflationary</span><span>  credentials,  is  less  a  result  of</span><span>  its  being  independent  than  be-</span><span>  cause  it  is  part  of  the  anti-infla-</span><span>  tionary  system  upon  which  Ger-</span><span>  man  industrial  success  is  built.</span></p> <p><span>  Hence,  the  strong  desire  to</span><span>  back  it  —  and  the  wariness  of</span><span>  substituting  a  single  European</span><span>  currency  for  the  Deutschemark.</span><span>  Inflation  would  undermine  the</span><span>  source  of  Germany's  compara-</span><span>  tive  advantage.</span></p> <p><span>  The  commitment  of  the  sys-</span><span>  tem  to  providing  long-term  debt</span></p> <p><span>  finance  to  raise  investment  lev-</span></p> <p><span>  els  is  breathtaking.  The  IKB,</span><span>  for  example,  is  an  industrial  in-</span><span>  vestment  bank  with  a  100  loan</span><span>  salesmen  making  between  three</span><span>  to  five  visits  a  day  trying  to  sell</span><span>  Mittelstand  companies</span><span>  long-term  loan  packages.</span></p> <p><span>  The  margin  on  IKB's  lending</span><span>  is  1  per  cent.  Margins  are  bid</span><span>  down  by  keen  competition  be-</span><span>  tween  the  big  regional  Landes-</span><span>  banks,  the  specialist  industrial</span><span>  banks  in  some  regions,  the  local</span><span>  municipal  savings  banks  and</span><span>  the  big  three  commercial  banks</span><span>  —  the  Deutsche,  Dresdner  and</span><span>  Commerzbank.</span></p> <p><span>  Each  has  a  mandate  to  serve</span><span>  particular  markets  —  for  small</span><span>  business  or  for  giant  industrial</span><span>  combines,  but  there  is  a  com-</span><span>  plex  system  for  \"refinancing\"</span><span>  them  so  they  can  get  the</span><span>  long-term  deposits  to  lend.</span></p> <p><span>  For  example,  the  Kreditan-</span><span>  stalt  fur  Wiederaufbau,  the  re-</span><span>  construction  bank,  specialises</span><span>  in  packages  of  long-term  fi-</span><span>  nance  —  partly  raised  from  the</span><span>  Frankfurt  money  markets  and</span><span>  partly  subsidised  by  govern-</span><span>  ment  —  which  can  be  used  for</span><span>  everything  from  export  finance</span><span>  to  social  housing.</span></p> <p><span>  This  avalanche  of  cheap</span><span>  long-term  debt  allows  firms  to</span><span>  be  choosy  about  the  terms  on</span><span>  which  they  raise  money  from</span><span>  the  alternative  source  of  fi-</span><span>  nance  —  the  stock  market.</span></p> <p><span>  Few  medium-sized  companies</span><span>  have  more  than  half  their</span><span>  shares  quoted  on  the  stock  mar-</span><span>  ket,  and  those  that  do  are  care-</span><span>  ful  to  issue  as  many  as  possible</span><span>  without  voting  rights.</span></p> <p><span>  Most  search  for  a  bank,  in-</span><span>  surance  company  or  partner</span><span>  who  will  hold  a  large  block  of</span><span>  equity  as  a  long-term  invest-</span><span>  ment.  Virtually  no  German</span><span>  company  has  a  majority  of  its</span><span>  voting  equity  freely  traded  be</span><span>  tween  a  floating  population  of</span><span>  owners.  Takeover  becomes  more</span><span>  difficult,  another  bias  to  \"long-</span><span>  termism\"  and  more  investment.</span></p> <p><span>  This  is  the  content  in  which</span></p> <p><span>  owners  and  managers  consult</span></p> <p><span>  with  their  workforces  in  works</span><span>  councils.  Ownership  is  secured.</span><span>  Long-term  finance  is  plentiful.</span><span>  Investment  rates  are  high.</span></p> <p><span>  The  task  is  to  get  the  best</span><span>  from  the  human  capital  work-</span><span>  ing  in  the  firm  —  hence  the</span><span>  commitment  of  both  parties  to</span><span>  exchanging  information  and</span></p> <p><span>  consulting.</span></p> <p><span>  —  The  Guardian</span></p> "

                        "articleText": "<p><span>  German  records  found</span></p> <p><span>  By  IAN  McPHEDRAN,</span></p> <p><span>  Foreign  Affairs  Reporter</span></p> <p><span>  German  consular  documents  seized  by</span><span>  Australia  before  both  World  Wars  have</span><span>  been  handed  back  to  the  German  Govern</span><span>  ment  hv  Fnrpicm  Affaire  Minictor-  flarotVi</span></p> <p><span>  Evans,  concluding  what  he  described  as  a</span><span>  \"detective  tale  of  some  consequence\".</span></p> <p><span>  The  documents  were  crated,  vaulted  and  for</span><span>  gotten  at  the  Australian  Archives  until  they</span><span>  were  drawn  to  the  attention  of  a  German  ar</span><span>  chivist,  Dr  Jurgen  Real,  in  1991.</span></p> <p><span>  They  had  been  held  in  secret  by  the  Com</span><span>  monwealth  Investigation  Service,  the  predeces</span><span>  sor  of  the  Australian  Secret  Intelligence  Or</span><span>  ganisation,  when  the  Germans  asked  for  them</span><span>  back  in  the  1950s.                         "articleText": "<p><span>  German  crimes  trial</span></p> <p><span>  ACCUSED  Nazi  war  criminal  Jo</span><span>  sef  Schwammberger  was  indicted</span><span>  last  month  in  court  at  Stuttgart,</span><span>  West  Germany,  on  charges  of</span><span>  murdering  “at  least  50  Jews”  dur</span><span>  ing  World  War  II.  He  also  was</span><span>  charged  as  an  accessory  to  the</span><span>  murder  of  at  least  3,377  other  peo</span><span>  ple,  according  to  the  World  Jew</span><span>  ish  Congress,  which  learned  of  the</span><span>  indictment  from  the  Jewish  com</span><span>  munity  of  West  Berlin.  Schwamm</span><span>  berger  admitted  to  ordering  the</span><span>  execution  of  one  person  under</span><span>  “special  circumstances,”  but  other</span><span>  than  that,  “he  has  completely  de</span><span>  nied  his  crimes,”  according  to  Hel</span><span>  mut  Kronbacher,  spokesman  for</span><span>  the  prosecutor’s  office.</span></p> <p><span>  Schwammberger,  78,  who  is  be</span><span>  ing  held  at  the  Stammheim  maxi</span><span>  mum  security  prison,  was</span><span>  extradited  from  Argentina  in  May,</span><span>  after  a  long  proceeding  that  in</span><span>  cluded  his  hospitalisation  in  an  Ar</span><span>  gentine  hospital  for  a  mysterious</span><span>  coma.  The  Stuttgart  court  found</span><span>  him  fit  to  stand  trial.  The</span><span>  prosecutor’s  office  said  the  trial</span><span>  would  probably  begin  early  next</span><span>  year.  That  would  likely  make</span><span>  Schwammberger  the  first  alleged</span><span>  Nazi  war  criminal  to  be  tried  in  a</span><span>  unified  Germany.  A  guilty  verdict</span><span>  would  bring  a  life  sentence.</span></p> <p><span>  A  former  lieutenant  in  the  Waf</span><span>  fen  SS  and  commandant  of  several</span><span>  concentration  camps  in  Poland,</span><span>  Schwammberger  allegedly  was</span><span>  known  for  his  particularly  cruel</span><span>  killings  of  Jews.  He  has  been  ac</span><span>  |  cused  by  survivors  of  camps  of</span></p> <p><span>  Jewish  areas  in  the  Polish  towns  of</span><span>  Przemysl,  Mielec,  Rozwadow  and</span><span>  Stalowa-Wola  of  smashing</span></p> <p><span>  children’s  heads  against  walls,</span><span>  throwing  people  alive  into  fires</span><span>  and  shooting  people  point-blank.</span><span>  Witnesses  said  they  saw</span><span>  Schwammberger  use  pliers  to  re</span><span>  move  gold  teeth  from  prisoners.</span><span>  He  was  known  as  the  “butcher  of</span><span>  Rozwadow.”</span></p> <p><span>  After  the  war,  Schwammberger</span><span>  was  arrested  in  Austria  with  bags</span><span>  of  jewellery  stolen  from  Jews,</span><span>  which  he  admitted  under  question</span><span>  ing.  He  escaped,  probably  in  1948,</span><span>  to  Argentina  with  what  is  believed</span><span>  to  have  been  help  from  Odessa,  a</span><span>  Nazi  fugitive  network. The  Austrian  police  files</span><span>  were  obtained  by  the  Anti</span><span>  Defamation  League  of  B’nai</span></p> <p><span>  B’rith.</span></p> <p><span>  The  indictment  in  Stuttgart</span><span>  stems  from  a  warrant  for</span><span>  Schwammberger’s  arrest  that  West</span><span>  Germany  issued  in  1972.  Addi</span><span>  tional  charges  against  him  were</span><span>  made  in  recent  years. Their  presence  signalled</span><span>  that  Jews  are  prepared  to  adjust</span><span>  to  the  reality  of  one  Germany,  if</span><span>  it  adheres  unswervingly  to  demo</span><span>  cratic  principles  and  peace. He  said  he  understood</span><span>  “the  intensity  of  their  anger  and</span><span>  their  bitterness”,  but  added,  “We</span><span>  are  here  because  we  have  some</span><span>  thing  to  say  to  a  united  Ger</span><span>  many.”</span></p> <p><span>  Although  they  delivered  their</span><span>  speeches  separately,  Mr  Bronf</span><span>  man  and  Mr  Kohl  engaged  in  a</span><span>  dialogue  of  sorts.
