The  new  Ger</span><span>  many  must  be  a  true  democracy,</span><span>  which  means  that  “all  minorities</span><span>  are  guaranteed  equal  protection</span><span>  under  the  law”,  he  said.  He  also</span><span>  said  the  German  people  “must</span><span>  always  support  Israel.  You  must</span><span>  never  help  those  who  would  help</span><span>  destroy  the  Jewish  State.”</span></p> <p><span>  Mr  Bronfman  said  Germany</span></p> <p><span>  must  never  become  a  nuclear</span><span>  power.  Nor  must  it  have  the</span><span>  means  of  perpetrating  mass  kill</span><span>  ing  or  destruction  through  bio</span><span>  logical  or  chemical  warfare.  It</span><span>  should  also  not  help  any  third</span><span>  party  attain  such  a  capability,  he</span><span>  said,  alluding  to  the  involvement</span><span>  of  West  German  firms  in  the  con</span></p> <p><span>  struction.of  a  chemical  weapons</span><span>  factory  in  Libya.</span></p> <p><span>  “Germany  must  enact  strong</span><span>  legislation  to  prevent  such  threats</span><span>  against  mankind  and  against</span><span>  Israel  and  vigilantly  enforce  that</span><span>  legislation.  Never,  never  streng</span><span>  then  the  enemies  of  Israel!”  Mr</span><span>  Bronfman  declared.  “The  path</span><span>  for  the  new  Germany  should  be</span><span>  clear,”  he  said.  “The  Jewish  peo</span><span>  ple  pray  that  you  will  prove  that</span><span>  the  world  has  nothing  to  fear,</span><span>  that  you  will  follow  the  path</span><span>  away  from  your  worst  traditions</span><span>  and  towards  the  best  traditions  of</span><span>  which  you  are  so  capable.</span></p> <p><span>  “The  great  challenge  is  to  build</span></p> <p><span>  (Continued  on  page  28)</span></p> <p><span>  GERMAN</span></p> <p><span>  (Continued  irom  page  3)</span></p> <p><span>  a  Germany  firmly  rooted  in  peace</span><span>  and  respect  for  universal  human</span><span>  values,”  he  concluded.</span></p> <p><span>  In  response,  Mr  Kohl  sketched</span><span>  his  vision  of  the  responsibilities</span><span>  of  a  united  Germany.</span></p> <p><span>  “It  remains  the  duty  of  all</span><span>  democratic  forces  to  fight  with</span><span>  out  compromise  all  those  who</span><span>  spread  antisemitic  prejudice  or</span><span>  decry  the  Jewish  religion  and</span><span>  faith,”  the  chancellor  said.  “For</span><span>  us  Germans  one  of  the  most  im</span><span>  portant  lessons  of  history  is  that  a</span><span>  democracy  must  not  put  itself  at</span><span>  the  mercy  of  its  enemies,  but</span><span>  must  actively  fight  them.”</span></p> <p><span>  With  respect  to  German  rela</span><span>  tions  with  Israel,  Mr  Kohl</span><span>  stressed  that  “close,  trustful  dia</span><span>  logue  must  remain  a  key  element</span><span>  of  the  Middle  East  policy  pursued</span><span>  by  a  united  Germany.  I  per</span><span>  sonally  guarantee  this,”  he</span><span>  added.</span></p> <p><span>  “To  us  Germans  the  right  of</span><span>  self-determination  of  nations,</span><span>  including  our  own,  is  a  particu</span><span>  larly  valuable  asset,”  Mr  Kohl  ex</span><span>  plained.  “However,  we  are  also</span><span>  aware  that  Palestinians’  right  of</span><span>  self-determination  meets  its  limits</span><span>  where  Israel’s  right  to  exist  is  con</span><span>  cerned.  A  fair  balance  must  be</span><span>  found  between  the  legitimate  in</span><span>  terests  of  both  sides,”  he  said.</span></p> <p><span>  The  chancellor  directly  ad</span><span>  dressed  the  question  of  whether</span><span>  the  Federal  Republic’s  relations</span><span>  with  Israel  and  the  way  it  has</span><span>  dealt  with  its  Nazi  past  will  be</span><span>  continued  in  the  future  by  a</span><span>  united  Germany.</span></p> <p><span>  While  he  answered  with  a  re</span><span>  sounding  affirmative,  he  admit</span><span>  ted  that  much  educational  work</span><span>  must  be  done  in  East  Germany  so</span><span>  that  the  people  there  have  a  true</span><span>  picture  of  the  terrors  and  horrors</span><span>  of  the  Nazi  past,  instead  of  the</span><span>  distorted  picture  created  by  the</span><span>  former  communist  regime.</span></p> <p><span>  Mr  Kohl  also  spoke  of  the</span><span>  dangers  of  rising  nationalism  in</span><span>  Europe.                         "articleText": "<p><span>  German  recession</span><span>  nearing  bottom</span></p> <p><span>  From  STEVE  CRAWSHAW</span></p> <p><span>  in  Bonn</span></p> <p><span>  LEADING  economic  fore</span></p> <p><span>  casting  organisations  in</span><span>  Germany  suggested  on</span><span>  Monday  that  the  country's  reces</span><span>  sion  was  poised  to  bottom  out.</span><span>  Five  of  the  six  main  economic  in</span><span>  stitutes,  in  their  joint  annual  re</span><span>  port,  predicted  growth  next  year  of</span><span>  1.5  per  cent  -  1  per  cent  in  the</span><span>  west,  and  7  per  cent  in  the  east.</span></p> <p><span>  Inflation  is  predicted  to  fall</span><span>  slightly.  Prices  are  expected  to  rise</span><span>  by  around  3.5  per  cent  in  western</span><span>  Germany  and  by  4.5  per  cent  in</span><span>  the  east.  But  unemployment  is  ex</span><span>  pected  to  rise  further,  to  2.6  mil</span><span>  lion  in  the  west  and  1.2  million  in</span><span>  the  east,  giving  an  overall  figure  of</span><span>  just  under  10  per  cent.</span></p> <p><span>  One  of  the  six  organisations</span><span>  takes  a  dissenting,  more  pessimis</span><span>  tic,  view,  which  is  presented  sepa</span><span>  rately  within  the  100-page  report.</span><span>  The  German  Institute  for  Eco</span><span>  nomic  Research  in  Berlin  argues</span><span>  that  there  will  be  a  further  0.5  per</span><span>  cent  contraction  of  the  economy</span><span>  next  year,  on  top  of  the  1.5  per  cent</span><span>  shrinkage  this  year.  But  even  the</span><span>  institute  tempers  its  pessimism</span></p> <p><span>  with  talk  of  a  turnaround  by  the</span><span>  middle  of  next  year.</span></p> <p><span>  The  annual  autumn  forecast  of</span><span>  the  six  organisations  accuses  the</span><span>  Government  of  having  \"no  medi</span><span>  um-term  plan\"  for  its  economic</span><span>  and  financial  policies,  and  sug</span><span>  gests  that  it  deals  \"only  in  ad  hoc</span><span>  measures\".  This  phrase  was  seized</span><span>  on  by  the  opposition  Social  Demo</span><span>  crats. vinced  than  ever  that  Serbia  is  the</span><span>  target  of  an  international  conspira-</span></p> <p><span>  cy.</span></p> <p><span>  If  Serbian  officials  and  media</span><span>  commentators  are  to  be  believed,</span><span>  Yugoslavia  is  now  the  victim  of  a</span><span>  German-Austrian  plot  to  dominate</span><span>  central  Europe  again.</span></p> <p><span>  The  republic,  Yugoslavia's  larg-</span><span>  est,  has  traditionally  been  distrust-</span><span>  ful  of  both  Germany  and  Austria,</span><span>  against  which  it  fought  in  two  world</span></p> <p><span>  wars.</span></p> <p><span>  It  perceives  that  the  West  Euro-</span><span>  peans  consider  Serbia,  ruled  for</span><span>  centuries  by  Turks  who  wiped  out</span><span>  much  of  its  impressive  art  and  liter-</span><span>  ature,  as  backward.</span></p> <p><span>  The  supposed  conspiracy,  aimed</span></p> <p><span>  at  resurrecting  a  \"Fourth  Reich\"</span><span>  consisting  of  Germany  and  the  pre-</span><span>  World  War  I  Austro-Hungarian</span><span>  Empire,  is  responsible  for  Slove-</span><span>  nia's  and  Croatia's  break  with  Yu-</span><span>  goslavia,  TV  commentator  Mila</span><span>  Stula  said.</span></p> <p><span>  Both  republics,  Yugoslavia's</span><span>  northernmost  states,  declared  them-</span><span>  selves  independent  on  June  25.</span></p> <p><span>  Though  Serbia  is  expected</span><span>  grudgingly  to  accept  Slovenian  in-</span><span>  dependence,  it  is  unlikely  to  see  ri-</span><span>  val  Croatia  go  the  same  way</span><span>  without  trying  to  annex  large</span><span>  chunks  of  its  territory  where  ethnic</span><span>  Serbs controlled  by  the  central</span><span>  government.</span></p> <p><span>  \"German  and  Austrian  interests</span><span>  are  once  again  behind  Slovenia's</span><span>  and  Croatia's <p><span>  A  theory  developed  by  law  pro-</span><span>  fessor  and  ideologue  Budimir  Kosu-</span><span>  tic,  of  Serbia's  ruling  party,  even</span><span>  implicated  the  United  States  in  a</span><span>  global  conspiracy  to  prevent  the</span><span>  unity  of  Europe.</span></p> <p><span>  Even  before  Slovenia's  and  Cro-</span><span>  atia's  independence 2</span></p> <p><span>  'German-inspired  plot'</span></p> <p><span>  Continued  from  Page  1</span></p> <p><span>  State-controlled  media  condemned  Wash-</span><span>  ington's  admonishments  that  Serbia's  elected</span><span>  Government  of  renamed  communists  was</span><span>  committing  human-rights  violations  and  not</span><span>  observing  democratic  freedoms.</span></p> <p><span>  The  Serbs  also  rejected  US  State  Depart-</span><span>  ment  urgings  that  they  drop  their  objection  to</span><span>  the  election  of  Stipe  Mesic,  a  Croat,  as  chair-</span><span>  man  of  the  federal  presidency.</span></p> <p><span>  They  told  the  Americans  to  keep  out  of</span><span>  Yugoslav  affairs,  permitting  Mr  Mesic's unbeatable  global  competitor,\"  Mr  Ko-</span><span>  sutic  wrote  in  the  mass-circulation  Politika</span><span>  Ekspres.</span></p> <p><span>  To  prevent  Europe  from  uniting,  the nia,\"  Mr  Kosutic  said.</span></p> <p><span>  \"A  scenario  created  in  a  special  operations</span></p> <p><span>  centre  in  Vienna,  which  includes  representa-</span><span>  tives  from Baltic  to  the  Adriatic.\"</span></p> <p><span>  Their  aim,  according  to  Mr  Kosutic,  \"is  the</span><span>  break-up  of  Yugoslavia  [and]  renewed  geno-</span><span>  cide  against  the  Serbian  people\".</span></p> <p><span>  In  a  veiled  reference  to  Hungary,  Politika</span><span>  also  accused  \"other  traditional  enemies  of  the</span><span>  Serbian  people  in  our                         "articleText": "<p><span>  Strikes  hamstring</span><span>  German  airports</span></p> <p><span>  FRANKFURT:  Frankfurt  airport  re</span><span>  opened  yesterday  after  security  staff</span><span>  strikes  on  Tuesday  forced  a  one-day</span><span>  closure  but  German  air  travel  contin</span><span>  ued  to  be  dogged  by  delays.</span></p> <p><span>  Closures  at  other  airports  and  logisti</span><span>  cal  problems  caused  by  the  diversion  of</span><span>  flights  on  Tuesday  meant  delays  were</span><span>  likely  on  most  services,  a  spokesman</span><span>  for  the  national  carrier  Lufthansa  said.</span></p> <p><span>  Airports  in  Hanover,  Hamburg,  and</span><span>  Berlin's  Tegel  and  Tempelhof  re</span><span>  mained  shut  due  to  striking  security</span><span>  staff.</span></p> <p><span>  Stuttgart  airport  was  also  closcd  for</span><span>  the  first  time  since  the  wave  of  stop</span><span>  pages  began  10  days  ago  —  the  longest</span><span>  public  service  strike  in  post-war  Ger</span></p> <p><span>  many.</span></p> <p><span>  A  spokesman  for  the  largest  public</span><span>  service  union,  OeTV,  said  his  union</span><span>  was  calling  300,000  workers  out  on</span><span>  strike  yesterday.</span></p> <p><span>  It  has  been  the  highest  number  called</span><span>  out  so  far,  up  from  275,000  the  previ</span><span>  ous  day.                         "articleText": "<p><span>  Mareike  's  Germanfestivities</span></p> <p><span>  M</span><span>  areike  Schlessmann  Mareike  is  from</span><span>  Prum,  in  Germany,  near  the  border  of</span><span>  Belgium.</span><span>  On  a  student  exchange,  she  is  going  to  school  at</span><span>  St  Joseph's  College.  She  said  people  started</span><span>  celebrating  Christmas  on  December  24,  usually</span><span>  by  going  to  church  in  the  evening.</span><span>  Mareike  said  the  main  reason  for  this  was</span><span>  because  Germany  in  winter  was  very  dark  and</span><span>  the  Christmas  trees  and  lights  looked  spectacular.</span><span>  In  Mereike's  part  of  Germany,  a  vvhite</span><span>  Christmas  is  quite  unusual.  Because  her</span><span>  grandparents  Iive  a  long  distance  away,  she</span><span>  usually  celebrates  Christmas  with  her  brother,</span><span>  sister  and  parents:</span><span>  I</span><span>  n  Germany  we  celebrate  Christmas  on  the</span><span>  24th,  in  the  evening.  If  you're  religious  you  go</span><span>  to  church  in  the  evening  and  then  you  go  home</span><span>  and  get  your  presents.</span><span>  On  the  25th  we  don't  go  to  mass.  It's  a  family</span><span>  day;  you  spend  the  day  with  family.  It's  always</span><span>  warm  inside  and  dark  and  cold  outside.  My</span><span>  mother  usually  cooks  ducks  and  we  always  cook</span><span>  cookies  with  icing.  Everyone  starts  cooking  them</span><span>  in  November  and  keeps  cooking  them  until</span><span>  Christmas.</span><span>  People  with  open  fire-places  also  often  cook</span><span>  apples  in  the  fire  or  else  in  the  oven.</span><span>  Mareike  has  a  recipe  for  some  of  the  cookies</span><span>  her  family  bakes  for  the  Christmas  festivities.</span></p> <p><span>  Black  and  White  biseuits</span><span>  Ingredients:</span><span>  300  grams  of  butter</span><span>  150  grams  of  castor  sugar</span><span>  pinch  of  salt</span><span>  400  grams  plain  flour</span><span>  30  grams  cocoa</span><span>  egg-white</span><span>  Method:</span><span>  Knead  the  butter  with  castor  sugar  and  salt.</span><span>  Add  flour,  knead  again  and  divide  the  dough</span><span>  into  two  equal  parts.</span><span>  Knead  cocoa  into  one  part.</span><span>  Leave  both  dough  portions  wrapped  in  foil  for</span><span>  two  hours  in  the  fridge.</span><span>  Roll  both  dough  portions  out  to  the  same  size</span><span>  and  place  on  plates  that  have  been  coated  with</span><span>  egg-white.  The  egg-white  makes  the  two  doughs</span><span>  stick  together.  Place  the  dough  on  top  of  each</span><span>  other  and  roll  up.  Retum  to  fridge  until  cold  and</span><span>  then  cut  the  roll  into  half  centimetre  thick  slices.</span><span>  Bake  at  190  degrees  celsius  for  10  minutes.</span><span>  Biseuits  will  harden  on  cooling.</span></p> <p><span>  •  Away  from  home...  exchangee  Mareike</span><span>  Schlessmann.</span></p> "

                        "tag": [],

                        "articleText": "<p><span>  German  honour  for  Goldhagen</span></p> <p><span>  DANIEL  DAGAN</span></p> <p><span>  BONN  —  The  Bonn-based</span><span>  Journal  for  German  and</span></p> <p><span>  International  Politics  has  decided</span><span>  to  award  author  Daniel  Goldhagen</span><span>  its  annual  Democracy  Prize.</span></p> <p><span>  In  a  statement,  the  journal</span><span>  said  Goldhagen,  more  than  any</span><span>  other  scholar,  stirred  the  con</span><span>  science  of  the  German  public</span><span>  with  his  book  Hitler's  Willing</span></p> <p><span>  Executioners.</span></p> <p><span>  In  August,  the  book  sold  out</span><span>  its  first  German  edition  of  40,000</span><span>  copies  in  less  than  a  week  and</span><span>  prompted  a  flurry  of  debate.</span></p> <p><span>  For  many  Jews  in  Germany,</span><span>  the  book’s  value  lies  in  that  it  tells</span><span>  non-Jewish  Germans  that  the</span><span>  Holocaust  did  not  begin  in  the  gas</span><span>  chambers  and  was  not  perpetrat</span><span>  ed  solely  by  SS  officials  in  the</span><span>  death  camps.</span></p> <p><span>  They  point  to  Goldhagen’s</span><span>  suggestion  that  the  persecution</span><span>  began  in  schools,  at  the  work</span><span>  place,  in  stores,  at  every  street</span><span>  comer  —  that  it  was  committed</span></p> <p><span>  by  millions  of  “simple”  Germans</span><span>  from  every  walk  of  life.</span></p> <p><span>  Daniel  Goldhagen</span></p> <p><span>  Goldhagen,  whose  book  has</span><span>  been  on  Germany’s  bestseller  list</span><span>  for  months,  told  the  editors  of  the</span><span>  journal,  “When  I  wrote  my  book  I</span><span>  believed  it  was  only  about  how  to</span><span>  understand  and  think  about  the</span><span>  past.</span></p> <p><span>  “More  and  more,  I  have  come</span><span>  to  realise  that  the  book  is  also</span></p> <p><span>  about  the  present  and  the</span></p> <p><span>  future.”</span></p> <p><span>  Meanwhile,  the  public  debate</span><span>  continues  about  Goidhagen’s  the</span><span>  sis,  though  with  less  intensity</span><span>  than  when  the  book  was  first  pub</span><span>  lished  here  last  year.</span></p> <p><span>  Frank  Schirmacher,  co-pub</span><span>  lisher  of  the  daily  Frankfurter</span><span>  Allgemeine  Zeitung,  wrote</span><span>  recently:  “Goldhagen  is  building  a</span><span>  new  mythology  around  the</span><span>  Holocaust.  He  traces  it  back  to</span><span>  the  Faustian  depths  of  German</span><span>  consciousness  and,  by  doing  so,</span><span>  prevents  it  from  being  dealt  with</span></p> <p><span>  on  a  rational  basis.”</span></p> <p><span>  Rudolf  Augstein,  founder  and</span><span>  publisher  of  Der  Spiegel,  wrote,</span><span>  on  the  other  hand,  that  while</span><span>  “very  little,  one  could  even  say</span><span>  next  to  nothing”  was  to  be  gained</span><span>  from  Goidhagen’s  book,  “the  sim</span><span>  ple  fact  that  the  history  of  the</span><span>  Holocaust  is  being  gone  into</span><span>  again  can  only  be  good,  and  will</span><span>  certainly  cause  a  stir.</span></p> <p><span>  “If  Goldhagen  manages  this,”</span><span>  he  concluded,  “he  will  have</span></p> <p><span>  achieved  quite  a  lot.</span></p> <p><span>  JTA</span></p> "

                        "articleText": "<p><span>  German  Army  exhibit  halted</span></p> <p><span>  BERLIN:  A  controversial  exhibit  on  Hitler’s</span><span>  army  will  not  come  to  New  York  next  month</span><span>  because  of  charges  that  some  of  the  atroci</span><span>  ties  depicted  in  the  exhibit  were  not  com</span><span>  mitted  by  German  soldiers.</span></p> <p><span>  Last  week,  the  head  of  the  institute  that</span><span>  mounted  the  exhibit  admitted  that  one  of</span><span>  the  atrocities  covered  in  the  show  —  the</span><span>  1941  murder  of  4500  Jews  in  a  Soviet  town  —</span><span>  was  committed  by  Lithuanian  Nazis,  not  by</span><span>  the  German  Army.</span></p> <p><span>  The  show  has  been  closed  amid  allega</span><span>  tions  that  some  parts  of  the  exhibit  may</span><span>  depict  victims  of  the  Soviet  secret  service.</span></p> <p><span>  The  exhibit,  which  is  meant  to  illustrate</span><span>  the  role  that  ordinary  German  soldiers</span><span>  played  in  the  Holocaust,  includes  photo</span><span>  graphs,  letters  and  other  documents  from</span><span>  World  War  II.  Opponents  claim  it  brands  all</span><span>  veterans  of  the  wartime  German  Army,  the</span><span>  Wehrmacht,  as  criminals  instead  of  honour</span><span>  ing  the  vast  majority  for  serving  their  coun</span><span>  try.</span></p> <p><span>  During  its  tour  of  Germany  and  Austria</span><span>  during  the  past  four  years,  the  exhibit  has</span><span>  generated  heated  protests  —  and,  in  some</span><span>  cases,  violence.  At  almost  every  stop,  the</span><span>  exhibit  has  attracted  neo-Nazis  who  handed</span><span>  out  fliers  claiming  that  the  photos  were  fal</span><span>  sified,  and  that  “our  grandfathers  were  not</span></p> <p><span>  criminals”.</span></p> <p><span>  Jan  Philipp  Reemstma,  head  of  the</span><span>  Hamburg  Institute  for  Social  Research,</span><span>  which  mounted  the  exhibit,  announced  the</span><span>  delay  in  sending  it  to  New  York,  saying  it  will</span><span>  take  researchers  at  least  three  months  to</span><span>  answer  questions  recently  raised  about</span><span>  some  of  the  photographs  in  The  War  of</span><span>  Extermination:  Crimes  of  the  Wehrmacht  from</span></p> <p><span>  1941  to  1944.</span></p> <p><span>  Supporters  say  the  exhibit  has  raised</span><span>  awareness  of  a  taboo  chapter  of  German  his</span><span>  tory  because  it  proves  that  ordinary  German</span></p> <p><span>  soldiers,  and  not  only  the  Nazi  SS,  were</span><span>  responsible  for  committing  atrocities  during</span></p> <p><span>  World  War  11.</span></p> <p><span>  Historian  Andreas  Nachama,  leader  of</span><span>  Berlin’s  Jewish  community,  said  he  thought</span><span>  the  exhibit  has  been  “overestimated  by  both</span><span>  its  friends  and  enemies.  We  knew  there  were</span><span>  many  historical  mistakes  in  it.”  Nachama,</span><span>  the  former  director  of  the  Berlin  museum</span><span>  Topography  of  Terror,  an  archive  and  exhib</span><span>  it  located  at  the  site  of  the  Gestapo’s  former</span><span>  headquarters.  “It  is  important  to  present</span><span>  such  material  to  the  public.  But  you  have  to</span><span>  be  very  careful,  especially  if  it  is  something</span><span>  new  for  the  general  public.”</span></p> <p><span>  The  involvement  of  the  Wehrmacht  in</span><span>  World  War  II  atrocities  has  long  been  known.</span><span>  But  discussion  of  this  involvement  was</span><span>  brought  to  the  fore  by  the  exhibit,  which</span><span>  presented  evidence  of  these  acts  to  the  gen</span><span>  eral  public.  More  than  800,000  visitors  in</span><span>  Germany  and  Austria  have  seen  the  exhibit,</span><span>  which  contains  1400  photos,  more  than  half</span><span>  of  them  portraits.</span></p> <p><span>  Reemstma’s  announcement  that  the  show</span><span>  would  close  came  after  an  appeal  by  a  leader</span><span>  of  the  Christian  Democratic  Party,  Michael</span><span>  Glos,  that  Foreign  Minister  Joschka  Fischer</span><span>  “use  all  necessary  means”  to  stop  the  exhib</span><span>  it  from  being  sent  to  New  York.  He  said  the</span><span>  Foreign  Ministry  should  be  working  to  help</span><span>  build  a  positive  image  of  Germany  abroad.</span><span>  Glos  said  the  exhibit  would  only  heighten</span><span>  prejudices  against  Germans  and  could  dam</span><span>  age  the  good  relationship  between  the</span><span>  United  States  and  Germany.</span></p> <p><span>  Reemstma  admitted  that  a  loss  of  credibil</span><span>  ity  threatened  to  undermine  the  exhibit’s</span><span>  thesis.  He  added  that  researchers  had  too</span><span>  often  depended  on  archival  descriptions  of</span><span>  photos.                         "articleText": "<p><span>  Sister  enjoys  German  food</span></p> <p><span>  ST  Joseph's  School  Principal</span><span>  Josephine  Dubiel  while</span><span>  very  busy  with  her  work,</span><span>  finds  time  to  enjoy  cooking</span><span>  German  meals.</span><span>  Sr  Josephine's  love  for  German</span><span>  meals  stems  from  her  family</span><span>  background.</span><span>  Her  mother  was  German  and</span><span>  her  father  was  Polish  and</span><span>  emigrated  to  Australia  following</span><span>  World  War  Two.</span><span>  They  were  among  the  first</span><span>  refugees  to  be  stationed  at</span><span>  Woodside.</span><span>  Sr  Josephine  said  she  lived</span><span>  with  three  other  sisters,  at  St</span><span>  Joseph's  convent  at  Port  Lincoln,</span><span>  who  all  shared  the  cooking.</span><span>  However  she  mainly  cooked</span><span>  on  the  weekend  when  she  had</span><span>  time  away  from  her  school</span><span>  commitments.</span><span>  She  admitted  to  being  a  sweet</span><span>  tooth,  and  German  food  provided</span><span>  a  wealth  of  delicious  tortes,</span><span>  desserts  and  cakes.</span><span>  Sr  Josephine  shares  some  of</span><span>  her  favourite  recipes  with</span><span>  Lifestyle  readers:</span><span>  Pancake  soup</span><span>  Ingredients</span><span>  Prepare  your  favourite  beef</span><span>  stock</span><span>  Pancake  mixture</span><span>  2  heaped  tablespoons  of  plain</span><span>  flour</span><span>  2  eggs</span><span>  pinch  of  salt</span><span>  milk</span><span>  Method</span><span>  Beat  this  mixture  until  it  is  a</span></p> <p><span>  smooth  and  thin  batter.</span><span>  Cook  as  very  thin  pancakes,</span><span>  and  then  roll  up  the  pancakes</span><span>  and  cut  into  very  thin  slices  (so</span><span>  it  looks  like  noodles).</span><span>  Place  about  half  a  cup  of  the</span><span>  pancake  noodles  into  a  soup</span><span>  bowl  and  add  very  hot  stock.</span><span>  Garnish  with  chopped  chives.</span><span>  Stuffed  capsicums</span><span>  (served  as  a  light  meal  or  as</span><span>  accompaniment  to  meat)</span><span>  Ingredients</span><span>  large  capsicum</span><span>  2  middle-sized  potatoes  almost</span><span>  cooked  and  lightly  mashed</span><span>  150  grams  shredded  Edam  or</span><span>  tasty  cheese</span><span>  1  onion  chopped</span><span>  150  grams  of  bacon  or  ham</span><span>  finely  chopped</span><span>  2  eggs</span><span>  100  grams  peas  (canned  or</span><span>  slightly  cooked  if  frozen)</span><span>  1  dessertspoon  of  plain  flour</span><span>  salt  and  pepper</span><span>  few  drops  of  tabasco  sauce</span><span>  Method</span><span>  Halve  the  capsicums,  remove</span><span>  seeds  and  wash.</span><span>  b</span><span>  m</span><span>  s</span><span>  s</span><span>  t</span><span>  m</span><span>  b</span></p> <p><span>  Combine  all  other  ingredients</span><span>  and  fill  the  capsicum  with  the</span><span>  mixture.</span><span>  Place  in  a  Pyrex  dish,  add</span><span>  about  250  ml  of  water  or  stock</span><span>  and  bake  at  210  degrees  Celsius</span><span>  for  30  to  40  minutes.</span><span>  Cherry  cake</span><span>  (Kirschkuchen)</span><span>  Ingredients</span><span>  80  grams  butter</span><span>  80  grams  sugar</span><span>  2  eggs</span><span>  grated  lemon  rind</span><span>  6  dessertspoons  of  milk</span><span>  250  grams  of  self-raising  flour</span><span>  melted  butter</span><span>  drained  pitted  black  cherries</span><span>  Method</span><span>  Combine  butter  and  sugar.</span><span>  Add  eggs  and  lemon.</span><span>  Mix  with  flour  and  milk  alternately</span><span>  to  make  a  dough.</span><span>  Grease  a  baking  tray  (about</span><span>  20  to  30  cm)  and  roll  out  the</span><span>  dough  to  form  the  base.</span><span>  Brush  over  with  melted  butter</span><span>  and  spread  cherries  over  the</span><span>  ase.</span><span>  Bake  about  15  minutes  in  a</span><span>  oderate  oven.</span><span>  Topping</span><span>  3  to  4  egg  whites</span><span>  100  grams  of  sugar  or  caster</span><span>  ugar</span><span>  Beat  the  egg  whites  with  the</span><span>  ugar  well  and  then  spread  over</span><span>  he  cake.</span><span>  Bake  a  further  10  to  15</span><span>  inutes  until  the  topping</span><span>  rowns.</span><span>  d</span></p> <p><span>  •  St  Joseph's  School  Principal  Josephine  Dubiel  prepared  this  stuffed  capsicum</span><span>  ish  in  advance  as  a  quick  and  easy  light  meal  which  only  needs  to  be  baked  and</span><span>  is  then  ready  to  eat.</span></p> "
